Ah, you forest, forest dark,
You forest of Miletin!
How is it you alone are green
In winter as in summer?

I would fain not weep,
Nor grieve my heart,
But tell me true, good people,
Who would not cry thus?

Where is my father, dear father?
He is lying in his grave. Where is my mother, good mother?
The grass it grows above her.

I've no brother, I've no sister,
Young men took them from me.

啊，这森林，这漆黑的森林，
米勒丁的森林！
为何只有你常披青绿
无论冬夏？

我无意哭泣，
更不愿感伤，
但是告诉我，苍生，
如何才能忍住泪水？

我的父亲身在何处，亲爱的父亲？
他早已入土。
我的母亲身在何处，亲爱的母亲？
她早已为荒草掩埋。

我没有兄弟，也没有姐妹。
战争已将他们从我身边夺去。

The cooks for us will brew
From mist and fog a stew,
From darkness roasted game
And venison in dreams,
Stew a log of wood
Or a club for food,
To honour guests and treat them.
Such food they serve to feed them
Would better serve to beat them! Keep your food so rough.
Black pudding with barley
And cabbage we love,
Buttermilk and whey,
Mashed peas,
Noodles with seeds
Of poppy, smoked ham too,
A pumpkin or two,
And chickpea stew!

做好我们的午饭
就着雾霾用餐，
想象着野味的烤香，
鹿肉只存在于梦乡。
再下锅木头一根，
或是一截木棍，
以热情招待我们的客人。
与其用这种食物款待他们，
还不如将其用来将他们暴揍一顿！ 粗茶淡饭已是足够。
要黑布丁配大麦，
还有心爱的卷心菜，
要乳酪和乳清，
还有豆泥作伴，
要罂粟种子做的面食，
熏火腿也不能缺席，
偶尔来一两个南瓜，
炖鹰嘴豆也美味可口！

Now has winter come,
Hear you, ragged ones!
Evil times are on us
And of clothing none!
Evil winds blow,
Evil is sown!
Blasts of bitter weather,
One upon another,
Bringing nought but bother Heavy falls the snow,
Foretelling great woe!
Worn threadbare your cloak,
Hose torn and shoes are broke.
We sleep through summer
Heedless in slumber
Of next winter's snows.
How great our woes,
How poor our clothes! Ye poor, be of good cheer,
Joy is with us here!
Clothes worn away,
Heads turned to grey!
Despair, poor ones,
Shall guide us on,
What can we endeavour?
Our path forever
To seek God's favour. Caps from our heads torn,
None is left to keep.
What grief we have sown
So shall we yet reap!
Sheaves cut short
And sad of heart.
In Bohemia what to do,
But to the tavern go,
For relief from woe?

凛冬已至，
听着，衣衫褴褛的人们！
日子一天比一天难熬，
我们连件衣服都没搞到！
恶魔的风呼啸而过，
将撒旦的种子撒播！
寒冷的侵袭，
一日胜过一日，
只让人苦恼不已。 大雪纷飞不停，
预言着灾祸无情！
你的袍子褴褛不堪，
靴子踏破，鞋子踩烂。
我们睡过了炎夏，
美梦的帷幕还没落下，
隆冬的雪便将我们冻醒。
灾祸是多么无情，
我们的衣衫是如此八碎七零！ 然而贫穷之人们，振作起来，
欢愉与我们同在！
衣裳补丁无数，
转眼白发苍苍！
贫穷之人们，是绝望，
将我们引航，
我们又能奈何？
这条道路永远严苛，
听天由命，等待千载一合。 帽子也是残破，
再无其他选择。
我们昔日将悲哀撒播，
今日就要自食苦果！
割下一捆捆的哀伤，
以及心灵的凄凉。
在波希米亚，
除了去酒馆消愁，
可去的又有何处？

And at the alehouse then,
They give us nought to drink,
Oh, what misery to sup
From a dry and empty cup!
Pawn accursed,
with empty purse.
What can you endeavour?
Seek relief from labour,
And pray for God's favour. On Friday here's our fare:
Soup from water prepared,
Stew of grass and wood;
An end to this bad food!
Fish will there be,
From Danube or sea?
Of that there's little fear,
For even eels are dear,
And loach are far from here. On Saturday we'll sup,
From grief's bitter cup.
And on Sunday morning,
Empty bellies groaning.
At table together,
One poor as another,
We'll sit and take our share
Of nothing else but air
And let that be our fare.

而在那酒馆之中，
他们不予我们酒喝，
哦，我们只剩啜饮忧伤，
独自面对那杯中空荡！
诅咒那小铺，
让它分文不入。
你们又能奈何？
用劳动换解脱，
祈求上帝的眷顾。 星期五，我们这样过活：
河水煮的汤已经齐活，
青草和树皮炖了满锅；
这悲惨的伙食，是时候终止！
鱼会有的，
是来自多瑙还是海里？
这倒不用担心，
鳗鱼便已是精品，
泥鳅更是足够令人欢欣。 星期六，我们会痛饮，
将悲伤的苦水一饮而尽。
星期天早上，
空腹发出阵阵悲鸣。
我们团团围坐，
一个比一个穷酸，
我们坐下来，议论分成，
无物可分，只剩西风。
这便是我们的人生。

<paragraph>The Massagetae, who were not accustomed to the effects of alcohol, became drunk within moments and were unable to defend themselves against the surprise attack of the Persians. Most of them were slaughtered, with the exception of Spargapis, their commander and the son of Queen Tomyris. He, however, rather than suffer the ignominy of defeat and captivity, ended his life by his own hand.</paragraph>
<paragraph>酒量不佳的马萨格泰人在饮用了营地内的葡萄酒后很快就失去了神智，也因此没能抵御住波斯人发起的奇袭。大多数马萨格泰人在这场战斗中丧生，而他们的指挥官，即托米丽司女王之子斯帕尔迦披西斯，却得以生还。但尽管如此，他并未接受被击败且沦为阶下囚的命运，而是亲手结束了自己的性命。</paragraph>

<paragraph><inc>T</inc>omyris was the queen of the Massagetae, a nomadic people who once inhabited the lands of present-day Persia. Although the Massagetae were predominantly pastoralists, there is no question of their being peaceful. They were fearsome archers mounted on their horses, and their infantry wielded axes and spears. They sacrificed horses to their sun god, and the writings of ancient historians show that they were not averse to eating human flesh.</paragraph>
<paragraph><inc>托</inc>米丽司曾是马萨格泰的女王，这一游牧民族早前栖居在当今的波斯领土上。尽管马萨格泰人大都是游牧民族，但他们崇尚和平的品性毋庸置疑。马背之上，他们是令人生畏的射手，斧枪在手，他们是叱咤沙场的勇士。他们会将身下的马匹献给太阳神，而且据史料记载，对于食用人肉之事，他们毫不忌讳。</paragraph>

<paragraph>When the queen learned from the messenger of the stratagem by which the Persians had succeeded in depriving her of her son, she replied to Cyrus II with the promise, "I will give you so much blood to drink that you will not be able to swallow it." She then placed herself at the head of her army and in the ensuing battle slaughtered most of the Persian army. Cyrus II himself fell that day. The story goes that Tomyris sought out his body after the battle, cut off his head, and with the words "Drink plenty!" threw it into a wineskin filled with blood. </paragraph>
<paragraph>当王后从信使那里得知自己的骨肉因中计而死于波斯人之手时，她便向居鲁士二世狠下毒誓：“血债我定要让你以饮无尽的血来偿，你会无法吞咽，生不如死。”随后她带领自己的军队出征，在后续的战斗中几乎将波斯人斩尽杀绝，居鲁士二世也正是在那一天魂飞魄散。战斗之后，托米丽司找出了居鲁士二世的尸体，割下他的头颅，一边咒骂着“喝个够吧！”，一边将断头扔进了血海之中。</paragraph>

<paragraph>The Massagetae waged war against the newly formed Persian Empire, which was united under the rule of Cyrus II the Great. However, the first forays against the Persian armies ended in failure, and the Persians did not even consider the small nomadic nation, led by a woman, as an equal opponent. On the next occasion, Cyrus managed not only to defeat, but also to disgrace Tomyris, thanks to the ruse of leaving behind a well-stocked camp full of food, and especially wine.</paragraph>
<paragraph>刚刚在居鲁士二世大帝统一治理下而建立的波斯帝国，就遭遇了马萨格泰人挑起的战争。然而，马萨格泰人针对波斯人发起的首次突袭却以失败告终，波斯人压根就没把这一小小的游牧民族放在眼里，这个由女性领导的族群根本就不是他们的对手。在随后的一场战役中，居鲁士大帝凭借一场计谋，击败了托米丽司，并留下一处堆满食物与葡萄酒的营地，更是让她倍受屈辱。</paragraph>
On Tomyris, the brave Queen of the Massagetae
托米丽司，英勇的马萨格泰女王的故事

The Sedletz monastery was built at the request of the bishop of Olomouc - Henry Zdiek. When he was staying in the place where now the monastery stands, he was visited by an angel and this task was granted to him. The monastery is named Sedletz after the saddle (sedle) on which the bishop laid his head that night.
塞德莱茨修道院是应奥洛穆茨主教金德日·兹迪克的请求而建造的。传说当他停留在此地时，一位天使造访了他，并赋予了他这项任务。由于当晚主教枕着马鞍入眠，故修道院命名为“塞德莱茨”（捷克语“鞍”的变体）。

<paragraph>For this willing and conscientious assistance, the Towns of Prague shall have all their existing rights and privileges confirmed, and shall be exempted from the tribute to the King for a period of five years. The Prague Militia shall also be paid a tribute while the King keeps them in the field. This agreement shall be submitted to King Sigismund of Luxembourg, so that he may issue a charter and duly confirm all these agreements in perpetuity. Amen, in the name of Jesus Christ.</paragraph>
<paragraph>基于此份自发且尽责之援助，在此认可布拉格各城市现有之权益及特权，并免除其未来五年内应向国王缴纳的赋税。同时，只要国王还需其驻守战场，将与布拉格军队以适当之军饷。此协议将提交西格斯蒙德国王处，以供其颁布宪章，并正式确认此等协议永久有效。以耶稣基督之名，阿门。</paragraph>

<paragraph><inc>A</inc>nd in memory eternal and beyond all doubt, we establish this charter to preserve the agreements between the most noble Sir Otto von Bergow, the brave Knight Markvart von Aulitz and the councillors of the City of Prague. They have agreed that the Prague Militia shall support King Sigismund of Luxembourg militarily in the territory of Bohemia, and that the above-named Sir Markvart von Aulitz shall command them.</paragraph><newpage/>
<paragraph><inc>为</inc>永久保存高贵的奥托·冯·波尔高领主、勇敢的马科瓦尔·冯·奥利茨骑士，以及布拉格市议会之间的协议，特此确立该宪章，且将其镌刻于永恒的记忆之中，不容置疑。上述三方意见已达成一致，布拉格各城市的军队将在波希米亚领土上支援匈牙利和克罗地亚国王西格斯蒙德，并交由马科瓦尔·冯·奥利茨爵士指挥。</paragraph><newpage/>
A letter sent by the Praguers to King Sigismund containing their agreement.
布拉格人写给西格斯蒙德国王的一封信，信中包含了他们的协议。
西格斯蒙德国王遗失的特许状

<paragraph>Feathered Friend,</paragraph> <paragraph>The folk who live in the Boot are restless. Time is short and the Fox is gathering strength. The house of pepper must burn! Tonight is the last chance. The Old Cat, the Gambler and the Groom are expendable - prepare for the worst. None is more silent than he whose lips have tasted the Kiss.</paragraph> <paragraph>Await the next message the day after tomorrow in the same place as always.</paragraph> <paragraph>Friends of the Lad from the Boot.</paragraph>

<paragraph>“羽饰之友”，</paragraph> <paragraph>“靴中人”坐立不安，“狐狸”在积蓄力量，我们的时间不多了。必须让“胡椒屋”燃烧起来！今晚是最后的机会，如果事态严重，“老者”、“赌徒”和“马夫”都可以牺牲掉。尝过“吻”的人都陷入了沉默。</paragraph> <paragraph>后天到老地方等待下一条消息。</paragraph> <paragraph>来自“靴中人”的朋友</paragraph>

Many shooters have found it very advantageous not to aim just anywhere, but at exactly what they want to hit.
许多射手发现，只瞄准你的目标而不去瞄其它地方是非常行之有效的。
Remember that the rate of fire must be higher than the rate of reduction of the distance between you and your opponent. And why is that? Well, otherwise this equation will result in your death.
请记住，射击速度必须比对方接近的速度快。要问为什么？这个嘛，不然你就死翘翘了。

Each situation calls for a different type of arrow or dart. Broadheads are excellent for game or ordinary peasants, while narrow and needle-like arrows are capable of piercing armour. And incendiary arrows? They're completely useless!
应对各种情况需要不同的弹药，宽头箭适合狩猎，或是农民用于保护田地，而细长头和尖头箭则用来穿甲。至于燃烧箭？那个完全没用！

Materials must be sifted through a sieve or a linen bag. Melt a pound of sulphur in a crucible, and stir in two pounds of properly grounded saltpetre and a quarter of a pound of charcoal. Soak the sulphur wick in the molten mass and let it cool and harden. If the powder should spoil, add a drop of sublimate of mercury, camphor and arsenic during the brewing.
制作火药的材料必须先用筛子或者亚麻袋筛掉杂质。之后，在坩埚中熔化一磅硫磺，加入两磅适当研磨的硝石和四分之一磅煤炭，搅拌均匀。将硫磺灯芯浸泡在熔化的硫磺中，让其冷却硬化。如果粉末变质了，就在过程中加入一滴水银升华物以及适量樟脑和砷。
If you want to create powder that stays dry on the ground but catches fire in the rain, read on. It's enough.
如果你想制作一种保持干燥时不可燃，但会在雨中燃烧的火药，请继续阅读。按照以下步骤操作：

If you don't want to scrape the saltpetre out of the sties or search in the pits, do this. Make a pipe out of clay with some small holes in it. Take a pound of tartaric acid, half a pound of salt, three times as much lime and the urine of a wine-drinker. Make a mash from the materials and spread it inside the pipe. Leave it in the sun for three days and empty it on the fourth day. Then hang the pipe in the cellar and wait for the nitre to grow. Then boil the saltpetre in water, wine or better vinegar as you would a fish and strain it through a thick cloth. Let the crystals dry properly.
在收集硝石时，如果你不想去刮谷仓的墙或四处寻找硝石坑，可以尝试以下方法。用陶土做一个管子，在上面打些小孔。取一磅酒石、半磅盐、三倍量的石灰和一个喜欢喝酒的人的尿液，将这些材料混合成糊状，涂在管子内部。将其放在阳光下晒三天，第四天倒空。然后将管子挂在地窖中，等待硝石析出。接下来，将生成的混合物像煮鱼一样用水或酒，最好是醋煮沸，并用厚布过滤。最后，让晶体充分干燥，就能制取出硝石了。

<paragraph>Among the qualities of a true master of fire are: The warrior's godliness, for when he handles powder, he has his arch-enemy in his hands. He also maintains humility towards the world he walks day and night. He should, as a master, be able to read and write, otherwise the knowledge written in this book cannot be retained in the mind, whether it be distillation, separation or sublimation. Only a man of prudence, honesty, kindness in word and deed will become a master. In particular, he must avoid drunkenness at any hour.</paragraph><newpage/>
<paragraph>真正的火药大师应该具备两种品质，其一是战士的神圣，当他处理火药时，应对此应用自如，得心应手；其二是对世间万物的谦卑，他应掌握读写，否则书中蕴藏的知识——无论是蒸馏，分离，还是升华——都无法铭记在心。只有谨慎，诚恳，仁慈，尤其是不会酗酒的人，才能成为真正的大师。</paragraph><newpage/>

White vitriol - 1 Lot 4 Sch Gr

I, the renowned Hermes Trismegistos, offer through my agents for exchange:
我，闻名于世的赫耳墨斯·特里斯墨吉斯忒斯，通过我的神谕者提出交换条件：

<paragraph>Although I have to admit, she's got it in for me. In the middle of my lecture on the dangers of nightshade extract, I found myself staring at her plump cleavage. Let's just say I let the rest of her transgressions go unnoticed. But I'll be locking the chest carefully from now on, as well as the chest with raw materials I keep right next to my apparatus.</paragraph><newpage/>
<paragraph>她还是很不满，但我得说，在和她讲龙葵提取物有多危险的时候，我发现我一直盯着她那对大胸看。这样吧，她其他的过失我就不追究了。不过从现在开始我得好好锁好所有的箱子，仪器旁边的原料箱也不例外。</paragraph><newpage/>

<paragraph>I didn't tell him that, of course. So I gave him some talk about the domes of Mars and the phases of the moon, so that it was clear that without a scholar of my capacity he would not prepare any miraculous concoction. I wonder when he'll come again.</paragraph>
<paragraph>当然，我是不会告诉他的，我讲了一些关于火星和月相的事情糊弄过去了。我得让他知道，只有我这种睿智的学者才能配制出这种奇迹的药方。不知道他什么时候再来找我。</paragraph>

<paragraph>Erazim the scribe was with me again. The fever had apparently subsided, but he demanded my tonic again. He said the fever keeps coming back at night, which is not unusual, but my tonicum should not be given lightly. I therefore gave him another dose, but warned him that it was the last. He made a rather strange face and then proceeded to question me rather clumsily about the composition of the tonic.</paragraph>
<paragraph>抄写员埃拉兹姆又来找我了。显然他发烧的迹象已经减退，但他要求更多的煎剂。他说他的发烧在晚上经常复发，这其实是个正常现象，但我的补药不能随便乱开。于是我还是给了他一剂，但警告他这是最后一剂。他的表情很奇怪，然后笨拙地询问我煎剂的成分。</paragraph>
<heading>April 23 - Bishop St. Adalbert / Adalberti episcopi et martyrum </heading>

<paragraph> Fortunately, the feverfew grows right in the forecourt, on the terrace on the path to the lower gate. I'm not a herbalist, so I had a bit of trouble finding it, as it looks almost identical to chamomile. As for the elderberry leaves, I visited the carpenter above the upper gate. I know well that they dye their cloth in secret right behind the workshop and then sell it around the village, so they have an abundance of elderberry leaves.</paragraph><newpage/>
<paragraph>幸运的是，前院通往下门的小路上就长有小白菊，露台上就有很多。因为它们看起来和甘菊几乎一模一样，我又不是专业的草药学家，分辨起来费了点力气。至于接⻣⽊莓叶，附近的木匠那里就有。我知道他在作坊后面偷偷给布料染色，然后卖到村子里，所以他藏了很多接⻣⽊莓叶。</paragraph><newpage/>

<paragraph>The scribe Erazim lay down with a fever, which probably came from an inflamed wound on his right hand. I have thus an occasion to try my new decoction against the fevers which accompany inflammations of various kinds. It's a simple decoction made from ingredients that are quite readily available. The decoction is prepared from boiled wine, three parts of feverfew, two parts of grated ginger and one part of elderberry leaves.</paragraph>
<paragraph>抄写员埃拉兹姆高烧不起，应该是他右手的伤口发炎的缘故，因此我有机会尝试我的新煎药了。这种药可以治疗各种炎症引发的发热，它的优点是材料易于获得，做起来也容易。用煮沸的葡萄酒、三份小白菊、两份磨碎的姜和一份接⻣⽊莓叶就可以制成。</paragraph>
<heading>April 30 - Octave of St. Adalbert / Octava sancti Adalberti </heading>
<heading>4月30日-圣阿达尔贝特八日庆典</heading>

<paragraph>I caught the maid, Katherine, rummaging through my things in my storeroom across from the lab. As I have a constant supply of decoctions, tinctures and medicines in my chest, the unprofessional use of which can be dangerous, she may be glad I only scolded her.</paragraph>
<paragraph>女仆凯瑟琳在实验室对面的储藏室里翻我的东西，被我逮到了。我在箱子里存了很多煎剂、酊剂和药物，业余人士随意使用会带来风险。她只是挨了一顿骂，已经是最好的结果了。</paragraph>

<paragraph>I got the ginger in the castle kitchen, although it was a struggle because the chest with the precious spices is locked and has had a broken lock on it for years. But the cooks were unusually kind and gave me a good measure. The rest I kept well in storage, as the last of my supply had mysteriously disappeared.</paragraph>
<paragraph>我费了不少力气才在城堡的厨房里找到姜，因为装珍贵香料的箱子锁坏了，我打不开。但厨师们异常友善，给了我一大份。我的上一份库存不知怎的就消失了，因此剩下的我都妥善保存了起来。</paragraph>

<paragraph>Mr. Chamberlain Ulrich was here again, but this time he did not come to quarrel with me, but on the contrary came running with a plea. His stomach is bothering him. After a short examination I immediately knew that he was suffering from a stomach ulcer, but I had not forgotten the unprecedented humiliation he had caused me, so instead of a professional diagnosis, I muttered something about Galen and the body fluids, threw up my hands helplessly and escorted him out. Since he thinks I'm a dim-witted ignoramus, he probably expected nothing better from me and settled for my little lie.</paragraph> <newpage/>

<paragraph>管家乌尔里希先生又来了。但这次他不是来和我吵架，而是来求助的，因为他的胃很不舒服。我简单检查后，立刻就知道他得了胃溃疡。但我并未忘记此前他给我带来的前所未有的羞辱，因此我没有给出专业的诊断，而是跟他含糊其辞了一些盖伦学说之类的东西，把他打发了出去。这家伙一点悔改的意思都没有，依然高高在上地觉得我什么都不懂，所以接受了我的谎话。或许他一开始就没想在我这得到什么答案。</paragraph><newpage/>

<paragraph>Chamberlain Ulrich was here again, this time quite unpleasant and threatening. He said that if I couldn't deal with his problem, I have nothing to do at Trosky. I told him that his problem was quite rare (which obviously flattered him) and that I could only treat common ailments. His problem would need a real physician. And since I flattered him and made a fool of myself, he was satisfied with my explanation.</paragraph><paragraph> But he demanded that I recommend someone. I sent him to Kolin to see Professor Joachim Bavorsky, who is known to be a rather eccentric astrologer. The meeting of these two figures will certainly be amusing, I almost wish I could see it. </paragraph><paragraph>I cannot prolong the sufferings of this pompous snob indefinitely, however, as it might turn against me. Next time I'll make him my digestive potion. Two handfuls of thistle, some nettle leaves and a little charcoal, which in small quantities is known to aid digestion, will do the trick.</paragraph><newpage/>

<paragraph>管家乌尔里希又来了，他这次的来访充满火药味。他威胁我说，如果不能解决他的问题，我在特罗斯基就再无立足之地了。我告诉他，他的病非常罕见（这么说显然让他很受用），而我只负责治疗常见病。他的病需要一个真正的医生来处理。他本来也啥都不懂，根本看不出我在装傻，再加上我奉承了他，让他感觉很满意。</paragraph><paragraph>他要求我推荐一位医生，我推荐他去科林见约阿希姆·巴沃斯基教授。众所周知，巴沃斯基教授是一位相当古怪的占星家，他俩碰上肯定会很有趣，我都想亲自去看看了。</paragraph><paragraph>不过，我不能让这个自大的混蛋一直痛苦下去，时间久了他或许要找我麻烦。下次我会给他开消化药剂的方子。两把蓟草、一点荨麻叶和一些木炭（大家都知道，少量的这东西有助于消化）应该就可以了。</paragraph><newpage/>
<title>Book of Notes</title><newpage/><heading>March 4 - Transfer of St. Wenceslas / Translatio sancti Wenceslai</heading>
<title>笔记</title><newpage/><heading>3月4日-圣瓦茨拉夫转移日</heading>
<heading>May 2 - Sigismund the Martyr / Sigismundi Regis et Martyris </heading>
<heading>April 14 - Feast of Saints Valerianus and Tiburcius / Tyburcii et Valeriani martyrum </heading>
<heading>4月14日-圣瓦莱里安和提布尔丘斯节庆</heading>

<paragraph>Let the Italian Court sink into the ground, the City Council choke on the monastery wine, the secret enterprise be revealed, and you and your brother hang from the same beam. </paragraph><paragraph>P.S. Fuck you, fuck the key, fuck everything!
<paragraph>那就让意大利宫沉入地下吧，让市议会那帮人被葡萄酒呛死，让那家秘密企业被彻底揭露，让你和你的兄弟吊死在同一根横梁上。</paragraph><paragraph>附：去你妈的，去你妈的钥匙，去他妈的一切！

<paragraph>If you're reading these lines, know that I'm long out of town. I know you, you sycophant, have had your eye on my position for a long time. It's yours, you lined rat! I wish it to you with all my heart! And I'm almost sorry I won't see your face when you find out where I left you the key! </paragraph><paragraph>The only thing left is to wish you to enjoy your new title with honour, it won't last long anyway. </paragraph>
<paragraph>当你读到这些内容的时候，我已经离开城镇很久了。我都知道的，你这哈巴狗，觊觎我的职位很长一段时间了吧。现在这职位是你的了，你这卑鄙小人！我全心全意地祝福你！不过实在可惜，等你发现我把钥匙放在何处的时候，我没机会看到你脸上的表情了！</paragraph><paragraph>最后，祝你享受新职位所带来的名誉，反正它也不长久了。</paragraph>
<heading>To the hands of Sir Christian of Pisek, the Mint Master of the Royal Mint at the Italian Court.</heading>
<heading>请交给意大利宫的皇家铸币官，皮塞克的克里斯蒂安先生。</heading>

Since the time of Alexander the Great, the bow has been an obsolete weapon, unworthy of a thinking man. But this dumb, back-bending instrument of the limited can easily be improved by substituting the human arm with a wooden one!
自亚历山大大帝的时代以来，弓就已经过时了，有脑子的人都不会考虑这种费上好大力气才能使用的愚蠢武器。但如果用木柄代替人类手臂发力，那可就不一样了！

Ever since the times of Adam, the bow has been the accurate, swift, silent and deadly weapon of choice for true men. Only a coward with arms as weak as a babe would resort to another weapon – slower and dishonourable.
自从亚当时代以来，弓箭一直是真正男子汉的武器，它准确、迅速、杀人于无形。只有那些如婴儿般无力的懦夫才会选择其他更慢，且十分不光彩的武器。

From two magical peaks, that gaze into the heavens,
Like a thirsty pilgrim I set out upon the path.
Across a valley overgrown to the very edge of the earth,
There I shall drink from a spring that will not let me perish.

双子山巅眺天路，
朝圣之人踏征途。
横跨峡谷尽边陲，
酌饮甘泉获永生。
Will it lead me to the Holy Grail?
它能指引我找到圣杯吗？
Just as man is dust and unto dust he shall return, so the most beautiful rose is but the manure from which it once sprang.
正如人生于尘土，亦归于尘土。最美丽的玫瑰也终将化为春泥。
The fundamental question of just about every philosophical movement is the question "why?" Why the hell waste time blathering?!
几乎每次哲学运动都基于探讨“为什么”。但为什么要浪费时间在这件事上？
This is my stuff! Where the hell am I supposed to hide it so you'll finally leave it alone? If I find out someone's taken anything from me again, I'll kick their arse!
这是我的东西！我到底该藏在哪里你们才肯罢休？告诉你们，要是我再抓到有谁偷东西，他保证吃不了兜着走！

<paragraph><inc>O</inc>f the year of our Lord 1382, we make it known to all before God that Brother Ambrose of Prague has fulfilled his vows of order and mastery, and has attained considerable renown and skill in his work, as well as having attained due wisdom in his age. We hereby place in the hands of Brother Ambrose of Prague all the duties and dignity of the office of Seneschal of the Order and swear allegiance to him before God. Our Brother is further dispensed from the hospital service and is charged with the care of appointing honest correctors of the courts and confirming suitable preceptors of castles, hospitals and other residences of the Order.</paragraph><paragraph>For his own use and that of his office, apart from the ordinary customs, our elder Brother Ambrose is given two good riding horses and one each for his knight and chaplain. He is also to have the service of one archer and two squires in armour, as well as two servants under saddle.</paragraph>

<paragraph><inc>在</inc>我主耶稣的1382年，我们在上帝面前向众人宣告，布拉格的安布洛斯修士已经履行了他的骑士团誓约和职责。他在工作中展现了卓越的技艺和与其年岁相符的智慧，并因此赢得了广泛的赞誉。我们在此将骑士团总管的全部职责和荣誉交于安布洛斯修士，并在上帝面前向他宣誓效忠。安布洛斯修士从此免除医院服务的义务，并负责任命正直的法庭监察员与合适的城堡、医院及其他骑士团设施的领导人。</paragraph><paragraph>为安布洛斯修士及其职务所需，除常规供给外，将为他配备两匹上等马匹，以及为他的骑士和牧师各配备一匹。此外，他还将得到一名弓箭手，两名着甲侍从，以及两名鞍下仆人的辅助。</paragraph>

<paragraph><inc>N</inc>os hic sumus, omnibus bonis in Christo fratribus, collegium duodecim Ordinis militaris Crucigerorum cum rubea stella,</paragraph><paragraph>diligenti consideratione unanimiter et indubitanter consensimus, maiorem fratrem nostrum Ambros Pragae ex ex domus hospitalis sancti Francisci vocatus est magister senescali itaque vicarius magistri magni Ordinis nostri ad praestituto a Deo tempore.</paragraph><newpage/>

<paragraph><inc>N</inc>os hic sumus, omnibus bonis in Christo fratribus, collegium duodecim Ordinis militaris Crucigerorum cum rubea stella,</paragraph><paragraph>diligenti consideratione unanimiter et indubitanter consensimus, maiorem fratrem nostrum Ambros Pragae ex ex domus hospitalis sancti Francisci vocatus est magister sénéchali itaque vicarius magistri magni Ordinis nostri ad praestituto a Deo tempore.</paragraph><newpage/>

<paragraph>I buried my friend Ambrose on the edge of the meadow above his hut. I piled stones by two gnarled birches and then marked the grave with a broken sword. Let whoever passes by take it, it doesn't matter anymore.</paragraph>
<paragraph>我将好友安布洛斯葬在了他小屋上方的草地边。在两棵体态歪曲的桦树旁，我堆石为墓，以断剑立碑，至于哪位路过之人会将其取走，就任由天意吧。</paragraph>

<heading> Quintilis 1403</heading><paragraph> My God, how could you let this happen? Why did Satan come among us? Why can't brother trust brother? The Inquisition has Grandmaster Zdenyek in its grasp! When he found out what I knew, he wanted to kill me... God forgive me, I killed my brothers!</paragraph><paragraph>...The only one who can stop Zdenyek is my old friend Ambrose. He's been living in seclusion for a long time, but he still has the rank of seneschal. Only he can convict Zdenyek and save our order.</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>1403年，5月</heading><paragraph>我主，您怎能容许这种事发生？为什么撒旦就混迹在凡人之中？为什么修士之间毫无信任？宗教法庭控制住了兹登耶克大师！知道我查明真相后，他居然想除掉我……愿主宽恕，我杀死了我的同伴们！</paragraph><paragraph>现在唯一能阻止兹登耶克的人只有我的故友安布洛斯。他归隐山林已久，但仍留有执事的军衔，只有他能审判兹登耶克，拯救我们的骑士团。</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>Februarius 1403</heading><paragraph>Omnia mentiunt, but now I know for certain that Mark was hiding from the Inquisition in Maria Kulm! I searched for relatives and found that, coincidentally, Waldemar's nephew Kolda was released from the bishop's prison a month later. Someone had put in a good word for him.</paragraph><paragraph>... Why was Mark hiding? Is Kold's release somehow connected to his murder?</paragraph><paragraph>I must go to Litoměřice!</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>1403年，2月</heading><paragraph>Omnia mentiunt（一切都是谎言），但现在可以肯定的是，马克过去一直都在躲避玛丽亚库尔姆的宗教法庭！我四处寻找他的亲人，无意间了解到，在后来的一个月，沃尔德马的侄子科尔达摆脱了主教的监禁，定是有人为他求了情。</paragraph><paragraph>……马克为什么要藏起来呢？科尔达的释放跟那起凶杀案有关联吗？</paragraph><paragraph>我必须去一趟利托梅日采！</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>Decembris 1402</heading><paragraph>Younger Brother Mark was an able monastic apothecary in our Prague Commandery, but in the spring he is said to have become involved with the Inquisition. Other brothers later helped him escape from the city to the countryside</paragraph><paragraph>.... Qui bono? Why did the Inquisition go after Mark? ... what did the priest Waldemar have to do with it?</paragraph><paragraph>I must question their relatives!</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>1402年，12月</heading><paragraph>小修士马克曾是我们布拉格骑士团指挥部里一名能干的草药师，但据说他在春天时陷入了与宗教法庭之间的麻烦中。后来他在其他修士的帮助下从城里逃到了乡下。</paragraph><paragraph>.... Qui bono（是什么人能从中获利）？宗教法庭与马克到底有何过节？沃尔德马又与此事有何干系？</paragraph><paragraph>我必须向他们的亲人问清楚！</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>Aprilis 1403</heading><paragraph>Brother Mark was involved in a heinous murder! Last spring, the Inquisition forced him to poison the archbishop of Prague, Olbram! Afterwards, they wanted to get rid of Mark, but he disappeared in time. Little did he know that the old priest Waldemar would turn him in for the life of his nephew Kolda. The Inquisition eventually got rid of both brothers and made it look like a devilish rampage.</paragraph><paragraph>... Who all is involved? The intrigue runs high! I have to tell my Grandmaster Zdenyek about everything!</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>1403年，4月</heading><paragraph>马克修士竟与一场十恶不赦的谋杀案有所关联！就在去年春天，他在宗教法庭的威逼之下毒害了布拉格的主教奥尔布拉姆！案发之后，宗教法庭还想要根除后患，好在马克及时逃走。老修士沃尔德马为了自己侄子科尔达的性命，亲手出卖了马克，马克却对此毫不知情。最后，宗教法庭除掉了两位修士，还将此事渲染成了邪魔伤人事件。</paragraph><paragraph>……与此事有所关联的都是何人？当下阴谋四溢！我必须将这一切都告诉兹登耶克大师！</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>Novembris 1402</heading><paragraph>On my way from Cheb to Prague, I was caught by a message from the provost of Konigsberg about the terrible murder of two brothers of the order. The murder happened two days ago in the nearby Maria Kulm Commandery. The two unfortunates were found flogged in the sacristy of the church. The elder priest Waldemar died in horror, tied to the rump of a black goat with Brother Mark's limb stuck deep in his mouth. Mark's fingers had been broken and his head smashed to a pulp. The superstitious villagers consider this to be the work of the devil, but this is a simple premeditated murder of our brothers!</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>1402年，11月</heading><paragraph>在从海布前往布拉格的途中，我从哥尼斯堡的修道院院长那里得知一项噩耗，内容是骑士团的两位修士两天前不幸遇害。据说这起凶杀案件就发生在玛丽亚库尔姆骑士团指挥部附近。两位惨死之人在教堂的圣器室里遭受了鞭打，老修士沃尔德马死状凄惨，他被与一只黑羊的臀腿绑到一起，嘴里还深深插着修士马克的残肢。马克的手指已然断裂，被弄得粉碎的头颅脑浆四溅。迷信的村民们都认为此事乃恶魔所为，但其实那就只是早有预谋的残害而已！</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>Februarius 1403</heading><paragraph>Brother Mark was in Litoměřice last April on his last visit to the archbishop's court. A month later archbishop Olbram died of unknown causes, his heart reportedly stopped.</paragraph><paragraph>... Is this related? Did the Inquisition pressure Mark to do their dirty work for them? In cauda venenum?</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>1403年，2月</heading><paragraph>去年四月，马克修士就在利托梅日采，进行着此生最后一次对主教的探访。一个月后，主教奥尔布拉姆猝然长逝，死因不明，但据说死于心脏骤停。</paragraph><paragraph>……此事会有关联吗？难道是宗教法庭在逼迫马克替他们行使肮脏之事？In cauda venenum（调查此事是否会带来风险）？</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>Quintilis 1403</heading><paragraph>Ambrose is dead. Mors ultima linea rerum. I arrived at night at the Troskowitz rocks and found my friend sick to death. He no longer perceived me, but awoke in the morning and suddenly spoke clearly. I gave him absolution, and a little while later he let his soul out</paragraph><paragraph>... God, you have already taken everything I had, at least grant me to fulfill his last wish. Give me the strength to find a way to save sinful souls. Ex nihilo nihil fit.</paragraph><paragraph>... please Lord show me the way!</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>1403年，5月</heading><paragraph>安布洛斯死了。Mors ultima linea rerum（人终有一死）。夜晚时分，抵达特罗斯科维茨山区后，我才发现好友已病入膏肓。他当时已不省人事，但却在清晨时醒觉，忽然口齿伶俐地说起话来。我对他进行了解罪仪式，片刻后，他便魂身分离。</paragraph><paragraph>……上帝啊，您已夺走我身边的一切，能否至少让我完成他的夙愿！请赐予我力量，让我找到拯救罪人灵魂的方法。Ex nihilo nihil fit（我毫无头绪，迷失方向）。</paragraph><paragraph>……上帝啊，请为我指条明路！</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>About the death of Blessed Agnes of Premyslid</heading><paragraph>After the severe winter in the year of the Lord 1282, under the administration of the fourth Grand Master, who was Otto of Saxony, died the venerable abbess, the Most Holy Agnes of the Premyslid family, called Bohemian, who founded the Order of the Knights of the Cross and contributed most to its flourishing. This woman, in her holy work, never married, although many princes aspired to her, and on the contrary she dedicated her life to God. Together with other noble maidens she founded the Convent of the Poor Virgins of St. Clare and became its first abbess. Here she cared for the poor and the sick and, as a daughter of the king, sought to right wrongs, always protecting the poor from the strong and powerful. Kyrie, eleison.</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>普热米斯尔的祝福之女阿格尼丝之死</paragraph><newpage/>在1282年的严冬过后，第四任大团长萨克森的奥托任职期间，可敬的女修道院院长，普热米斯尔家族最神圣的阿格尼丝去世了。她被称为波希米亚人，是十字骑士团的创始人，为骑士团的繁荣做出了巨大贡献。尽管曾经有许多贵族追求她，但这位从事神圣事业的女性却终身未嫁，将一生都献给了上帝。她与其它几位贵族千金一同创立了圣克莱尔清贫修女会，并成为该修道院的第一任院长。在修女会，她照顾贫民和病患，而作为国王的女儿，她一直致力于纠正不公，为保护穷人免遭富人和权贵压迫而奋斗一生。愿主垂怜！</heading><paragraph>

<heading>On the Fire of the Order's Commandery</heading><paragraph>The death of the blessed Emperor Charles IV in the year of the Lord 1378 ignited a spark of sinful hatred. Only a few hours after the death of the illustrious emperor, a red rooster engulfed the entire Order's commandery in the Old Town of Prague. The flames quickly consumed the entire church, the hospital and the Order's library containing thousands of precious manuscripts and holy relics. Many of the sick and the brothers who had thrown themselves into the fire for them were burned.</paragraph><paragraph>The terrible loss was all the greater because the land books and records also disappeared. It was very well contrived. For the new pope, Urban VI, did not look kindly on rich monasteries and rebellious orders, and gave his bishops free rein to intrigue. Much of the Order's property was soon lost under strange circumstances.</paragraph><paragraph>Old Grand Master Frederick died two years later and could no longer look on at the misdeeds of his brothers. His successor was elected Zdeněk, who, however, more than concerned with the reformation of things, was on the contrary more concerned with intrigue, and conspired with the Prague chapter against the archbishop, so that truth and unity came to a great detriment. God, what dark times have come for our order. We have fallen prey to the whore of Babylon and have been poisoned by the poison from her breast. For by courtesy small things grow, but by discord even the greatest things crumble to dust.</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>骑士团总部大火</heading><paragraph>1378年，伟大的皇帝查理四世去世后，再无人抑制罪恶与仇恨的火花。就在这位杰出的皇帝逝世几小时后，一场大火吞噬了布拉格旧城区的整个骑士团总部。整个教堂、教会医院和骑士团的图书馆迅速没入火海，数以千计的珍贵手稿和圣物被毁，大量病人和舍身救人的修士被烧死。</paragraph><paragraph>更为严重的是，地籍和账簿也在大火中烧毁，骑士团也因此损失了大部分财产。而这一切都是被精心策划的，其幕后黑手新任教皇乌尔班六世对富庶的修道院和叛逆的骑士团充满敌意，并放任他的主教们下此毒手。</paragraph><paragraph>两年后，大团长弗雷德里克去世，至此无法目睹弟兄们自相残杀的丑恶行径。他的继任者是兹德内克，但此人并未试图改善现状，而是热衷于阴谋和斗争，他与布拉格分会密谋反对大主教，因此，真理和团结受到了极大的损害。上帝啊，此刻正是至暗之时，我们皆成了巴比伦淫妇的猎物，被她的毒乳所毒害。我们曾上下一心，齐心协力创造出如此的辉煌，如今一切都要在恶魔的挑拨下化为灰烬。</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>About Judith's Bridge</heading><paragraph>Blessed Daniel, the thirteenth Bishop of Prague, had the intention of building a stone bridge where for centuries only deep fords and sandy paths led across the Vltava River. The bishop also won his king Vladislav II Premyslide and his wife Judith, when they were in Italy on a campaign against the Milanese in the summer of 1158 and took a great wealth there.</paragraph><newpage/>The bishop also enlisted excellent Italian craftsmen to build Prague's oldest bridge, so that it was said to have been built in just three years, so that it was possible to cross between the Old Town on the eastern bank to the sub-castle of the old Premyslid kings' seat on the west. Named Judith's Bridge after the noble patroness of the building, it became the oldest in the Bohemian Kingdom and the third stone bridge north of the Alps before the terrible flood in the year of the Lord 1342 destroyed it.</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>朱迪斯桥</heading><paragraph>几个世纪以来，人们只能通过泥沙小径来渡过伏尔塔瓦河，有时甚至需要直接涉水。因此，布拉格第十三任主教圣丹尼尔希望在河上建一座石桥。在1158年的夏天，主教和国王弗拉迪斯拉夫二世·普热米斯尔及其妻子朱迪斯一同在意大利对抗米兰人，并于那场战役获取了巨大的财富后，他的修桥计划得到了国王夫妇的支持。</paragraph><newpage/>主教还招募了优秀的意大利工匠来建造桥梁，于是据说这座桥只用了三年时间就建成了，人们此后便可以从东岸的旧城穿过河流，到达西岸的旧普热米斯尔王座下的城堡。这座桥以王后朱迪斯的名字命名，是波希米亚王国最古老的桥梁，也是阿尔卑斯山以北的第三座石桥。然而，后来这座桥毁于1342年的恐怖洪水之中。</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>About the founding of the Knights of the Cross</heading><paragraph>There have always been many foreign religious orders in the Kingdom of Bohemia, but none of them have ever come from our roots. The blessed daughter of Premysl, Agnes of Bohemia, seeing the misery and suffering of her subjects, who, plagued by sickness and wounds, had nowhere to turn, founded in the year 1233, at her female monastery, the humble hospital brotherhood of St. Francis.</paragraph><paragraph>By the grace of God, unity and devotion to helping their fellow men, the brothers soon achieved renown, so that after only two years the brotherhood moved to the church of St. Peter under the old town of Vyšehrad in Prague. Many clerics and priests now came with an interest in joining the Order, which was not even a real Order yet. In the year of the Lord 1237, through the intercession of the blessed Agnes of Bohemia, Pope Gregory IX himself took the Hospitallers under his protection, so that no foreign power could harm them and they would have to confess to him and to God alone. The Bull Omnipotens Deus established the brotherhood as the Knights of the Cross.</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>《十字骑士团的创立》</heading><paragraph>波希米亚王国一直有很多宗教团体，但皆来自外国，没有一个是起源于我们本土的。直到1233年，普热米斯尔受祝福的女儿，波希米亚的阿格尼丝，看到她的子民在疾病和创伤的折磨下无处可求，于是心生怜悯，在她的女子修道院建立了简陋的圣方济各医院兄弟会。</paragraph><paragraph>承蒙上帝恩典，加之成员的团结与奉献，兄弟会很快便赢得了声誉，在仅仅两年后，就搬到了布拉格的威瑟赫拉德旧城区的圣彼得教堂。此刻，尽管该组织在当时还并非真正意义上的骑士团，但许多牧师和其他神职人员都纷纷对此产生了兴趣。1237年，在波希米亚的祝福之女阿格尼丝的斡旋下，教皇格里高利九世亲自将医院兄弟会纳入保护，以确保外国势力不能伤害他们，而兄弟会成员从此只得向教皇和上帝忏悔。后来，在教宗诏书《全能的上帝》中，将医院兄弟会确立为十字骑士团。</paragraph><newpage/>

<paragraph><inc>T</inc>he history of the rise and fall of the noble and honourable order of the Knights of the Cross.</paragraph><paragraph>Thank God and Christ that He has been pleased to guide my hand and bless me in the unworthy thing which I have, perhaps, only presumed to do out of insolent pride. I give attention to work where others cannot, to record what is not to be forgotten. </paragraph><newpage/>Concordia res parva crescunt. Discordia res maxima dilabuntur.</paragraph><newpage/>

<paragraph><inc>荣</inc>耀而尊贵的十字军骑士团兴衰史。</paragraph><paragraph>感谢上帝和基督，他乐于指引我的手，在这项因我个人之傲慢而染指的伟业之上亦赐予我祝福。我将专注于他人无法完成的工作，记录不应被遗忘之事。</paragraph><paragraph>Concordia res parva crescunt. Discordia res maxima dilabuntur.</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>On the growth of the Order</heading><paragraph>The Crusader Order stood faithfully by the Premyslid family for many years, and for this it received many benefits. But when King Wenceslas III was assassinated in Olomouc in the year of the Lord 1306, the country was in a terrible state of lawlessness for five years. Then the Order of the Cross fortified their commandery, but not their hearts. Many pilgrims continued to find relief from illness within the walls of the hospitals. Finally, the turmoil was ended by the coronation of the new King John of Luxembourg.</paragraph><paragraph>The Order did well in his service, but it was his son, Emperor Charles IV, who brought the order to its true growth. Thanks to him, the order acquired a wealth of learned foreign books, holy relics and other mysteries. The Order's commanderies abounded from Cheb to Vratislava in Silesia, and many villages, mills, ponds and castles fell under the sovereign power of the Grand Master Frederick.</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>骑士团的发展</heading><paragraph>十字军骑士团多年来忠实地支持着普热米斯尔家族，并因此获得了许多利益。然而，在1306年，国王瓦茨拉夫三世在奥洛穆茨遭遇暗杀后，国家群龙无首，陷入了长达五年的无政府状态。这期间，十字骑士团加固了他们的据点，但并未牢固他们的心志。许多朝圣者继续在医院的庇护下寻求救治。而最终，这场动荡在新国王约翰·卢森堡加冕后得以平息。</paragraph><paragraph>骑士团在他的统治期间表现出色，但真正使骑士团发展壮大的是他的儿子查理四世皇帝。由于他的缘故，骑士团获得了大量外国学术书籍，圣物，以及其他神秘的珍宝，骑士团的影响力从海布延伸至西里西亚的布拉迪斯拉发。许多村庄、磨坊、池塘和城堡都听命于大团长弗雷德里克。</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>About the founding of the hospital in the Old Town of Prague</heading><paragraph>In the year of the Lord 1252, under the second Grand Master Conrad called Swabian, because he came from Swabia, the brothers moved to the foot of the Judith Bridge and founded a new large hospital there. In addition to caring for the wounded and sick, the Order was given the privilege by the gracious King Wenceslas I to collect customs duties on the bridge for its repairs.</paragraph><newpage/><paragraph>The new hospital with the Church of the Holy Spirit soon became the main seat of the Order, which flourished greatly in those blessed years thanks to the beneficence of the King and other Bohemian lords. They thought of their immortal souls by having other hospitals built in their towns for the greater glory of God.</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>布拉格旧城区医院的创立</heading><paragraph>1252年，在第二任大团长康拉德的领导下（他来自施瓦本，被称作“施瓦本人”），修士们迁移到了朱迪斯桥下，并在那里建立了一座新的大型医院。除了照顾伤病的日常工作外，仁慈的国王瓦茨拉夫一世还赐予了骑士团在桥上征收关税以支撑修缮桥梁所需的特权。</paragraph><newpage/><paragraph>很快，这座新的医院和医院中的教堂就成为了骑士团的主要驻地。在那段祝福的岁月里，波希米亚的贵族们为了追求灵魂的永生，在各自的城镇中修建了医院，以赞颂上帝的荣耀，而骑士团凭借国王与他们的慷慨得到了极大的发展。</paragraph><newpage/>

<paragraph>Brother Ambrose, I know something that should interest you. I know who started the fire at St. Francis' Almshouse and why. They want the Grand Master removed too! Meet me tonight at the appointed place. The Dominicans from the Inquisition suspect me, and the bishop won't help us anymore.</paragraph><paragraph>Don't trust anyone!</paragraph>
<paragraph>安布洛斯修士，我掌握了一些你很感兴趣的信息。我知道是谁在圣弗朗西斯医院纵火，也知道了原因，他们是想罢免大团长！今晚在老地方见面。宗教法庭的多明我会正对我穷追不舍，主教也不再会为我们提供援助。</paragraph><paragraph>不要相信任何人！</paragraph>

Find out where the fire started!This limping man from New Town brought pots of oil to the hospital. I have to find him!Provost Matthew suddenly fell ill. Was he collaborating?The body of Squire Jacob was never found. No skeleton was two fingers short!The brothers had a secret... Blackmail? Who was blackmailing? The two strange imperial relics were lost.Where do the clues lead... who betrayed?

The spider didn't come to a familiar place. Has he disappeared or is he dead?

调查火灾！那个从新城区来的跛脚男人带了几罐油到医院。我必须找到他！院长马修这几天突然称病。他是不是内应？没找到侍从雅各布的尸体，没有缺少两根手指的骸骨！修士们还有其它秘密……是勒索吗？是谁在勒索？两件奇怪的帝国圣物遗失了。这些线索……谁是叛徒？

“蜘蛛”没有回去，他也死了？还是失踪了？

Dear Mistress of the chambers. Persevere.
We shall soon escape the dungeon of those two women.
Cursed fate, however, has placed an obstacle in my way.
The heat of the Lightbringer's potion is working, and I can feel my insides being reborn.
But when the last remnants of old age left my body, something else was washed away with them.
My damned clumsiness. It has sent all of the Lightbringer's secrets into the void.
But fear not. I shall get them back.
May this be the first task on the road to your liberation.

尊敬的殿堂之主，请坚持下去。
我们很快就能逃离那两个女人设下的牢笼。
但命运在我的道路上设置了一个障碍。
光明使者药剂的能量在我体内激荡，我的内在正在重生。
但随着岁月的侵蚀离开我的身体，其它的东西也随之而来。
我太过笨拙，让它们把所有光明使者的秘密都送入了虚空之中。
不过，不要担心，我会找回它们的。
和我一起找到它吧，这就是通往你解放之路上的第一个任务。
The house is quiet, there is enough saltpetre and plenty of charcoal. Let's go and make powder!
房子很安静，还有足够的硝石和大量的木炭。是时候制作火药了！
He that seeketh me in the scriptorium, and cannot find me, let him know that I am writing for Sir Otto in the Knights' Hall.
让他来抄写室找我，如果我不在，就告诉他我正在骑士大厅为奥托爵士写作。

Gentle night, why linger on?
I yearn thus for my love so long,
Without her words to calm my breast,
Who shall set my soul to rest?

And now my heart in sorrow dwells,
From melancholic pining swells.
Since I, alas, was forced to part
From the mistress of my heart.

Ah Lord, let me not wait in vain,
I yearn to see my love again!
Oh gentle Sir, be of good cheer,
I shall not cling to another, dear.

温柔的夜，为何流连？
思念我的爱人已久，
没有她的话语抚慰胸膛，
灵魂何以安睡？

如今我的心于悲伤中囚居，
那里哀愁滴水成河。
因为我呀，被迫告别
我可爱的心上人。

啊，上帝，不要让我苦苦等待，
我渴望与爱人重逢！
哦，温柔的先生，请放心，
我不会依附于他者，我的挚爱。

To love and be forlorn
Is like night without a dawn.
To be close with nought to say,
Like winter frost in May.

To have lips and yet kiss not,
Is like leaving grain to rot,
To love without consumating
Is like unsown fields in the spring.

I shall love you then, my dear
As long as you lie with me here.
If you'll not give your all to me,
No longer shall I bide with thee.

爱与孤独
如同不见黎明的长夜。
如此接近，却无可言说，
仿佛五月的冻霜。

空有双唇，却无处亲吻，
如同将谷物荒废腐烂。
残缺的爱
似是春日尚未播种的田地。

我会好好爱你，亲爱的
只要你陪我一起入梦。
倘使你不愿向我敞开心扉，
我也不会再守望你。
<title>The Maidens' War</title><subtitle>and how it all began</subtitle><newpage/>
<title>Charles IV,</title><subtitle>King of Bohemia and the Holy Roman Emperor</subtitle><newpage/>
<title>《查理四世传》</title><subtitle>波希米亚之王暨神圣罗马帝国之皇帝</subtitle><newpage/>

Saint Wenceslas,
Ruler of Bohemia,
Our Prince,
Intercede for us with God,
The Holy Spirit.
Kyrie Eleison

Heavenly the beautiful kingdom,
Blessed is he who cometh there.
Life eternal,
Fire bright
Of the Holy Spirit.
Kyrie Eleison.

We ask you for your help;
Have mercy upon us,
Console the sad,
Drive away all evil,
Saint Wenceslas.
Kyrie Eleison.

圣瓦茨拉夫，
波希米亚之主，
我们的君王，
把我们的忏悔传达给上帝，
圣灵在上。
神佑世人

美丽的天国，
有福之人的乐土。
永生，
不灭
生灵在上。
愿主怜悯。

我们请求您的恩赐；
请求您的宽恕，
慰藉那受伤的心灵，
驱走一切恶魔，
圣瓦茨拉夫。
神佑世人。

<inc>S</inc>cabies and growths of the skin of all manner, the same as insects and all low, crawling creatures, have been the bane of mankind since time immemorial. For he who wishes to protect his body, he must sleep less amongst cattle, at least once a fortnight wash himself in water or visit a bath, and expose his clothes to the sun. For water and sun drive away all ailments of the skin, whilst sickness does flourish where there is the filth and stench of the human body. Keep distance from vagrants and beggars, for it is they who are the greatest bearers of illness and they can easily infect you.<newpage/>
<inc>疥</inc>疮和各种皮疹，与害虫鼠辈一样，自古以来便是人类之敌。倘若有人想保护自己的身体免受侵害，他需尽量避免与牛群同寝，至少每两周用水清洗一次身体，或者直接去澡堂。同时，要将衣服放在阳光下晾晒。之所以这样做，乃是因为清水与阳光取走皮肤上的病害，而病害专门在人体脏臭之处滋生。不要接近流浪者与乞丐，因为他们是病害的传播者，可以轻易地将皮肤病传染给你。<newpage/>

Breezes waft through princely woods,
A maiden hurries to the stream
To draw water in an iron-hooped pail.

To the girl a bouquet floats,
A fragrant bouquet of violets and roses.
And when she reaches for the bouquet,
She falls, alas, in the water cold.

“If I only knew, bouquet so fair,
Who sowed you in the fertile soil,
I'd give a golden ring to him.

If I only knew, bouquet so fair,
Who bound you with a silky stem,
I would give him the very pin from my hair.

If I only knew, bouquet so fair,
Who dropped you in the water cold,
I would give him the wreath from my head.

微风拂过肃穆的森林，
女孩赶去溪流，
用铁箍桶打水。

一束花向女孩漂来，
散着紫罗兰和玫瑰的芳香。
当她向那花束伸出手去，
她跌落进了，唉，那冰冷的水中。

“如果我知道，美丽的花束，
是谁将你用富饶的土壤栽培，
我会赠予他一只金戒指。

如果我知道，美丽的花束，
是谁将你用丝绸绑起，
我会赠予他我的发簪。

如果我知道，美丽的花束，
是谁将你放逐于这冰冷的水中，
我会赠予他我头上的花环。”
<title>关于圣威尔福斯</title><subtitle>（或 圣斯塔罗斯塔）</subtitle><newpage/>
Gunpowder used to fire lead shot that even the best plate armour can't stop at close range. For safety reasons, load only when sober.
用于发射铅弹的火药，即便是最坚硬的板甲也无法承受如此火药轰出的近距离射击。出于安全考虑，装填时务必保持清醒。
Gunpowder used to fire scrap iron and other small projectiles. Will pierce anything with ease at close range, but is ineffective at long range. For safety reasons, load only when sober.
用于发射铁屑等小型射弹的火药，可在短距离内随意击穿任意目标，但长距离难有杀伤力。出于安全考虑，装填时务必保持清醒。
A weak but long-lasting perfume. Slightly increases charisma for a longer period, but reduces charisma if used with another perfume.
此种香水气味清淡，但可长久留香。使用后可在较长时间内略微提升魅力值，若与其他香水混合使用将会降低魅力值。
A strong but short-lasting perfume. Substantially increases charisma for short periods, but reduces charisma if combined with another perfume.
此种香水香飘十里，却难长久留香，其可在短时间内大幅度提升魅力值，若与其他香水混合使用将会降低魅力值。
Increases riding and dog-handling skills. If good quality, animals will take less notice of you and dogs won't bark at you.
可提升骑术以及训犬能力，高品质药剂还可让你不会轻易被动物察觉，且可避免犬类对你吠叫。
Reduces the feeling of fullness after food and cures food poisoning. If good quality, cures any poisoning, as well as boosting your vitality.
可缓解饱腹感并治疗食物中毒，高品质药剂则能解除一切中毒效果，并让你感到活力四射。
Improves your archery skill and if good quality, reduces the loss of stamina while aiming.
提升射箭能力，高品质药剂还能降低瞄准时所需的耐力消耗。
Reduces health by 110, resulting in certain death. Decreases health faster if good quality. More suitable for poisoning cooking pots than applying to weapons.
减少110生命值，服用后必死无疑，高品质药剂还将会使生命值更快地降低。相比于涂抹在武器上，把它洒进别人的餐食里才是明智之选。
Improves speech and speeds up reading if good quality. Also increases the amount of experience gained if best quality.
提升口才能力，高品质药剂还可提高阅读速度，且当药剂品质最优时则提高经验获取量。
Sleep heals you faster and if good quality, Energy replenishes faster while sleeping.
睡眠可以更快地为你恢复伤势，如果睡眠状态良好，也会更快地恢复能量。
Increases agility and if good quality, reduces the amount of stamina used by sprinting.
可提升敏捷度，高品质药剂还可降低冲刺时所需的耐力消耗。
Increases Energy and if good quality, slows tiring.
恢复能量，高品质药剂还可减缓疲惫速度。
Fever and related complications can often end in death. This tonic reduces fever if given in time.
发烧及相关病症无疑会最终导致死亡，而及时服用此种药剂将可缓解发热症状。
Reduces drunkenness, or if good quality, restores complete sobriety and also helps with hangovers and alcoholism.
可用于醒酒，高品质药剂则可缓解宿醉与酒精中毒，并完全恢复清醒。
Henry's homemade moonshine. A strong drink that is sure to put you in a good mood.
亨利自家的私酿酒，虽口感浓烈，但定能让你神清气爽。
Gradually heals part of your health. Helps against hangover, or cures it immediately if good quality.
可缓慢恢复部分生命值，并可缓解宿醉效果，高品质药剂则可立即解除宿醉。
You will see better in the dark and your Energy will deplete slower or if good quality, not at all.
你于黑暗中的视觉将得到提升，且能量消耗速度降低，高品质药剂可以避免能量消耗。
Lessens the effects of wounds and reduces the amount by which maximum stamina decreases with health.
减轻伤口带来的负面影响，并减缓最大耐力随生命值降低而减少的速度。
Makes running impossible and reduces weapon skills. Decreases health as well if good quality. Suitable for applying to weapons rather than poisoning cooking pots.
可使人丧失奔跑能力，并削弱武器技能，高品质药剂还将减少目标生命值。相比于用作餐中毒药，将此药剂涂抹于武器上时，其效将更胜一筹。
If you want to put to rights the imprudent choices of your life, all it takes is 1 mouthful, and you can chose your perks anew. Beware, though, the procedure is irreversible and painful!
曾经那些草率的决定让你有所懊悔了吗？想重新分配技能点就喝上一口吧。但是注意啦，这个过程可不好受，而且将无法挽回！
Saves the game and if good quality, boosts strength, vitality and agility.
可用于保存游戏进度，且高品质药剂还能提升力量、活力和敏捷。
Reduces Energy to 0. Reduces Stamina regeneration if good quality. Suitable for applying to weapons and for poisoning cooking pots.
可将能量降至0，高品质药剂还将降低耐力的恢复速率。无论是用作餐中毒药还是涂抹武器都有奇效。
可提升偷窃和工艺技能。
Increases stamina and increases stamina regeneration if good quality.
可提升耐力值，高品质药剂还将提升耐力恢复速率。
Reduces loss of health and slows bleeding.
降低生命值损失，并减缓流血效果。
You can't wash your own clothes without soap.
<subtitle>The Gravedigger's Jest</subtitle> <paragraph>What do you call a woman who knows exactly where her husband is every night? A widow.</paragraph>
<subtitle>掘墓人笑话</subtitle> <paragraph>什么样的女人能知道丈夫每晚都在哪？答案是寡妇！</paragraph>

<subtitle>On Innocence</subtitle> <paragraph>A young man tenderly embraces his beloved and asks, 'Am I your first lover by any chance?' 'Could be,' she replies. 'I thought I'd seen you somewhere before.'</paragraph>
<subtitle>纯真</subtitle> <paragraph>一位年轻男子温柔地拥抱他的爱人，问道：“我是否是你的初恋？”女子回答说：“也许吧，我觉得我在哪里见过你。”</paragraph>

<subtitle>On the Wisdom of the Elders</subtitle> <paragraph>A father says to his son on his wedding day, 'Remember, son, that a newlywed woman loves well and cooks badly. But wait a few years and it will be just the opposite.'</paragraph>
<subtitle>过来人的智慧</subtitle> <paragraph>父亲在儿子的婚礼日对他说：“记住，儿子，新婚的女人爱意深沉，厨艺却很糟，几年之后，就会完全反过来了。”</paragraph>

<newpage/><subtitle>Thinking is Not Knowing</subtitle> <paragraph>A certain Kuttenberg gentleman once visited an old charlatan and wanted to know his fate. The charlatan examined his palm carefully and said to him, 'I see you are the father of two children...' 'You're mistaken,' he shook his head. 'I am the father of three children!' 'It is you who are mistaken!' smiled the charlatan. </paragraph>
<newpage/><subtitle>想象非真知</subtitle> <paragraph>从前，库滕堡有一位男子拜访了一位年长的占卜师，希望了解自身的命运。占卜师认真地观察了他的手掌后说道：“我看到你有两个孩子……”“那只是你的想象罢了，”男子摇了摇头说，“我有三个孩子！”“但那也只是你的想象……”占卜师微笑着回答。</paragraph>
A book of short stories secretly written in Lady Rosa's hand. The last part is our work together.
一本由罗莎小姐秘密撰写的短篇故事集。最后一部分内容是由我与她协力完成的。

About the clever priest One priest in Prague didn't like the fact that his parishioners didn't want to buy indulgences. The treasury in the church was empty, but even some really wealthy people were coming to confession, and the priest knew they had something to confess. So one day, as the people were gathering to leave after Mass, he announced, so that everyone could hear: 'Good people! Believe me, I am very reluctant to do this, but I must. Hear that there is a man among us who is having a sinful affair with his neighbor's wife. Remember the seventh commandment - thou shalt not commit adultery! - and listen to me well. If there are not at least one hundred and twenty groschen in the treasury by tomorrow evening, I will publicly proclaim who the sinner is among us.' The parishioners dispersed to their homes, whispering excitedly among themselves as to whom the priest could possibly be talking about. The latter only smiled under his beard, looking forward to seeing how he would succeed with his threat. When he opened the treasury the next evening, he found not one hundred and twenty, but the whole three hundred groschen, and a small folded note with the following message: 'Have mercy, father, and give me one more day. I'll get the other sixty somewhere!'

精明的牧师 布拉格的一位牧师对于他的教徒们不购买赎罪券一事很是不快。教堂的奉献箱总是空空如也，即便有一些家财万贯的富人们来此忏悔，而牧师很清楚他们心中确实有鬼，也无济于事。一天，结束了弥撒仪式的教徒们正要成群结队地离开，牧师扯大嗓门说道： “教徒们！请相信我，尽管这并非我所愿，但是我别无选择。听说我们之中的某个人染指了邻居的家妻，诸位可还记得‘第七戒律’的要求——‘不可奸淫’！所以现在请好好听我说，如果明晚之前，奉献箱内见不到至少一百二十枚格罗申，我将把这个罪人公之于众。” 教徒们随后便散开，各自回了家，喜闻乐见的他们路上还交头接耳了起来，都在猜测牧师所指何人。可谁知此刻的牧师，胡须之下泛起微笑，正期盼着他的这番恐吓所带来的成效。第二天夜晚，当他打开奉献箱时，发现里面躺着整整三百枚格罗申，还伴有一张折起的字条，上面写着： “请您宽恕，神父，再给我一天时间，我一定会把剩下六十枚格罗申凑齐！”

<subtitle>Wedding toast</subtitle> <paragraph>Unfortunately, I don't know the bride, so I can't congratulate her groom. And knowing the groom too well, neither can I congratulate the bride.</paragraph>
<subtitle>婚礼祝词</subtitle> <paragraph>遗憾的是，我不认识新娘，所以没法祝贺新郎。我对新郎了解甚多，所以也没法祝贺新娘。</paragraph>

<newpage/><heading>Repent, Adam's Gender</heading> <subtitle>A. von Wallenstein and Raimund R. Hardt on men and women</subtitle> <paragraph>As many, and men in particular, will gladly testify, of the two genders, it is the female that is imperfect, prone to all manner of sins and faults. It is an old known truth that the testimony of many is a credible testimony, the truth of which cannot be doubted. But who hath appointed the woman her lot? God? Or man? Who has decreed that woman is incapable of thinking, acting and deciding without the guidance of man?</paragraph> <paragraph>By whom was it determined that women were too foolish and vice-ridden to participate in matters wholly male - politics, science, or the liberal arts? Is such a resolution supported by experience or evidence? After all, no one has ever given a woman the opportunity to demonstrate the necessary judgement and wit. We have only conveniently condemned it as inadequate and have made this judgement an established truth which no one dares to question. </paragraph> <paragraph>We have witnessed many injuries to the daughters of Eve, and therefore may, or rather must, testify that the world is unjustly ordered in this respect. Men are fond of exalting themselves above women and attributing all sorts of wrongs to them, but only to cover their own faults!</paragraph> <paragraph>A man who accuses a woman of vice has squandered his own youth in licentiousness. In old age, these men recall with regret the sins of their past life without ever repenting of them. It is out of this bitterness that they denounce women, in order to humiliate and vilify them in the minds of all who are willing to listen to them. These corrupt old men are like incurable leprosy.</paragraph> <paragraph>But even more than women, men prefer to elevate themselves above other men. For example, they claim that husbands who listen to their wives' advice are fools and deserve ridicule. But we say that a man who has a wife who is sensible and wise, and refuses to listen to her, is twice as foolish!</paragraph>

<newpage/><heading>悔改吧，亚当之子</heading> <subtitle>瓦伦施泰因和雷蒙德关于男女的论述</subtitle> <paragraph>在讨论男性与女性的议题上，许多人，特别是男性，常常声称女性是不完美的，容易犯各种罪过和错误。一条古老且公认的真理是：多数人的证词就是可信的证词，其真实性不容置疑。但是谁为女性定下这样的命运？是上帝还是男性？又有谁规定女性不能在没有男性指导的情况下思考、行动和决策？</paragraph> <paragraph>又是谁将女性定义为愚昧和陋习缠身，认为她们无法参与所谓“纯粹男性的领域”——政治、科学或自由艺术？这样的决议是否有经验或证据作为支撑？说到底，从未有人给予女性机会来展示她们所需的判断力和智慧，人们只是自顾自地认定她们能力不足，并将这一判断奉为既定事实，无人敢于质疑。</paragraph> <paragraph>我们见证过太多对夏娃之女的诽谤与中伤，因此我们可以，或者说必须站出来，证明这个世界在性别平等方面的不公。男性常常将自己凌驾于女性之上，并将种种罪责归咎于她们，但这一切只是为了掩盖他们自己的缺点！</paragraph> <paragraph>那些指责女性有恶习的男性，往往在年轻时也沉溺于放纵的生活。这些男性到了晚年，虽然对自身过去的罪行感到后悔，却从未真心悔改。正是出于这种心态，他们谴责女性，以便在所有与他们一派的人心中羞辱和诋毁她们。而他们的这些言论，就如同麻风病般在社会上蔓延。</paragraph> <paragraph>但与对女性的贬低相比，男人欺压其他男人的行为更胜一筹。比如，他们会嘲笑那些听从妻子建议的丈夫，认为这是愚蠢的行为。但如果一个男人有通情达理且聪慧的妻子，却不愿听从她建议，那才是真正的愚蠢！</paragraph>

<newpage/><subtitle>Thinking is Not Knowing</subtitle> <paragraph>A certain Kuttenberg gentleman once visited an old charlatan and wanted to know his fate. The charlatan examined his palm carefully and said to him, 'I see you are the father of two children...' 'You're mistaken,' he shook his head. 'I am the father of three children!' 'It is you who are mistaken!' smiled the charlatan. </paragraph>
<newpage/><subtitle>想象非真知</subtitle> <paragraph>从前，库滕堡有一位男子拜访了一位年长的占卜师，希望了解自身的命运。占卜师认真地观察了他的手掌后说道：“我看到你有两个孩子……”“那只是你的想象罢了，”男子摇了摇头说，“我有三个孩子！”“但那也只是你的想象……”占卜师微笑着回答。</paragraph>
<subtitle>The Gravedigger's Jest</subtitle> <paragraph>What do you call a woman who knows exactly where her husband is every night? A widow.</paragraph>
<subtitle>掘墓人笑话</subtitle> <paragraph>什么样的女人能知道丈夫每晚都在哪？答案是寡妇！</paragraph>
A book of short stories secretly written in Lady Rosa's hand. The last part is our work together.
一本由罗莎小姐秘密撰写的短篇故事集。最后一部分内容是由我与她协力完成的。

<subtitle>On the Wisdom of the Elders</subtitle> <paragraph>A father says to his son on his wedding day, 'Remember, son, that a newlywed woman loves well and cooks badly. But wait a few years and it will be just the opposite.'</paragraph>
<subtitle>过来人的智慧</subtitle> <paragraph>父亲在儿子的婚礼日对他说：“记住，儿子，新婚的女人爱意深沉，厨艺却很糟，几年之后，就会完全反过来了。”</paragraph>

<subtitle>Wedding toast</subtitle> <paragraph>Unfortunately, I don't know the bride, so I can't congratulate her groom. And knowing the groom too well, neither can I congratulate the bride.</paragraph>
<subtitle>婚礼祝词</subtitle> <paragraph>遗憾的是，我不认识新娘，所以没法祝贺新郎。我对新郎了解甚多，所以也没法祝贺新娘。</paragraph>

Is such a resolution supported by experience or evidence? After all, no one has ever given a woman the opportunity to demonstrate the necessary judgement and wit. We have only conveniently condemned it as inadequate and have made this judgement an established truth which no one dares to question. </paragraph> <paragraph>We have witnessed many injuries to the daughters of Eve, and therefore may, or rather must, testify that the world is unjustly ordered in this respect. About the Vengeful Seamstress Not so long ago, a young seamstress used to have her own shop in Kuttenberg. A young nobleman regularly had his clothes made by her. He was always kind, brought her gifts, spared no praise and the seamstress liked him. Once he asked her to make him a coat and trousers in which he could propose to his beloved. The seamstress got all flushed and asked if she knew the girl. He smiled and said she didn't, but if she made the dress, she would certainly get to know her soon. The seamstress cheered inwardly and promised that the dress would be ready in three days. She chose the best cloth, worked day and night, and took care of every stitch. When on the third day the nobleman came to collect the finished dress, she had ants in her pants. 'You have golden hands,' the young man complimented her. 'I will go at once to my sweetheart and ask for her hand! When she says yes, I'll bring her here so you can make her a dress for the wedding!' The seamstress recognized that the nobleman had taken advantage of her, and she felt like crying. But she made no sign of it, and as she helped the young man into his new coat, she tore one of the sleeves. 'Oh, I am clumsy!' She apologized. 'You can't go to your sweetheart like that! Give me another day and I'll fix the coat!' The young man didn't want to wait any longer, but he agreed rather than ask a lady for her hand in a torn dress. The seamstress had ripped out all the seams overnight and sewn in fleas she had picked up from a stray dog. She finished the job by pouring several generous handfuls of salt into the folds of fabric. The next morning, the nobleman picked up the dress and immediately rushed to his mistress in it. Soon, however, fleas came out of the seams and began to bite him. The young man scratched and clawed, but only rubbed the pungent salt into the fresh bites. He wriggled, jumped, stumbled about, and before he reached his sweetheart's house the whole town was laughing at him.

女裁缝的报复 不久前，库滕堡有位经营着一家裁缝店的女裁缝，一位贵族青年常常会向她定制衣物。那位贵族青年举止和善，给女裁缝带来过不少礼物，也从不吝啬对她的赞美，这也让女裁缝对他颇有好感。一天，贵族青年请求女裁缝为他制作一件外套与一条裤子，他想穿着新衣裳向心上人求婚。听闻此事的女裁缝满脸通红，便问起青年，她是否认得那个女孩。 青年微微一笑，摇了摇头，还说如果她能够做出他要的衣裳，她很快就能认识那个女孩。女裁缝心花怒放，承诺会在三天内将衣物做好。她选用了最好的布料，夜以继日地工作着，一针一线都倾注了自己的心血。三日已至，青年前来拿取衣物，此时的女裁缝心中早已小鹿乱撞。 “你可真是妙手生花，”青年奉承道，“我马上就会去找我的爱人求婚！如果她答应了，我就把她带过来，到时候你就能为她定制婚服！” 女裁缝才意识到，原来贵族青年不过是在利用她，这也让她欲哭无泪。但她没有让自己的悲伤溢于言表，正当她为青年换上新衣裳时，她撕烂了衣服的一边袖子。 “啊！我真是笨手笨脚的！”她再三道歉，“你不能就这样去见你的爱人！再给我一天时间，我来帮你补好！” 青年虽无意再等，但不想穿着破衣裳向爱人求婚的他还是同意了这一提议。女裁缝连夜撕开了所有线缝，把她从一只流浪狗身上取下的跳蚤全都缝到了衣服里，最后还将好几大把盐倒入了衣服的褶层中。 次日早晨，才刚来取走衣服的贵族青年便立马奔向了自己的爱人。但是，跳蚤很快就从衣服接口中跳出，开始啃咬着青年。青年抓挠着，却将盐抓到了刚被啃咬的地方，伤口辛辣无比。他身体蜷曲，四处跳动，踉踉跄跄地走着，还没抵达爱人的家，整座城镇就响彻着对他的嘲笑声。

<subtitle>On Innocence</subtitle> <paragraph>A young man tenderly embraces his beloved and asks, 'Am I your first lover by any chance?' 'Could be,' she replies. 'I thought I'd seen you somewhere before.'</paragraph>
<subtitle>纯真</subtitle> <paragraph>一位年轻男子温柔地拥抱他的爱人，问道：“我是否是你的初恋？”女子回答说：“也许吧，我觉得我在哪里见过你。”</paragraph>
<subtitle>The Gravedigger's Jest</subtitle> <paragraph>What do you call a woman who knows exactly where her husband is every night? A widow.</paragraph>
<subtitle>掘墓人笑话</subtitle> <paragraph>什么样的女人能知道丈夫每晚都在哪？答案是寡妇！</paragraph>

About an Eloquent Lady and a Bad Dancer It is known that anyone can point out someone's shortcomings and bring shame upon them. But only few can point out someone's faults in such a way that the unfortunate person notices them without causing public ridicule. I will tell you of a lady who mastered this art. She was not only clever and quick in speech, but also young and beautiful to look at. When she appeared in society, men flocked to her. The young men asked her to dance and offered their arms, the older ones asked for her hand in marriage and offered what little the old men could still give to the young lady. Suddenly a young man asked her to dance. He had a handsome face and fine manners, so the lady accepted his proposal. After a few steps, however, she realized that she had made a big mistake. The dancer seemed to have two left feet. He stumbled, tripped, almost fell several times, and despite his apologies, the lady found dancing with him a torture. The other dancers noticed this, and began to whisper and point in their direction. Any other would have embarrassed him with indiscriminate words. She might even have told the other ladies to watch out for such loser. Not the lady in my story. What does it matter if he's a bad dancer? she said to herself. Others may dance with ease, but they also drink with it, indulge in dice and light girls. Better a bad dancer than a good drinker. So she smiled and said out loud for all to hear, "Young sir, how I would love to keep dancing with you. But I wore the wrong shoes today. They're pushing me so hard that I can't go on. Please escort me out into the fresh air." Her dancer quickly understood what she meant by that remark and hurriedly walked with her to the door. Everyone present thought that perhaps she was going to give him a hard time at the door, or give him a well-deserved slap. The lady and her dancer, however, did not return to the entertainment that evening.

善辩的女士与糟糕的舞者 众所周知，指出他人的缺点并教他蒙羞并非难事。但只有极少数人能运用语言的艺术，既能让当事人知晓错误，又不致使他贻笑大方。 这是一位精通这门艺术的女士的故事。她不仅聪明伶俐、思绪敏捷，还年轻貌美。每当她出现在社交场合，男士们便蜂拥而至。年轻人请她跳舞，向她投怀送抱，年长的则向她求婚，许诺那些在迟暮之年能够给予的一切。 突然，一位年轻男士请她跳舞。他面貌英俊，举止得体，于是女士接受了他的邀请。跳了几步之后，她才意识到自己犯了大错。这位舞者就像有两只左脚一样毫不协调，他跌跌撞撞，有好几次都几乎摔倒，尽管他不停地道歉，但与他共舞简直是一种折磨。其他的舞者也注意到了这一情况，开始窃窃私语，朝他们的方向指指点点。 换了别人，肯定会不分青红皂白地让他难堪，甚至可能昭告在场的所有女士远离这个失败者。但故事中的女士不会这样做。她扪心自问，跳舞不好难道是多大的罪过吗？其他人或许舞步轻盈，但他们也同样酗酒，沉迷于赌博和轻浮的女伴。尽管他舞步糟糕，也总比酒量过人者要来得好些。 因此，她面带微笑，大声地让所有人都能听到：“年轻的先生，我多么想继续与您共舞啊，但今天我穿错了鞋子，它们太紧了，我没法继续跳下去了。还请送我出门去换换气吧。” 舞者很快明白了她话中的意味，并急忙陪她走向门口。在场的每个人都以为她会在门口严厉地指责他，或者给他一记应得的耳光。然而，女士只是与她的舞伴默不作声地离去，当晚并未再归来。

For example, they claim that husbands who listen to their wives' advice are fools and deserve ridicule. But we say that a man who has a wife who is sensible and wise, and refuses to listen to her, is twice as foolish!</paragraph>

<newpage/><heading>悔改吧，亚当之子</heading> <subtitle>瓦伦施泰因和雷蒙德关于男女的论述</subtitle> <paragraph>在讨论男性与女性的议题上，许多人，特别是男性，常常声称女性是不完美的，容易犯各种罪过和错误。一条古老且公认的真理是：多数人的证词就是可信的证词，其真实性不容置疑。但是谁为女性定下这样的命运？是上帝还是男性？又有谁规定女性不能在没有男性指导的情况下思考、行动和决策？</paragraph> <paragraph>又是谁将女性定义为愚昧和陋习缠身，认为她们无法参与所谓“纯粹男性的领域”——政治、科学或自由艺术？这样的决议是否有经验或证据作为支撑？说到底，从未有人给予女性机会来展示她们所需的判断力和智慧，人们只是自顾自地认定她们能力不足，并将这一判断奉为既定事实，无人敢于质疑。</paragraph> <paragraph>我们见证过太多对夏娃之女的诽谤与中伤，因此我们可以，或者说必须站出来，证明这个世界在性别平等方面的不公。男性常常将自己凌驾于女性之上，并将种种罪责归咎于她们，但这一切只是为了掩盖他们自己的缺点！</paragraph> <paragraph>那些指责女性有恶习的男性，往往在年轻时也沉溺于放纵的生活。这些男性到了晚年，虽然对自身过去的罪行感到后悔，却从未真心悔改。正是出于这种心态，他们谴责女性，以便在所有与他们一派的人心中羞辱和诋毁她们。而他们的这些言论，就如同麻风病般在社会上蔓延。</paragraph> <paragraph>但与对女性的贬低相比，男人欺压其他男人的行为更胜一筹。比如，他们会嘲笑那些听从妻子建议的丈夫，认为这是愚蠢的行为。但如果一个男人有通情达理且聪慧的妻子，却不愿听从她建议，那才是真正的愚蠢！</paragraph>

<subtitle>On Innocence</subtitle> <paragraph>A young man tenderly embraces his lady and says, 'Am I your first lover by any chance?' 'Could be,' she replies, 'I thought I'd seen you somewhere before.'</paragraph>
<subtitle>纯真</subtitle> <paragraph>一位年轻男子温柔地拥抱他的爱人，问道：“我是否是你的初恋？”女子回答说：“也许吧，我觉得我在哪里见过你。”</paragraph>

<newpage/><subtitle>Thinking is Not Knowing</subtitle> <paragraph>A certain Kuttenberg Grandmaster once visited an old charlatan and wanted to know his fate. The charlatan examined his palm carefully and said to him, 'I see you are the father of two children...' 'That's what you think,' he shook his head. 'I am the father of three children!' 'That's what you think...' smiled the charlatan. </paragraph>
<newpage/><subtitle>想象非真知</subtitle> <paragraph>从前，库滕堡有一位大师拜访了一位年长的占卜师，希望了解自身的命运。占卜师认真地观察了他的手掌后说道：“我看到你有两个孩子……”“那只是你的想象罢了，”大师摇了摇头，“我有三个孩子！”“但那也只是你的想象……”但占卜师微笑着回答。</paragraph>

<subtitle>Wedding Toast</subtitle> <paragraph>Unfortunately, I don't know the bride, so I can't congratulate her husband. And knowing the groom too well, I can't congratulate the bride either.</paragraph>
<subtitle>婚礼祝词</subtitle> <paragraph>遗憾的是，我不认识新娘，所以没法祝贺新郎。我对新郎了解甚多，所以也没法祝贺新娘。</paragraph>
A book of short stories secretly written in Lady Rosa's hand. The last part is our work together.
一本由罗莎小姐秘密撰写的短篇故事集。最后一部分内容是由我与她协力完成的。

<subtitle>On Innocence</subtitle> <paragraph>A young man tenderly embraces his beloved and asks, 'Am I your first lover by any chance?' 'Could be,' she replies. 'I thought I'd seen you somewhere before.'</paragraph>
<subtitle>纯真</subtitle> <paragraph>一位年轻男子温柔地拥抱他的爱人，问道：“我是否是你的初恋？”女子回答说：“也许吧，我觉得我在哪里见过你。”</paragraph>

<newpage/><subtitle>Thinking is Not Knowing</subtitle> <paragraph>A certain Kuttenberg gentleman once visited an old charlatan and wanted to know his fate. The charlatan examined his palm carefully and said to him, 'I see you are the father of two children...' 'You're mistaken,' he shook his head. 'I am the father of three children!' 'It is you who are mistaken!' smiled the charlatan. </paragraph>
<newpage/><subtitle>想象非真知</subtitle> <paragraph>从前，库滕堡有一位男子拜访了一位年长的占卜师，希望了解自身的命运。占卜师认真地观察了他的手掌后说道：“我看到你有两个孩子……”“那只是你的想象罢了，”男子摇了摇头说，“我有三个孩子！”“但那也只是你的想象……”占卜师微笑着回答。</paragraph>

<subtitle>On the Wisdom of the Elders</subtitle> <paragraph>A father says to his son on his wedding day, 'Remember, son, that a newlywed woman loves well and cooks badly. But wait a few years and it will be just the opposite.'</paragraph>
<subtitle>过来人的智慧</subtitle> <paragraph>父亲在儿子的婚礼日对他说：“记住，儿子，新婚的女人爱意深沉，厨艺却很糟，几年之后，就会完全反过来了。”</paragraph>

The Black-eyed Girl Once upon a time there was a poor girl, black-eyed and black-haired, the most beautiful girl in those parts, though she wore poor clothes and lived in a shack by the woods. The other girls shunned her because they envied her beauty, but she ignored them. There was a miller in the village who thought of marrying her. He tried to flatter her with sweet words and told her what she would have if she became his wife. But she would not listen to his words. Soon word spread in the village that the miller was visiting her, and the rest of the girls became jealous. They came to the miller and each tried to tell him something bad about the black-eyed girl. She's a savage and a witch, they said. The miller pretended to listen attentively, but subtly took something from each of them. From one an embroidered ribbon, another a silver ring, the third a silk scarf. Then he hurried to the woods and gave the stolen items to the girl as a gift. He hoped to win her over and make her his wife at last. The black-eyed girl gratefully accepted the gifts, but when he proposed again, she again refused. The miller became angry, took her by the hand and dragged her to the stream where the other girls were washing clothes. 'I'm bringing you a thief! Look what she took from you! Your scarf, your ribbon, even your ring!' Each of them recognised her belongings and in a fit of rage, they killed the black-eyed girl. When they realized what they had done, they begged the miller to help them. He promised to say nothing and buried the girl's body under a dead hazel bush. Because she lived away from the village, no one looked for her for a long time, and the miller thought that everything would be forgotten. In the spring, however, the hazel bush turned green and new branches grew on it. When they grew stronger, the local shepherds made whistles out of them. But when they wanted to play, the whistles lamented: Eyes of black and bones of white lie here buried out of sight. The miller stole, the miller lied, 'Twas for his deceit that she died. And so the young miller was exposed and executed within a year of his crime.

黑眼女孩 从前有个穷女孩，黑色头发，黑色眼睛，是附近最漂亮的女孩。她穿着破旧的衣服，住在树林边的小屋里。其它女孩嫉妒她的美貌，对她避而远之，但她对此并不在意。 村里有个磨坊主，打算娶女孩为妻。他用甜言蜜语讨好她，告诉她如果成为他的妻子，她会得到大量的财富，但女孩拒绝了。不久后，磨坊主拜访她的消息传遍了村里，其它女孩变得更加嫉妒，她们纷纷跑去找磨坊主，说着黑眼女孩的坏话，说她是野蛮人，是女巫，是女妖的女儿…… 磨坊主装作认真地听，但暗中取走了每一位女孩的一件东西。一个是绣花丝带，一个是银戒指，还有一条丝绸围巾。随后他匆匆赶到树林，把偷来的东西当做礼物送给了黑眼女孩，并再次向她求婚。黑眼女孩感激地接受了礼物，但当磨坊主求婚时，她再次拒绝了。磨坊主十分愤怒，抓住女孩的手，把她拖到其他女孩正在洗衣服的小溪旁。 “这家伙就是个小偷！看看她偷了什么！你的丝带，你的戒指，还有你的围巾！”磨坊主说道。 三个人都认出了自己的物品，她们一怒之下杀死了黑眼女孩——而等她们回过神来，大错既已铸成，女孩们畏惧不已，恳求磨坊主帮帮她们。磨坊主答应对这件事守口如瓶，并把黑眼女孩的尸体埋在一颗枯死的榛树下。由于她住在村外，也没有人会去找她，磨坊主以为时间会冲刷他们的罪行。然而，随着春天到来，这颗枯死的榛树重焕新生。 榛树逐渐变得繁茂，当地的牧羊人就取下了它的枝条，做成了一个哨子。正当他们想要吹奏时，哨子中却传来了哀叹的曲调： 一双黑眼，一具白骨， 榛子树下，少女坟墓。 磨坊主偷，磨坊主骗， 亲手将她，埋于此处…… 随后，牧民们发现了少女的尸骨，磨坊主的罪行也因此暴露，在距离犯下罪行还未满一年时，就被处以了死刑。

<subtitle>Wedding toast</subtitle> <paragraph>Unfortunately, I don't know the bride, so I can't congratulate her groom. And knowing the groom too well, neither can I congratulate the bride.</paragraph>
<subtitle>婚礼祝词</subtitle> <paragraph>遗憾的是，我并不认识新娘，所以没法祝贺新郎。并且因为我对新郎了解甚多，所以也没法祝贺新娘。</paragraph>

<newpage/><heading>Repent, Adam's Gender</heading> <subtitle>A. von Wallenstein and Raimund R. Hardt on men and women</subtitle> <paragraph>As many, and men in particular, will gladly testify, of the two genders, it is the female that is imperfect, prone to all manner of sins and faults. It is an old known truth that the testimony of many is a credible testimony, the truth of which cannot be doubted. But who hath appointed the woman her lot? God? Or man? Who has decreed that woman is incapable of thinking, acting and deciding without the guidance of man?</paragraph> <paragraph>By whom was it determined that women were too foolish and vice-ridden to participate in matters wholly male - politics, science, or the liberal arts? Is such a resolution supported by experience or evidence? After all, no one has ever given a woman the opportunity to demonstrate the necessary judgement and wit. We have only conveniently condemned it as inadequate and have made this judgement an established truth which no one dares to question. </paragraph> <paragraph>We have witnessed many injuries to the daughters of Eve, and therefore may, or rather must, testify that the world is unjustly ordered in this respect. Men are fond of exalting themselves above women and attributing all sorts of wrongs to them, but only to cover their own faults!</paragraph> <paragraph>A man who accuses a woman of vice has squandered his own youth in licentiousness. In old age, these men recall with regret the sins of their past life without ever repenting of them. It is out of this bitterness that they denounce women, in order to humiliate and vilify them in the minds of all who are willing to listen to them. These corrupt old men are like incurable leprosy.</paragraph> <paragraph>But even more than women, men prefer to elevate themselves above other men. For example, they claim that husbands who listen to their wives' advice are fools and deserve ridicule. But we say that a man who has a wife who is sensible and wise, and refuses to listen to her, is twice as foolish!</paragraph>

<newpage/><heading>悔改吧，亚当之子</heading> <subtitle>瓦伦施泰因和雷蒙德关于男女的论述</subtitle> <paragraph>在讨论男性与女性的议题上，许多人，特别是男性，常常声称女性是不完美的，容易犯各种罪过和错误。一条古老且公认的真理是：多数人的证词就是可信的证词，其真实性不容置疑。但是谁为女性定下这样的命运？是上帝还是男性？又有谁规定女性不能在没有男性指导的情况下思考、行动和决策？</paragraph> <paragraph>又是谁将女性定义为愚昧和陋习缠身，认为她们无法参与所谓“纯粹男性的领域”——政治、科学或自由艺术？这样的决议是否有经验或证据作为支撑？说到底，从未有人给予女性机会来展示她们所需的判断力和智慧，人们只是自顾自地认定她们能力不足，并将这一判断奉为既定事实，无人敢于质疑。</paragraph> <paragraph>我们见证过太多对夏娃之女的诽谤与中伤，因此我们可以，或者说必须站出来，证明这个世界在性别平等方面的不公。男性常常将自己凌驾于女性之上，并将种种罪责归咎于她们，但这一切只是为了掩盖他们自己的缺点！</paragraph> <paragraph>那些指责女性有恶习的男性，往往在年轻时也沉溺于放纵的生活。这些男性到了晚年，虽然对自身过去的罪行感到后悔，却从未真心悔改。正是出于这种心态，他们谴责女性，以便在所有与他们一派的人心中羞辱和诋毁她们。而他们的这些言论，就如同麻风病般在社会上蔓延。</paragraph> <paragraph>但与对女性的贬低相比，男人欺压其他男人的行为更胜一筹。比如，他们会嘲笑那些听从妻子建议的丈夫，认为这是愚蠢的行为。但如果一个男人有通情达理且聪慧的妻子，却不愿听从她建议，那才是真正的愚蠢！</paragraph>
<subtitle>The Gravedigger's Jest</subtitle> <paragraph>What do you call a woman who knows exactly where her husband is every night? A widow.</paragraph>
<subtitle>掘墓人笑话</subtitle> <paragraph>什么样的女人能知道丈夫每晚都在哪？答案是寡妇！</paragraph>
A book of short stories secretly written by Lady Rosa. The final part is our joint work.
一本由罗莎小姐秘密撰写的短篇故事集。终章是由我们二人共同完成的。

The Nightingale Maiden In a distant land, there lived a young prince who, during one of his hunting trips into the forest, heard a girl's voice, singing so beautifully that the songbirds ruffled their feathers in envy. The prince followed the voice and thought to himself, "When I find this singing maiden, I will take her with me and marry her. Everyone will envy me, because my wife will sing more beautifully than a nightingale!" He walked and walked until he came to a clearing where an old, tall willow tree stood. In its crown sat a lovely maiden, singing so beautifully that even the wind in the branches fell silent. The prince set aside his crossbow, so as not to frighten the girl, and called out: "Beautiful maiden, I am the prince of this kingdom, and I ask for your hand! Be my wife and live as a queen!" "I cannot be your wife," she replied. "I am not allowed to leave here. But if you care for me, come again tomorrow." The prince was unwilling to give up the girl, and the next day he set out to see her again. He brought with him a magnificent golden ring. "Come with me, beautiful maiden. I will love you forever, and you will want for nothing!" he pleaded. "I’ve already told you that I cannot," she repeated. "But if you care for me, you will come again tomorrow." The third time, the prince brought the girl a dress made from the finest silk. She liked it, but again repeated that she could not marry him, even so. And so the young prince went to the willow a fourth time, bringing with him a trio of woodcutters. "You will finally be my wife!" he said, and ordered the tree to be cut down. The maiden wept and begged in vain. The tree soon fell to the ground, and the prince thought he had won. But as soon as her foot touched the moss-covered earth, the girl turned into a small nightingale and instantly disappeared into the shadows of the forest. Love cannot be taken by force, and whoever tries will soon lose it.

夜莺少女 从前在很远的地方有一位年轻的王子，有一天他在林间狩猎时，忽然听见一个女孩的声音。那歌声是如此美妙，让金丝雀都因为嫉妒竖起了羽毛。王子顺着声音走去，心想，如果找到了这位唱歌的女孩，我就带她回家，娶她为妻，这样所有人都会羡慕我，因为我妻子的歌声比夜莺还要动听！ 王子走呀走呀，来到了一片空地上，那里有一棵古老而茂盛的柳树，在树冠上坐着一位美丽的少女。少女的歌声如此动听，连枝叶间的风都为之驻足。王子放下弩箭，以免惊吓到少女，然后大声说道： “美丽的姑娘，我是这个国家的王子，我要向你求婚！做我的妻子，过王后的生活吧！” “我不能做您的妻子，”少女回答道，“我无法离开这里。但如果您对我有意，不妨明天再来这里。” 王子不愿放弃追求女孩，于是第二天他又去见她，还带了一枚精美的金戒指。 “跟我走吧，美丽的小姐。我会永远爱你，你想要什么都应有尽有！”他恳求道。 “我和您说过，我不能离开这里，”少女的回答一如既往，“但如果您对我有意，您明天可以再来这里。” 第三次，王子给女孩带来一条最好的丝绸做成的裙子。她很喜欢，但她仍然重申，即便如此，她也不能嫁给他。 于是年轻的王子第四次来到树下，还带来了三个樵夫。 “你终于能做我的妻子了！”他说道，并命令他们砍掉那棵树。 少女哭泣着乞求他停手。树很快倒在了地上，王子以为他终于成功了。但就当他的脚踩上长满青苔的土地时，女孩变成了一只小小的夜莺，迅速消失在森林的阴影里。爱情不能强取豪夺，若是有人强硬为之，便定会一无所获。

The charlatan examined his palm carefully and said to him, 'I see you are the father of two children...' 'You're mistaken,' he shook his head. 'I am the father of three children!' 'It is you who are mistaken!' smiled the charlatan. </paragraph>
