For example, they claim that husbands who listen to their wives' advice are fools and deserve ridicule. But we say that a man who has a wife who is sensible and wise, and refuses to listen to her, is twice as foolish!</paragraph>

<newpage/><heading>悔改吧，亚当之子</heading> <subtitle>瓦伦施泰因和雷蒙德关于男女的论述</subtitle> <paragraph>在讨论男性与女性的议题上，许多人，特别是男性，常常声称女性是不完美的，容易犯各种罪过和错误。一条古老且公认的真理是：多数人的证词就是可信的证词，其真实性不容置疑。但是谁为女性定下这样的命运？是上帝还是男性？又有谁规定女性不能在没有男性指导的情况下思考、行动和决策？</paragraph> <paragraph>又是谁将女性定义为愚昧和陋习缠身，认为她们无法参与所谓“纯粹男性的领域”——政治、科学或自由艺术？这样的决议是否有经验或证据作为支撑？说到底，从未有人给予女性机会来展示她们所需的判断力和智慧，人们只是自顾自地认定她们能力不足，并将这一判断奉为既定事实，无人敢于质疑。</paragraph> <paragraph>我们见证过太多对夏娃之女的诽谤与中伤，因此我们可以，或者说必须站出来，证明这个世界在性别平等方面的不公。男性常常将自己凌驾于女性之上，并将种种罪责归咎于她们，但这一切只是为了掩盖他们自己的缺点！</paragraph> <paragraph>那些指责女性有恶习的男性，往往在年轻时也沉溺于放纵的生活。这些男性到了晚年，虽然对自身过去的罪行感到后悔，却从未真心悔改。正是出于这种心态，他们谴责女性，以便在所有与他们一派的人心中羞辱和诋毁她们。而他们的这些言论，就如同麻风病般在社会上蔓延。</paragraph> <paragraph>但与对女性的贬低相比，男人欺压其他男人的行为更胜一筹。比如，他们会嘲笑那些听从妻子建议的丈夫，认为这是愚蠢的行为。但如果一个男人有通情达理且聪慧的妻子，却不愿听从她建议，那才是真正的愚蠢！</paragraph>

<newpage/><heading>Repent, Adam's Gender</heading> <subtitle>A. von Wallenstein and Raimund R. Hardt on men and women</subtitle> <paragraph>As many, and men in particular, will gladly testify, of the two genders, it is the female that is imperfect, prone to all manner of sins and faults. It is an old known truth that the testimony of many is a credible testimony, the truth of which cannot be doubted. But who hath appointed the woman her lot? God? Or man? Who has decreed that woman is incapable of thinking, acting and deciding without the guidance of man?</paragraph> <paragraph>By whom was it determined that women were too foolish and vice-ridden to participate in matters wholly male - politics, science, or the liberal arts? Is such a resolution supported by experience or evidence? After all, no one has ever given a woman the opportunity to demonstrate the necessary judgement and wit. We have only conveniently condemned it as inadequate and have made this judgement an established truth which no one dares to question. </paragraph> <paragraph>We have witnessed many injuries to the daughters of Eve, and therefore may, or rather must, testify that the world is unjustly ordered in this respect. Men are fond of exalting themselves above women and attributing all sorts of wrongs to them, but only to cover their own faults!</paragraph> <paragraph>A man who accuses a woman of vice has squandered his own youth in licentiousness. In old age, these men recall with regret the sins of their past life without ever repenting of them. It is out of this bitterness that they denounce women, in order to humiliate and vilify them in the minds of all who are willing to listen to them. These corrupt old men are like incurable leprosy.</paragraph> <paragraph>But even more than women, men prefer to elevate themselves above other men. For example, they claim that husbands who listen to their wives' advice are fools and deserve ridicule. But we say that a man who has a wife who is sensible and wise, and refuses to listen to her, is twice as foolish!</paragraph>

<newpage/><heading>悔改吧，亚当之子</heading> <subtitle>瓦伦施泰因和雷蒙德关于男女的论述</subtitle> <paragraph>在讨论男性与女性的议题上，许多人，特别是男性，常常声称女性是不完美的，容易犯各种罪过和错误。一条古老且公认的真理是：多数人的证词就是可信的证词，其真实性不容置疑。但是谁为女性定下这样的命运？是上帝还是男性？又有谁规定女性不能在没有男性指导的情况下思考、行动和决策？</paragraph> <paragraph>又是谁将女性定义为愚昧和陋习缠身，认为她们无法参与所谓“纯粹男性的领域”——政治、科学或自由艺术？这样的决议是否有经验或证据作为支撑？说到底，从未有人给予女性机会来展示她们所需的判断力和智慧，人们只是自顾自地认定她们能力不足，并将这一判断奉为既定事实，无人敢于质疑。</paragraph> <paragraph>我们见证过太多对夏娃之女的诽谤与中伤，因此我们可以，或者说必须站出来，证明这个世界在性别平等方面的不公。男性常常将自己凌驾于女性之上，并将种种罪责归咎于她们，但这一切只是为了掩盖他们自己的缺点！</paragraph> <paragraph>那些指责女性有恶习的男性，往往在年轻时也沉溺于放纵的生活。这些男性到了晚年，虽然对自身过去的罪行感到后悔，却从未真心悔改。正是出于这种心态，他们谴责女性，以便在所有与他们一派的人心中羞辱和诋毁她们。而他们的这些言论，就如同麻风病般在社会上蔓延。</paragraph> <paragraph>但与对女性的贬低相比，男人欺压其他男人的行为更胜一筹。比如，他们会嘲笑那些听从妻子建议的丈夫，认为这是愚蠢的行为。但如果一个男人有通情达理且聪慧的妻子，却不愿听从她建议，那才是真正的愚蠢！</paragraph>

The Miserly Burgher Being rich doesn't necessarily make a person bad. While there are rich people who are greedy and selfish, they are certainly not all like that. The burgher of our story is, however, is one of the richest and most miserly who ever lived. For his name was Hermann Knauser! Knauser was renowned in the town for his wealth, but his greed was the talk of the region. He had the most beautiful house in the best quarter and liked to invite visitors who admired its decoration. When it came to hospitality, however, he gave them dry bread, lest they should eat of the delicacies he kept for himself. One day, a painter who had formerly also stayed at the royal court came to town. 'So to have him paint something for me would certainly be the envy of all!' thought Knauser, and the next day he invited the master to his house. He took him through the rooms, showing him the costly furniture, fabrics and statuettes with which they were decorated. The painter examined everything, but said nothing. Finally, Knauser told him: 'Master, you see that my house contains the best of all kinds of art. I have seen the works of various artists, and few things can surprise me yet, let alone make me pay for it. What do you think, master, can you paint something like this?' The master, who had long ago guessed Knauser's character, shook his head and replied: 'I'm certain I can. I'll show you something that will make your head spin. But I'll need plenty of time, and I can't bear for the client to see the work unfinished. If you really want my painting, go away for a week, let me work in peace, and when you come back, I promise you will find a work like you've never seen before.' Knauser didn't want to host the master for a week, but finally agreed and left. Instead of painting for a week, the master had Knauser's servants wait on him hand and foot, gradually drinking dry the wine cellar and emptying the pantry. It was not until just before his departure that he picked up his brushes and paints. When Knauser returned seven days later, he found the house empty of stocks, eaten to the last crumb. He ran to the room where the master was to paint his picture on the wall. There he found a hastily painted fat roast pig on a golden platter, with a golden apple in its jaws.

关于吝啬者 富有并不一定使人变坏，虽然很多富人都贪婪自私，但绝对不是所有富人都这样。然而，我们的主人公则是有史以来最富有却又最吝啬的人之一。他的名字叫赫尔曼·克瑙瑟！ 克瑙瑟的富有程度在城镇中人尽皆知，但他吝啬的名声更是为当地人所津津乐道。他在城中最好的地段有一栋最漂亮的房子，并经常邀请客人来访，供他们欣赏房子的华美装饰。然而，在招待客人时，他却只给他们干面包吃，生怕他们吃了自己私藏的美味佳肴。 有一天，一位曾在皇家宫廷任职过的画家来到镇上。“请他为我画点东西一定会让所有人羡慕不已！”克瑙瑟先生心想。于是，第二天他就邀请这位大师来到他家。克瑙瑟带着画家参观了各个房间，向他展示了昂贵的家具、织物和雕像。画家注视着这一切，但一言不发。 最后，克瑙瑟对画家说： “大师，您也见到了，我的房子里有各种最好的艺术品。我已见过无数艺术家的画作，但多数平平无奇，极少有能吸引我的，更不用说让我为之付钱了。您觉得如何呢，大师？您能画出足以让我愿意打开腰包的惊世之作吗？” 大师早已揣摩出到克瑙瑟的品性，于是他先是摇了摇头，然后说道： “我当然可以画出与您的目光相匹的作品，但这样伟大的画作需要足够的时间才能完成。而且，我也无法接受让我尊贵的客户看到作品未完成的样子。如果您真的想要我为您作画，就请离开一周，让我安静地工作。等您回来时，我保证，您定能看到一副前所未见的作品。” 克瑙瑟本不想白白接待大师一周，但最终还是妥协并离开了。然而，大师在这一周里并没有作画，而是和仆人们打成一片，喝光了酒窖的酒，洗劫了储藏室里的存粮。直到临走前，他才拿起画笔和颜料。 七天后，克瑙瑟回来时发现房子里空无一人，连最后一块面包屑也被吃光了。他跑到本应是大师作画的房间，只见那里匆匆画了一只放在金色托盘上的烤肥猪，嘴里含着一个金苹果。

<subtitle>On Innocence</subtitle> <paragraph>A young man tenderly embraces his beloved and asks, 'Am I your first lover by any chance?' 'Could be,' she replies. 'I thought I'd seen you somewhere before.'</paragraph>
<subtitle>纯真</subtitle> <paragraph>一位年轻男子温柔地拥抱他的爱人，问道：“我是否是你的初恋？”女子回答说：“也许吧，我觉得我在哪里见过你。”</paragraph>

<subtitle>Wedding toast</subtitle> <paragraph>Unfortunately, I don't know the bride, so I can't congratulate her groom. And knowing the groom too well, neither can I congratulate the bride.</paragraph>
<subtitle>婚礼祝词</subtitle> <paragraph>遗憾的是，我不认识新娘，所以没法祝贺新郎。我对新郎了解甚多，所以也没法祝贺新娘。</paragraph>
A book of short stories secretly written in Lady Rosa's hand. The last part is our work together.
一本由罗莎小姐秘密撰写的短篇故事集。最后一部分内容是由我与她协力完成的。

<newpage/><subtitle>Thinking is Not Knowing</subtitle> <paragraph>A certain Kuttenberg gentleman once visited an old charlatan and wanted to know his fate. The charlatan examined his palm carefully and said to him, 'I see you are the father of two children...' 'You're mistaken,' he shook his head. 'I am the father of three children!' 'It is you who are mistaken!' smiled the charlatan. </paragraph>
<newpage/><subtitle>想象非真知</subtitle> <paragraph>从前，库滕堡有一位男子拜访了一位年长的占卜师，希望了解自身的命运。占卜师认真地观察了他的手掌后说道：“我看到你有两个孩子……”“那只是你的想象罢了，”男子摇了摇头说，“我有三个孩子！”“但那也只是你的想象……”占卜师微笑着回答。</paragraph>

<subtitle>On the Wisdom of the Elders</subtitle> <paragraph>A father says to his son on his wedding day, 'Remember, son, that a newlywed woman loves well and cooks badly. But wait a few years and it will be just the opposite.'</paragraph>
<subtitle>过来人的智慧</subtitle> <paragraph>父亲在儿子的婚礼日对他说：“记住，儿子，新婚的女人爱意深沉，厨艺却很糟，几年之后，就会完全反过来了。”</paragraph>
<subtitle>The Gravedigger's Jest</subtitle> <paragraph>What do you call a woman who knows exactly where her husband is every night? A widow.</paragraph>
<subtitle>掘墓人笑话</subtitle> <paragraph>什么样的女人能知道丈夫每晚都在哪？答案是寡妇！</paragraph>

About the miser who rose from the dead Once upon a time there was a man in Kuttenberg who was considered the biggest miser in town. He never dropped a coin to beggars or street hustlers, he never went to taverns or bathhouses. Even when he walked down the street with a lantern and someone wanted to light a candle from him, he would not share lest he accidentally run out of light. Even thieves avoided his house because there was nothing to take. His servants had to work for a pittance, and were given hard bread and half a tankard of beer with their meals. But even that was not enough for the miser. He pondered and pondered until he figured out a way to keep all his servants hungry for at least one day. He consulted the apothecary, and in the morning, at the time he usually woke up, his servants discovered him lying on his bed, pale, cold, as if dead. None of them suspected that their master was actually alive and hearing their every word. They washed his body and wrapped him in a shroud, as was proper. But then they began to rejoice and rejoice loudly. When, instead of mourning and fasting, the servants opened the larders and chambers, rolled out the casks of wine and began to feast, the false dead man decided to put a stop to their celebrations. He arose from his bed, and, still in the shroud, ran among them. But before he could say anything, one of his servants, by this time quite drunk, cried out, "Ghost!" and took him over the head with a jug. The master was dead on the spot, but it was three days and three nights before anyone called for a priest.

死而复生的守财奴 从前，在库滕堡，有一个非常吝啬的人，他从不施舍一分钱给乞丐或街头小贩，也从不去酒馆或浴室消费。即便是他提着灯笼走在街上，有人想借他的灯笼点燃蜡烛，他也不愿分享出一丝光亮。就连小偷也会绕开他的房子，因为所有财产都锁着，房间里空无一物。 他的仆人们只有微薄的工资，每餐只有硬面包和半杯啤酒，但即使如此，守财奴仍不满足， 他左思右想，终于想出一个办法，能少供他们几顿餐食。 他咨询了草药师如何装病，随后在早上起床的时间，仆人们发现他躺在床上，脸色惨白，身体冰冷，仿佛死了一样。因为他装得很像，没有人意识到他们的主人只是在装死，而且能听到他们的每一句话。仆人们按照惯例，给守财奴清洗身体，用裹尸布包好，随后他们却开始欢呼雀跃，大声庆祝。 仆人们并没有像守财奴想象中那样在哀悼和禁食，而是打开储藏室和酒窖，开始盛宴。假死的守财奴哪里受得了这个？他立刻跳起来，披着裹尸布冲入人群， 要终止他们的庆祝，但还没等他说话，一个醉得厉害的仆人大喊一声“鬼啊！”，用酒瓶狠狠敲打了守财奴的头。守财奴当场死去，但直到三天三夜之后，才有人敢去叫神父来驱邪。

Hardt on men and women</subtitle> <paragraph>As many, and men in particular, will gladly testify, of the two genders, it is the female that is imperfect, prone to all manner of sins and faults. It is an old known truth that the testimony of many is a credible testimony, the truth of which cannot be doubted. But who hath appointed the woman her lot? God? Or man? Who has decreed that woman is incapable of thinking, acting and deciding without the guidance of man?</paragraph> <paragraph>By whom was it determined that women were too foolish and vice-ridden to participate in matters wholly male - politics, science, or the liberal arts? Is such a resolution supported by experience or evidence? After all, no one has ever given a woman the opportunity to demonstrate the necessary judgement and wit. We have only conveniently condemned it as inadequate and have made this judgement an established truth which no one dares to question. </paragraph> <paragraph>We have witnessed many injuries to the daughters of Eve, and therefore may, or rather must, testify that the world is unjustly ordered in this respect. Men are fond of exalting themselves above women and attributing all sorts of wrongs to them, but only to cover their own faults!</paragraph> <paragraph>A man who accuses a woman of vice has squandered his own youth in licentiousness. In old age, these men recall with regret the sins of their past life without ever repenting of them. It is out of this bitterness that they denounce women, in order to humiliate and vilify them in the minds of all who are willing to listen to them. These corrupt old men are like incurable leprosy.</paragraph> <paragraph>But even more than women, men prefer to elevate themselves above other men. For example, they claim that husbands who listen to their wives' advice are fools and deserve ridicule. But we say that a man who has a wife who is sensible and wise, and refuses to listen to her, is twice as foolish!</paragraph>

一本由罗莎小姐秘密撰写的短篇故事集。最后一部分内容是由我与她协力完成的。

<subtitle>On Innocence</subtitle> <paragraph>A young man tenderly embraces his beloved and asks, 'Am I your first lover by any chance?' 'Could be,' she replies. 'I thought I'd seen you somewhere before.'</paragraph>
<subtitle>纯真</subtitle> <paragraph>一位年轻男子温柔地拥抱他的爱人，问道：“我是否是你的初恋？”女子回答说：“也许吧，我觉得我在哪里见过你。”</paragraph>

<newpage/><heading>Repent, Adam's Gender</heading> <subtitle>A. von Wallenstein and Raimund R. Hardt on men and women</subtitle> <paragraph>As many, and men in particular, will gladly testify, of the two genders, it is the female that is imperfect, prone to all manner of sins and faults. It is an old known truth that the testimony of many is a credible testimony, the truth of which cannot be doubted. But who hath appointed the woman her lot? God? Or man? Who has decreed that woman is incapable of thinking, acting and deciding without the guidance of man?</paragraph> <paragraph>By whom was it determined that women were too foolish and vice-ridden to participate in matters wholly male - politics, science, or the liberal arts? Is such a resolution supported by experience or evidence? After all, no one has ever given a woman the opportunity to demonstrate the necessary judgement and wit. We have only conveniently condemned it as inadequate and have made this judgement an established truth which no one dares to question. </paragraph> <paragraph>We have witnessed many injuries to the daughters of Eve, and therefore may, or rather must, testify that the world is unjustly ordered in this respect. Men are fond of exalting themselves above women and attributing all sorts of wrongs to them, but only to cover their own faults!</paragraph> <paragraph>A man who accuses a woman of vice has squandered his own youth in licentiousness. In old age, these men recall with regret the sins of their past life without ever repenting of them. It is out of this bitterness that they denounce women, in order to humiliate and vilify them in the minds of all who are willing to listen to them. These corrupt old men are like incurable leprosy.</paragraph> <paragraph>But even more than women, men prefer to elevate themselves above other men. For example, they claim that husbands who listen to their wives' advice are fools and deserve ridicule. But we say that a man who has a wife who is sensible and wise, and refuses to listen to her, is twice as foolish!</paragraph>

<newpage/><heading>悔改吧，亚当之子</heading> <subtitle>瓦伦施泰因和雷蒙德关于男女的论述</subtitle> <paragraph>在讨论男性与女性的议题上，许多人，特别是男性，常常声称女性是不完美的，容易犯各种罪过和错误。一条古老且公认的真理是：多数人的证词就是可信的证词，其真实性不容置疑。但是谁为女性定下这样的命运？是上帝还是男性？又有谁规定女性不能在没有男性指导的情况下思考、行动和决策？</paragraph> <paragraph>又是谁将女性定义为愚昧和陋习缠身，认为她们无法参与所谓“纯粹男性的领域”——政治、科学或自由艺术？这样的决议是否有经验或证据作为支撑？说到底，从未有人给予女性机会来展示她们所需的判断力和智慧，人们只是自顾自地认定她们能力不足，并将这一判断奉为既定事实，无人敢于质疑。</paragraph> <paragraph>我们见证过太多对夏娃之女的诽谤与中伤，因此我们可以，或者说必须站出来，证明这个世界在性别平等方面的不公。男性常常将自己凌驾于女性之上，并将种种罪责归咎于她们，但这一切只是为了掩盖他们自己的缺点！</paragraph> <paragraph>那些指责女性有恶习的男性，往往在年轻时也沉溺于放纵的生活。这些男性到了晚年，虽然对自身过去的罪行感到后悔，却从未真心悔改。正是出于这种心态，他们谴责女性，以便在所有与他们一派的人心中羞辱和诋毁她们。而他们的这些言论，就如同麻风病般在社会上蔓延。</paragraph> <paragraph>但与对女性的贬低相比，男人欺压其他男人的行为更胜一筹。比如，他们会嘲笑那些听从妻子建议的丈夫，认为这是愚蠢的行为。但如果一个男人有通情达理且聪慧的妻子，却不愿听从她建议，那才是真正的愚蠢！</paragraph>
<subtitle>The Gravedigger's Jest</subtitle> <paragraph>What do you call a woman who knows exactly where her husband is every night? A widow.</paragraph>
<subtitle>掘墓人笑话</subtitle> <paragraph>什么样的女人能知道丈夫每晚都在哪？答案是寡妇！</paragraph>

<newpage/><subtitle>Thinking is Not Knowing</subtitle> <paragraph>A certain Kuttenberg gentleman once visited an old charlatan and wanted to know his fate. The charlatan examined his palm carefully and said to him, 'I see you are the father of two children...' 'You're mistaken,' he shook his head. 'I am the father of three children!' 'It is you who are mistaken!' smiled the charlatan. </paragraph>
<newpage/><subtitle>想象非真知</subtitle> <paragraph>从前，库滕堡有一位男子拜访了一位年长的占卜师，希望了解自身的命运。占卜师认真地观察了他的手掌后说道：“我看到你有两个孩子……”“那只是你的想象罢了，”男子摇了摇头说，“我有三个孩子！”“但那也只是你的想象……”占卜师微笑着回答。</paragraph>

<subtitle>On the Wisdom of the Elders</subtitle> <paragraph>A father says to his son on his wedding day, 'Remember, son, that a newlywed woman loves well and cooks badly. But wait a few years and it will be just the opposite.'</paragraph>
<subtitle>过来人的智慧</subtitle> <paragraph>父亲在儿子的婚礼日对他说：“记住，儿子，新婚的女人爱意深沉，厨艺却很糟，几年之后，就会完全反过来了。”</paragraph>

About the one-legged heron Once upon a time there was a cook. His name was Witzbold, and one afternoon he was preparing his master a heron for dinner. The bird was already roasted, and the cook was just cutting fresh bread to nibble on, when a maid he was very fond of came into the kitchen. 'Witzbold, what a smell!' she gushed. 'Would you give me a thigh...' 'I am not giving you anything!' he protested. 'That's a heron for our master!' 'If you're so stingy, I'll also be tonight!' the maid retorted. The cook was mollified, gave the girl a heron's leg, and hurried to the dining hall with the rest of the roast. But the master immediately noticed that the bird was missing one leg. He called Witzbold back and demanded an explanation. 'My lord, herons have just one leg. And therefore one thigh,' Witzbold replied seriously. 'What are you saying, cook? Do you take me for a fool?' the master fumed. 'It is as I say, Sir. If you want to see for yourself, I'll show you.' the cook boasted. The gentleman, convinced that the cook was lying, agreed. The next morning they went together to the pond, where a whole flock of herons were sleeping by the banks. Their heads were tucked under their wings and they were actually standing on one leg. 'So you see, Sir, one bird, one leg,' the cook pointed triumphantly. The gentleman, however, did not accept defeat. He put his hands to his mouth and shouted: 'Shoo!' until all the herons flew to the sky. Clearly they both saw that they had two legs, like any other bird. 'Well, cook? Are you still going to tell me they only have one leg?' frowned the master. 'Oh no, Sir,' Witzbold defended himself. 'But you didn't shout "shoo" at dinner last night either. Had you done so, certainly the other leg would have grown on the roast.' It served the Lord's honour that he laughed heartily instead of thinking of punishment. Witzbold appreciated it and never again presented him with an incomplete dinner.

独脚苍鹭的故事 从前有一位厨师，他的名字叫维茨博尔德。一天下午，他正在为主人准备晚餐，烤好了一只苍鹭。就在他切着新鲜面包准备当配菜时，一位他暗恋已久的女仆走进了厨房。 “维茨博尔德，这肉闻起来真香啊！”她兴奋地说。“你能给我一只鸟腿吗？” “我不能这样做呀！”他答道。“这可是给我们主人的苍鹭！” “如果现在不给我，晚上你也什么都别想要！”女仆反驳道。 厨师被说服了，给了女仆一只苍鹭腿，然后匆匆忙忙地把剩下的烤鸟端到餐厅。但主人很快注意到鸟缺了一条腿，他立刻叫回了维茨博尔德并要求他解释。 “我的主人，苍鹭就是一种只有一条腿的生物。”维茨博尔德一本正经地回答。 “你在开什么玩笑啊？把我当傻子吗？”主人怒气冲冲地说。 “真是这样的，先生。如果您想亲眼看看，我可以带您去看。”厨师自信地回答。 虽然主人依旧认为厨师在撒谎，但还是给了他一个机会。他们一起去了池塘，那里的河岸上正有一大群苍鹭在睡觉。它们的头缩在翅膀下，确实都只用一条腿站着。 “您看，先生，每只鸟都只有一条腿。”厨师得意地指着鸟群说。 当然，主人并不会这么轻易上当，他把双手放在嘴边，对着鸟群大喊“去！”，鸟群被惊醒了，纷纷飞向天空，显然它们都有两条腿，和其他任何鸟类一样。 “那么，厨师，你还有什么好说的呢？”主人皱着眉头问。 “哦不，先生。”维茨博尔德艰难地辩解着，“如果您昨晚晚餐的时候也喊了‘去’，那么烤鸟的第二条腿也会长出来的。” 主人听了这风趣的回答，哈哈大笑，没有惩罚厨师。维茨博尔德对他的仁慈非常感激，从此再也没有呈上过偷工减料的晚餐。

<subtitle>Wedding toast</subtitle> <paragraph>Unfortunately, I don't know the bride, so I can't congratulate her groom. And knowing the groom too well, neither can I congratulate the bride.</paragraph>
<subtitle>婚礼祝词</subtitle> <paragraph>遗憾的是，我不认识新娘，所以没法祝贺新郎。我对新郎了解甚多，所以也没法祝贺新娘。</paragraph>

<subtitle>掘墓人笑话</subtitle> <paragraph>什么样的女人能知道丈夫每晚都在哪？答案是寡妇！</paragraph>

A widower who remarried Once upon a time there was a rich old burgher in Kuttenberg. He had been widowed long ago, but he was not so old that he wanted to live alone. So he married a maid who served him. She was a simple, poor girl, but prettier than any noblewoman and twice as clever. But the old widower did not know that. It was enough for him to enjoy the sight of his wife during the day, and once in a while to enjoy her in the evening. He had no idea that the girl had eyes for his young groom more than for him. So when her husband did not want to enjoy her in the evening, she hurried to the stables to see the groom who slept there. One day, however, she forgot that her husband had an important journey early in the morning. What a surprise it was to both partners when the master entered the stable at dawn. Instead of a horse, he found a saddled groom and his own wife in the saddle. What a scream! The husband called her a harlot and was about to go to the town bailiff to get justice. His wife, however, did not just give in. She stood in his way and said: "Before you go complaining about me, think. Have I ever been unkind to you? When you asked me to come to you for the evening to please you, did I ever refuse?" "Never," the old man admitted. "You always came to me as I asked." "Have I ever been stingy, unwilling, or cold to you? Have I refused to give you what you wanted from me?" "No," he repeated, more modestly now. "You always gave me everything I asked for." "So tell me, what was I supposed to do with what was left? Feed it to the pigs? Lock it in a chest and throw away the key? After all, isn't it better to please another man who loves me? It doesn't take away from what's rightfully yours." The husband felt ashamed at the words and had to admit that his wife was right and to this day Plümmel, the town bailiff, still knows nothing of it.

再婚的鳏夫 很久以前，在库滕堡有一位富有的老人，他已经守寡不少年了，但他又不算太老，不想一个人度过余生。因此，他娶了一个侍女为妻。她是个朴实的穷姑娘，但容貌不输其他贵妇，才学更是远胜之。不过，鳏夫对她了解不深，于他而言，白天能欣赏她的美貌，晚上能享受她的陪伴，便已足矣。她真正的心上人是一位年轻的马夫，但他对此并不知情。 于是，在那些不必陪伴丈夫的晚上，女仆就会跑去马厩和马夫幽会。然而有一天，女孩去陪马夫时，忘记了丈夫第二天一早就要出门，在黎明时分被抓了个正着——那时她正骑在鞍上，而鞍下的是她的小情人。他惊叫出声，指责她是荡妇，并准备去找镇上的法官讨回公道。 但他的妻子并未屈服，她拦住了老人说： “先等等，你不妨想想，我之前有对你不好过吗？当你每晚要求我来取悦你时，我有拒绝过吗？” “确实没有。”老人回想了一下，承认道，“你每次都很听话。” “我有过哪怕一次对你吝啬我的关爱，对你表露出不情愿，或者对你冷眼相对吗？我哪怕拒绝过任何一次你的要求吗？” “也没有，老人再次回答，这次更加动摇了，“你一直给予我我想要的一切。” “所以，告诉我，我已经给了你需要的一切，我剩下的时间要怎么办？难道要拿去喂猪？或者锁在箱子里丢掉吗？在你不需要侍奉的时候，我去取悦另一个爱我的男人，又没有剥夺你任何应得的东西，有什么不可以的吗？” 丈夫听了十分羞愧，承认她的妻子是对的。于是直至今日，镇上的法官普卢梅尔仍然对此事毫不知情。

<newpage/><heading>Repent, Adam's Gender</heading> <subtitle>A. von Wallenstein and Raimund R. Hardt on men and women</subtitle> <paragraph>As many, and men in particular, will gladly testify, of the two genders, it is the female that is imperfect, prone to all manner of sins and faults. Is such a resolution supported by experience or evidence? After all, no one has ever given a woman the opportunity to demonstrate the necessary judgement and wit. Men are fond of exalting themselves above women and attributing all sorts of wrongs to them, but only to cover their own faults!</paragraph> <paragraph>A man who accuses a woman of vice has squandered his own youth in licentiousness. These corrupt old men are like incurable leprosy.</paragraph> <paragraph>But even more than women, men prefer to elevate themselves above other men. For example, they claim that husbands who listen to their wives' advice are fools and deserve ridicule. But we say that a man who has a wife who is sensible and wise, and refuses to listen to her, is twice as foolish!</paragraph>

Have you ever tried hunting those damned overgrown rats? How did it go? Well, now you know why ermine is so expensive…
你可曾抓捕过那些该死的黄鼠狼？结果如何？怎样，现在你知道为何鼬皮如此昂贵了吧。
Towards Flexibility of the Body III
A skill book on Agility. Can be read from level 10 of this skill.
一本关于敏捷的技能书。敏捷技能10级以上才能阅读。
The cat is perhaps the only creature of God that can change the state of its body at will. Either liquid like water, immaterial like ether, solid like... Well, just be like a cat!
在上帝的造物里，猫似乎是唯一能够自如改变体态的生物。它们要么像水一样呈液态，要么像以太一样无形，或者坚硬如……总之，学学猫的本领吧！
Towards Flexibility of the Body II
A skill book on Agility. Can be read from level 5 of this skill.
一本关于敏捷的技能书。敏捷技能5级以上才能阅读。
The pike, the so-called queen of our rivers. Fast, agile and relentless hunter of anything that moves underwater or flies just above it. But even a non-swimmer could learn a thing or two from her!
狗鱼，河流之中的女王，它速度飞快，身法敏捷，无论在水面还是水下都是无情的猎手。就算是最不擅长游泳的猎人，也能在它们身上学到几招！
一本关于敏捷的技能书。

You'll be like the wind. No one will clinch you unless you want it.
你当像风一样，谁能将你留住，除非你作茧自缚。

Just as the power of God in the sacred transubstantiation can transform the wine and the host into the blood and body of the Lord, it can also endow various potions with healing power. Thus the man of true faith finds redemption in the decoction of belladona, but the unbeliever finds death.
正如上帝在圣餐变体仪式中能将圣酒或圣饼转化为耶稣的血液与身体一样，他同样有能力赋予各种药剂治愈的精力。因此，拥有真正信仰的人在颠茄制作的煎剂中觅见了救赎，而等待无信仰之人的只有死亡。
If you don't have sage, put onions in. And if you don't have onions, don't put anything in, just add more liquor to the base.
如果没有鼠尾草，就把洋葱放进去。如果你没有洋葱，那就啥也别放，往底酒中多加点烈酒就行。
On the Composition of Alchemy III
A skill book on Alchemy. Can be read from level 10 of this skill.
一本关于炼金术的技能书。炼金术技能10级以上才能阅读。
On the Composition of Alchemy II
Agita, agitamus, agitant, commiscere, commiscemus, commisunt, ferve, ferve, ferve, bullio, bullio, commiscemus. Stridere, stridere. Tero, tero, tero. Et plunctus!
Agita, agitamus, agitant, commiscere, commiscemus, commisunt, ferve, ferve, ferve, bullio, bullio, commiscemus. Stridere, stridere. Tero, tero, tero. Et plunctus!
A skill book on Alchemy. Can be read from level 5 of this skill.
一本关于炼金术的技能书。炼金术技能5级以上才能阅读。
一本关于炼金术的技能书。
On the Composition of Alchemy I

Magic potions usually use strange sounding ingredients, but their origin is quite simple. Prepare the eye of a newt (mustard seed), the finger of a frog (ranunculus), the tongue of a dog (cynoglossum) and the tooth of a wolf (aconitum).
魔药经常使用一些听着很奇怪的成分，但真相其实很普通。蝾螈的眼睛是芥菜籽，青蛙的手指是毛茛，狗的舌头是倒提壶，而狼的牙齿是乌头。

Sift the flour well, mix with lukewarm water and do not spare the salt. Knead the dough thus formed into patties, toast it on a hot stone and rub it well with lard and crushed garlic. Sprinkle the hot pancakes thickly with cracklings and raw onions and ingest three times a day.
将面粉筛好，混合温水，多放盐。将面团揉成饼状，在热石上烤熟，然后用猪油和捣碎的大蒜涂抹均匀。最后在热煎饼撒上大量的油渣和生洋葱，每天食用三次。
A skill book on Alchemy. Can be read from level 15 of this skill.
一本关于炼金术的技能书。炼金术技能15级以上才能阅读。
On the Composition of Alchemy IV
A skill book on Craftsmanship. Can be read from level 15 of this skill.
一本关于工艺的技能书。工艺技能15级以上才能阅读。
一本关于工艺的技能书。
A skill book on Craftsmanship. Can be read from level 10 of this skill.
一本关于工艺的技能书。工艺技能10级以上才能阅读。
A skill book on Craftsmanship. Can be read from level 5 of this skill.
一本关于工艺的技能书。工艺技能5级以上才能阅读。
Just don't forget to tell all your customers that every thing needs to be taken care of! And why? Well, that's obvious. They can pay you well for every repair, honing or maintenance!
别忘了告诉你的所有客户，每件物品都需要被妥善保养！为什么呢？这很明显：每次修理、打磨，或者保养的时候，他们都要支付给你不菲的报酬！

They say even slander sells and every disgruntled customer will bring you two new ones, but if you sell someone such shitty armour that they get impaled in the first fight, they won't be able to tell anyone about you!
黑红也是红，就算是差评也会吸引来一两个新顾客。但如果你卖的盔甲太糟，顾客第一场战斗就被刺死了，那就没法给你带来任何宣传效果了！

You may be a master craftsman, but which is better - to sell one wooden figurine for a hundred groschen, or ten figurines for fifteen? And so what if they're full of splinters? At least they'll prod the customer's interest!
你或许是个手艺大师，但卖一个雕像，每个一百枚格罗申，和卖十个雕像，每个十五枚格罗申，哪边更好？你说什么，它们都长得一样，质量都很差？没关系！至少顾客们会一见倾心！
The iron must be forged while hot. That doesn't mean you're going touch it with your bare hands, you numbskull! Take the tongs!
铁件必须在高温下进行锻造，但你可不能伸手去碰，你这蠢货！拿钳子来！
Glo glo glo glo gloria! How the beer goes down the throat! Glo glo glo glo glo gloria! How that beer goes down!
Glo glo glo glo gloria！一杯啤酒饮入喉！Glo glo glo glo glo gloria！一杯啤酒吞入腹！
A skill book on Drinking and alcoholism. Can be read from level 10 of this skill.
一本关于饮酒和酒精中毒的技能书。饮酒技能10级以上才能阅读。
That tavern of ours, from top to bottom, such a lovely place! The soup is hot, the beer is cold, there's a smile on the innkeep's face!
完完全全属于我们自己的酒馆，真是个好地方！热汤滚烫，啤酒冰爽，店主脸上神采飞扬！
A skill book on Drinking and alcoholism. Can be read from level 5 of this skill.
一本关于饮酒和酒精中毒的技能书。饮酒技能5级以上才能阅读。
A skill book on Drinking and Alcoholism.
一本关于饮酒和酒精中毒的技能书。

Up to our tavern door, there are three steps and no more.
That's the reason, my dear, why I love to come here.
From the tavern door, those three steps seem like a score.
That's the reason, my dear, why I'm afraid to leave here.
独坐此门前，台阶数到三。何处尽欢娱？心爱小酒馆。
A skill book on Drinking and alcoholism. Can be read from level 15 of this skill.
一本关于饮酒和酒精中毒的技能书。饮酒技能15级以上才能阅读。
On Wednesday I'm at the Devil's Den, on Thursday I'm at the Devil's Den, on Friday I'm at the Devil's Den, on Saturday I'm at the Devil's Den.
周三，我在魔窟喝酒，周四，我在魔窟喝酒，周五，我在魔窟喝酒，周六，我在魔窟喝酒。
A skill book on Horsemanship. Can be read from level 5 of this skill.
一本关于马术的技能书。马术技能5级以上才能阅读。
A skill book on Horsemanship. Can be read from level 10 of this skill.
一本关于马术的技能书。马术技能10级以上才能阅读。

As the nomads from the east teach us, it is almost never necessary to dismount. You can even prepare yourself some good meat if you put it under the saddle and roast it by constant friction. Perhaps you'd better dismount before shitting though.
那些东方的游牧民族就从来都不下马，他们甚至把好肉放在马鞍下，通过摩擦就可以变成美味的烤肉。不过，要方便的时候最好还是下去吧……

Your horse will carry you to hell and back, but only if you take proper care of him. So don't forget to change his horseshoes for the winter, grease his saddle properly and supply him with some frost-resistant oats in a nosebag.
只有悉心照顾你的马，它才会随你一同出生入死。所以，冬天之前别忘了给它换马蹄铁，给马鞍上好油，并在它的鼻袋里放些防冻燕麦给他吃。

The cavalier is dangerous from the front, but the horse from behind. So if you don't want to end up kicked out of the corral, you have to be careful! That's probably why we have the saying: 'Come at me from the side!'
从正面突击而来的骑士固然危险，突然受惊、从身后袭来的马儿也不遑多让。如果你不想被踢出栅栏，就必须小心谨慎！这就是人们常说的“侧面对敌”的重要性了。
A skill book on Horse Riding.
一本关于马术的技能书。
A skill book on Horsemanship. Can be read from level 15 of this skill.
一本关于马术的技能书。马术技能15级以上才能阅读。

It may seem that horsemanship is a useless skill off the saddle, but even a foot soldier will appreciate your ability to care for other living creatures. Grooming will keep your hair shiny, and even in your love life, you'll soon learn the benefits of being able to mount well!
虽然看起来马术离开了马背就毫无用武之地，但如果你好好打理了你的坐骑，谁都会羡慕它的光鲜。我们都知道打理外表十分重要，而坐骑也正是其中一环。很快，你就能感受到会马术在恋爱关系中的威力了！
You think now that you can read and write, you're half-educated? Even though in the world of mathematics two halves are always the same size, you only know the smaller half!
你以为会读会写，就已经是半个文人了？虽然数学上两半总相等，但现实里，你所知的那一半也不过冰山一角！
一本关于学术的技能书。
I hope you won't sully the noble art of measuring, dividing and shaping space by drawing rude symbols all over the walls!
希望诸位能够理解，几何学是一门关于测量、分割和空间构造的神圣学问，在墙上乱涂乱画只是对它的亵渎！
A skill book on Scholarship. Can be read from level 5 of this skill.
一本关于学识的技能书。学识技能5级以上才能阅读。
Even something as beautiful, pure and soulful as music can be spoiled if you focus on mathematics instead of singing and playing the lute.
如果你专注于数学，而非奏乐高歌，即使是如音乐这般美丽、纯净和富有灵魂的事物也会失去魅力。
A skill book on Scholarship. Can be read from level 10 of this skill.
一本关于学术的技能书。学术技能10级以上才能阅读。
Starry skies above you and a wealth of knowledge within you.
群星悬于头顶，知识藏于心间。
A skill book on Scholarship. Can be read from level 15 of this skill.
一本关于学术的技能书。学术技能15级以上才能阅读。
For His works are without blemish and all His ways are judgment; God is trustworthy and is not evil; He is righteous and upright.
上帝定当享誉伟大之名，他信实公正、坦诚正直；其乃磐石，神举无可挑剔，所行之事皆为正义。
一本关于学术的技能书。
Listen, brothers and sisters, to what Peter Waldo taught us when he gave up his possessions to follow the teachings of Christ.
聆听吧，兄弟姐妹们，彼得·瓦尔多舍弃了一切财产以追随基督的教义，这也是对我们的教导。
一本关于学术的技能书。

If you are planning an army expedition, take a lesson from the greatest army commander of all time, Alexander the Great. The best counter to a warrior with a spear is a warrior with a slightly longer spear!
如果你正计划一次远征，不妨向史上最伟大的军事指挥官亚历山大大帝学习。对抗持矛战士的最佳策略就是配备更长的矛！
A skill book on Polearm combat. Can be read from level 10 of this skill.
一本关于长柄武器的技能书。长柄武器技能10级以上才能阅读。
Spears, glaves and halberds are the most popular weapons of every city's garrison, mainly because they are so easy to lean on when you want to take a nap while on guard duty.
长矛、长柄刀和戟是城市驻军中最受欢迎的武器，尤其是你执行任务期间困了的话，可以依靠着它们小睡一会。
A skill book on Polearm combat. Can be read from level 5 of this skill.
一本关于长柄武器的技能书。长柄武器技能5级以上才能阅读。
There are many guards, lunges and feints that can be used when fighting with polearms, but you only need to remember one rule to get you started: Stab with the pointy end!
用长柄武器战斗时，防御，冲刺与佯攻都有很多技巧，不过作为一个初学者，你只需要用尖的那头去刺就行了！
A skill book on Polearm combat.
一本关于长柄武器的技能书。

Warrior, remember there are many ways to hold your spear. With one or both hands, with the whole palm of your hand or even just with two fingers. Don't forget to also slowly slide your hands up and down the long and hard shaft…
战士，记住，持握长矛的方式有很多。单手或双手都是可行的，你还可以用整个掌心，甚至只用两个手指。别忘了，双手还要在长且坚硬的矛杆上缓慢上下滑动……
A skill book on Polearm combat. Can be read from level 15 of this skill.
一本关于长柄武器的技能书。长柄武器技能15级以上才能阅读。
A skill book on Speech. Can be read from level 10 of this skill.
关于口才的技能书。口才技能10级以上才能阅读。

Every conversation is in a way a battle of wisdom and sharp tongues. And, as in any other contest, it pays to fight impurely. Simplify, try to disable your opponent instead of refuting his arguments! And if that's not enough, start slandering his mother.
每一次对话都是智慧与言辞的较量，和任何竞争一样，使用不当手段往往能获得优势。比起反驳对手的论点，更应该简化问题，尝试削弱他！如果这还不够，就诽谤他的母亲。
《德摩斯梯尼艺术 · 第三章》
A skill book on Speech. Can be read from level 5 of this skill.
一本关于口才的技能书。口才技能5级以上才能阅读。
《德摩斯梯尼艺术 · 第二章》

Always speak such that you say just what you want to say and no more. Then keep quiet. For those who want to hear, be proud and say a few more words. But only a few! Let them be sated, but not stuffed.
谨言慎行，惜字如金。对于真正愿意倾听的人，不妨多说几句，但仅限几句！让他们仿佛醍醐灌顶，但不要过度。

Limber up for a nimble tongue, try not to twist it into a knot now. Try tongue twisters to train that tongue. For example: If a dog chews shoes, whose shoes does he choose? No need to light a night-light on a light night like tonight. He threw three free throws.
准备好你灵活的舌头，不要让它打结了！试试绕口令吧，比如：小狗挑鞋咬，鞋裹谁的脚？明明明夜明明灯，明灯明明夜更明。他一手抛出九颗球。
《德摩斯梯尼艺术 · 第一章》
一本关于口才的技能书。
《德摩斯梯尼艺术 · 第四章》

Many problems and even arguments can be avoided if you learn a few basic phrases and let their wisdom guide your life. Among the most important ones are: It wasn't me. It was already like this. Take over for me. It's better if a professional does it. No, I haven't been paid yet.
许多问题乃至争吵都是可以避免的，只要你学会应对的话术，并让其中的智慧引领你的生活。其中最重要的几句话是：不是我干的。本来就是这样的。帮我弄一下。还是让专业人士来做吧。不行，我还没拿到钱。
A skill book on Speech. Can be read from level 15 of this skill.
一本关于口才的技能书。口才技能15级以上才能阅读。
A skill book on Strength. Can be read from level 10 of this skill.
一本关于力量的技能书。力量技能10级以上才能阅读。

Everyone knows that a true knight is best toughened and his muscles strengthened by a tournament. Discipline is truly royal! But if perhaps even this exercise is too easy for you, try switching places with your horse and carry him on your back into battle.
众所周知，真正的骑士最擅长通过比武磨砺自己，精进技艺。纪律才是王者之道！不过如果你觉得这还是很轻松，不妨和你的马换下位置，由你来背着它战斗！
The Strength of the Knight III
The Strength of the Knight II

Proper strength is not hidden in the muscles, but in the stomach. So include plenty of quark, sauerkraut, meat and eggs in your diet. But don't eat it all at once, or you'll be running to the latrine instead of battle!
吃不好的话，再强的肌肉也使不上力。所以你的饮食里应该包括大量的农家干酪、酸菜、肉类和鸡蛋。但不要一次吃太多，否则你上的就不是战场，而是茅坑了！
A skill book on Strength. Can be read from level 5 of this skill.
一本关于力量的技能书。力量技能5级以上才能阅读。
The Strength of the Knight I
Next time you get into a duel, try doing a squat every time you swing your sword. Not only will you get a good workout, but with a bit of luck, you'll avoid a blow that would cut your head off!
下次参与决斗时，你可以试着出剑之后就立刻蹲下。这样不仅能锻炼身体，运气好的话还能避免被砍头！
一本关于力量的技能书。
The Strength of the Knight IV

A knight's fitness is best increased by running. After all, leg strength is often more important than arm strength, especially if you often retreat. We can therefore recommend running over difficult terrain. The muddy fields near Sudomer are suitable.
提升骑士体能的最佳方式是奔跑。毕竟，尤其是在需要撤退时，腿部的力量往往比手臂力量更为重要。因此，我们推荐在复杂地形上进行跑步训练。比如，苏多梅尔附近的泥泞田野就非常适合此类训练。
A skill book on Strength. Can be read from level 15 of this skill.
一本关于力量的技能书。力量技能15级以上才能阅读。

Third day alone in the wilderness. I've got something to drink and a place to sleep, but I'm getting hungry. If I'm lucky, I can set a rabbit trap, find some mushrooms or some roots. But if it's not soon, I'll eat this book!
在荒野中独自度过的第三天。现在我有水喝，有地方睡，但有些饿了。我可以设一个兔子陷阱，运气好的话能抓到兔子，或是至少找一些蘑菇或根茎。但如果全都找不到，我就把这本东西吃了！
A skill book on Survival in the wilderness. Can be read from level 10 of this skill.
一本关于野外生存的技能书。野外生存技能10级以上才能阅读。

Second day alone in the wilderness. I've quenched my thirst, now I have to find shelter. A rock overhang, a hut made of branches, or even a hastily dug earthlodge will do. The caves may look inviting, but it often happens that a bear quietly snuggles up to you at night.
在荒野中独自度过的第二天。我已经解渴了，现在我得找一个地方避风。突出的岩石背面，用树枝搭一个小屋，或者挖一个土屋出来都可以。野生洞穴看起来诱人，不过半夜醒来或许会和熊对上视线，还是算了。
A skill book on Survival in the wilderness. Can be read from level 5 of this skill.
一本关于野外生存的技能书。野外生存技能5级以上才能阅读。
A skill book on Survival in the wilderness.
一本关于野外生存的技能书。

First day alone in the wilderness. First things first, I gotta get something to quench my thirst. A spring or some stream of running water would be best, as stagnant water can be spoiled. But in a pinch, you can even drink urine. I'd rather have my own than someone else's.
在荒野中独自度过的第一天。我得先找点东西解渴，最好是泉水或是溪水，死水会变质。不过真到紧要关头，尿也是能喝的。不过我只喝自己的，别人的不行。
A skill book on Survival in the wilderness. Can be read from level 15 of this skill.
一本关于野外生存的技能书。野外生存技能15级以上才能阅读。
Fourth day alone in the wilderness. That should be enough. I'm sure by now my parents, God rest them, understand how sad they'd be to lose me!
在荒野中独自度过的第四天。这样应该够了。我的父母此刻一定已经感受到，没有我他们是多么伤心！
Remember the story about the woman and her ten coins? How happy she was when she found the one lost coin? How happy will she be when all her money gets lost?
还记得女人与十枚银币的故事吗？她找回丢的那枚银币的时候是那么开心，但如果所有的钱都丢了，她还笑得出来吗？
The Rule of St. Dismas III
《圣迪斯马斯教规 · 第三章》
A skill book on Thievery. Can be read from level 10 of this skill.
一本关于偷窃的技能书。偷窃技能10级以上才能阅读。
A skill book on Thievery. Can be read from level 5 of this skill.
一本关于偷窃的技能书。偷窃技能5级以上才能阅读。
The way to God is not through earthly possessions, but through humility and renunciation. So, in fact, every groschen you steal helps someone to heaven!
通往天国的道途并非依赖世俗财富的累积，而是在于谦卑和放弃。所以，你偷的每一分钱其实都是在帮助失主接近天堂！
The Rule of St. Dismas II
《圣迪斯马斯教规 · 第二章》
The Rule of St. Dismas I
《圣迪斯马斯教规 · 第一章》

Remember, wicked man, to honour Saint Dismas, for he is your patron saint, who hung at the right hand of the Lord on the cross. In death he became a good villain, though in life he was a damn good villain!
恶人，你须铭记，你应当尊敬圣迪斯马斯，因为他是你的守护神，他在十字架上安息于主的右侧。这家伙在死后被敬奉成了好的恶棍，可在他生前，可是什么好事都做过！
一本关于偷窃的技能书。
The Rule of St. Dismas IV
《圣迪斯马斯教规 · 第四章》
A skill book on Thievery. Can be read from level 15 of this skill.
一本关于偷窃的技能书。偷窃技能15级以上才能阅读。
Good sinner on the right, fill my coffers tight. Steal thy neighbour's silver, it spoils his character!
好罪人，站右边；把钱箱，填满满。若盗取，邻居银；当败坏，他人品。
A skill book on Vitality. Can be read from level 10 of this skill.
一本关于活力的技能书。活力技能10级以上才能阅读。
Wow, it's harder than I thought... But I can do it!
唔，这比我想象得要难……但我能做到的！
A skill book on Vitality. Can be read from level 5 of this skill.
一本关于活力的技能书。活力技能5级以上才能阅读。
一本关于活力的技能书。
I can do this! I've been practicing! I've got it!
我一定能行！历经苦练，我已经掌握了诀窍！
A skill book on Vitality. Can be read from level 15 of this skill.
一本关于活力的技能书。活力技能15级以上才能阅读。

<paragraph>At that time a plague was raging in the city and in the surrounding area, which was mowing people down by the hundreds. But the rich, convinced that their earthly power would protect them from the punishment of God, made nothing of the disease, and spent their days and nights in drinking, during which they overfed, fornicated, and committed other sins in abundance. But the fact that they did not care about the death of everyone around them did not mean that death did not care about them.</paragraph>
<paragraph>在那时，城市及其周边地区正爆发瘟疫，每天都有数百人的生命被夺走。但富人们相信他们的世俗权力会保护他们免受上帝的惩罚，对瘟疫充耳不闻，日夜饮酒作乐。他们酗酒、暴饮暴食、淫乱无度，并犯下其他许多罪行，然而，他们不在乎周边人的死亡，并不代表死亡会对他们视而不见。</paragraph>
讲述了犯下暴食之罪的人遭受天罚的故事。

<paragraph><accent>Their bodies, together with all the costly clothing and valuables they had brought to the feast, were taken to the cemetery in Sedletz. They were buried there in the northernmost corner in a mass grave. The place is still marked by a stone circle and a large cross with a wreath of flowers.</accent></paragraph>
<paragraph><accent>他们的尸体，连同他们带到宴会上的所有奢华衣物和金银财宝，都一起被运到了塞德莱茨的墓地。他们被埋葬在最北边的一个乱葬坑里。那个地方至今仍有一个石圈和一个带花环的十字架标记。</accent></paragraph>

<paragraph><inc>T</inc>hough it may seem otherwise at times, our Lord is equally gracious to all men, and exalts none above another. The rich men of Kuttenberg were convinced of this truth when, in the second year of the reign of King Charles, they held sinful feasts in the town hall until God himself stopped them.</paragraph>
<paragraph><inc>虽</inc>然有时看起来并非如此，但我们的主对所有人一视同仁，并没有谁比其他人更高贵。查理国王登基第二年时，库滕堡的富人们就并不相信这一真理，他们在市政厅日夜欢淫，而最终遭到了主的神罚。</paragraph>

<paragraph>No wonder, therefore, that at one of those unclean feasts a deadly contagion broke out, which would surely have swept the whole city, had not the zealous guards, who locked the drunken lords and ladies in the feast hall, protected the others. And in vain did the rich beat at the door, and begged for mercy with entreaties and threats. It took three weeks for the Lord to put an end to their suffering.</paragraph>
<paragraph>报应终将降临在他们头上，因此，在其中一次不洁的宴会上，致命的传染病开始爆发。要不是热心的卫兵们快速反应过来，将醉酒的大人们和夫人们锁在了宴会厅内，瘟疫肯定会席卷到整个城市。这些罪恶的富人绝望地敲打着门，苦苦哀求，威胁恐吓，但一切都无济于事。上帝用三周的时间作为惩罚，才最终结束了他们的痛苦。</paragraph>

Underneath the oak tree in the tavern on the square
a whistle and a lute ring out, and drums boom out their share.
From far and wide, from all around,
folk come to dance to the merry sound.

The whistle is whistling, the lute ringing out,
folk are all dancing, the thin and the stout.
And while the drum is loudly booming,
among the dancers, love starts blooming.

在那广场橡树下，酒馆生意忙，
那里琴声可绕梁，鼓声亦响亮。
那里音律时起伏，悠扬又高昂，
四方来客皆来此，起舞乐洋洋。

哨声唱罢笛声响，
胖瘦皆捧场。
鼓声正到最酣时，
爱情花绽放。

In the fields by the woods a shepherd boy plays
on his pipe as his sheep quietly graze.
But now he has gone to fight for his king,
away in a far distant place.

His flock is long scattered with no one to lead them,
he plays now to soldiers instead.
To return to his pasture was his only dream,
But in Crécy now he lies dead.

树林旁，欢快牧童笛声起，
草地上，悠悠绵羊把草食。
国王召，牧童持剑踏征程，
奔沙场，千里迢迢离家去。

牧童去，绵羊四散如星辰。
笛声复，只见战友未见羊。
思家梦，昔日草原映眼帘，
魂归乡，克雷西战牧童殇。

My whistle carved from willow,
Ah, it's such a fine thing.
On it my sweetheart loves to blow,
lying down or standing.
Ey ey ey - lying down or standing!

She blows and then she blows again,
my little whistle goes hard,
my darling jumps for joy then.
She says I am her bard.
Ey ey ey - she says I am her bard!

我有一个小柳笛，
它可真是好东西。
老婆把它来吹奏，
不论躺下或站起。
哎~哎~哎~不论躺下或站起！

老婆小嘴吹呀吹，
小小柳笛就雄起。
骑在上面多欢愉，
老婆夸我真给力！
哎~哎~哎~老婆夸我真给力！

A vineyard in the town? Strange, but who knows!
And yet there it is, quite nearby.
By the water that gushes, now listen and try
to keep your eyes open, so that you can tell
shortly after the midday bell,
you'll find us where the shadow goes.

葡萄园，居镇中？岂谓无可能！
尚且有一处，须臾间可及。
潺潺流水过，聆听寻此声。
瞪眼观六路，竖耳听八方。
午时稍稍过，阴影指明路。
随其往而行，彼处寻我等。
A piece of paper carried by Hynek the 'Greaser', a former thief.
有小偷前科的“格雷泽”海尼克随身携带的信。

Keeping gold at home
is surely not the wisest,
a thief may find it even if
you locked it in a nice chest.

金子藏在家，
主意可真差，
箱子再结实
，也能打开它。

When you want to sleep and there’s no bed,
no place your head to lay,
go behind the house, and there,
you cansleep upon the hay.

无枕头难安，
无床夜难眠，
屋后檐下处，
草上可安眠。

With loot in your pockets,
you can't go to market.
Best find a buyer,
who's willing to take it.

口袋里有货，
就去市场逛。
找个好买家，
大功便告成。

‘Tis customary for rooms in houses
to be joined by a corridor.
In the cellars underground,
a tunnel leads from door to door.

房室千万间
走廊皆相连。
地窖幽深处
隧道衔门间。

Get out of here, you foolish fellow!
Hereabouts no loot you'll find!!
Have you no fear of the gallows? Hear my warning,.
if you've got a mind!

滚出去，大蠢货！
金银财宝这儿没有！
绞架高高悬半空，听我劝，
赶紧走！

There is only one divine creature in the whole world that could serve as a model of stealth, and that is the cat. If you study its movements properly, you too will one day be able to steal a piece of meat quietly from the plate and eat it in the woodshed.
在潜行这件事上，世上的唯一典范就是猫，它们真是一种神圣的生物！如果你仔细研究猫咪的动作，总有一天你也能在无人察觉时顺走盘子里的肉，然后拿去柴棚吃掉。
As Quiet as a Cat I
一本关于潜行的技能书。
Like the cat lurking behind the door, you will also be invisible to human eyes if you stop in mid-motion and just look innocent.
就像藏在门后的猫咪一样，如果你停下动作，保持无辜的样子，人们也会忽视掉你。
A skill book on Stealth. Can be read from level 5 of this skill.
一本关于潜行的技能书。潜行技能5级以上才能阅读。
As Quiet as a Cat II

Even the best thief sometimes fails and is caught during his craft. In these cases, however, you can charm the annoyed guards with cat cuteness or even an innocent look. But be careful not to spit coughing hair on them!
最老练的窃贼也会有被抓个正着的时候。这时你可以装作猫咪，用可爱和无辜的眼神迷惑恼怒的守卫！但注意，千万别把毛球吐他们身上！
As Quiet as a Cat III
A skill book on Stealth. Can be read from level 10 of this skill.
一本关于潜行的技能书。潜行技能10级以上才能阅读。

Sneaking alone is actually useless, unless you can also jump out of cover and attack unsuspecting prey silently. And it doesn't matter if your target is a castle guard, a mouse in a barn, or a dropped shoe.
光会掩人耳目是没有作用的，离开掩体悄无声息发起攻击的那一瞬间才会见真章。不管你的目标是城堡卫兵，谷仓里的老鼠，或者只是掉下去的鞋子，都是一样的道理。
As Quiet as a Cat IV
A skill book on Stealth. Can be read from level 15 of this skill.
一本关于潜行的技能书。潜行技能15级以上才能阅读。
The best defence is offence, so if you want to survive a fight, you have to hit your opponent before he hits you. Who'd have thought?
进攻就是最好的防守。如果你想在战斗中幸存下来，只要在对手打到你之前打到他就行了。没想到吧？
A skill book on Sword combat.
一本关于击剑的技能书。
The Art of the Sword I

You can attack your enemy head-on like a donkey and hope to hit him, but it would be far wiser to wait for him to attack you. Provoke him! Feel free to accompany your attack with a few peppery curses.
虽然你可以像驴子一样向对手正面冲击，但等待对方攻击你时露出破绽会更明智一些。时刻记得激怒对手！在挥剑时，可以随口骂他两句。
A skill book on Sword combat. Can be read from level 5 of this skill.
一本关于剑术的技能书。剑术5级时可以阅读。
The Art of the Sword II
I'll let you in on a secret. You can come out of any fight unscathed, even if you're up against the most skilled swordsman, if you surrender before the fight starts.
我会偷偷教你一招。这个小技巧能让你即便是面对身手不凡的最强剑客，也能从一切战斗中安然脱身。其实你只需要在战斗开始前投降，就可以保证毫发无伤了。
A skill book on Sword combat. Can be read from level 10 of this skill.
一本关于剑术的技能书。剑术10级时可以阅读。
The Art of the Sword III
Charge them! Hammer them! Kill them! Spare no one!
撕碎他们！打烂他们！屠杀他们！一个也别放过！
A skill book on Sword combat. Can be read from level 15 of this skill.
一本关于剑术的技能书。剑术15级时可以阅读。
The Art of the Sword IV
<paragraph>The knight's service is rewarded with food and water, delivered every month to the shaft by the locals. So undertakes the parish priest Richard from Old Kutna.</paragraph>
<paragraph>地狱之坑的守护者以食物和水为报酬，每月由当地居民送到矿井。这一事务由由旧库特纳的教区牧师理查德承担。</paragraph>

<paragraph>The honourable Sir Taras Mura swears a knight's oath to guard the pit of hell in the mines of Old Kutna and not to leave the mines while his service lasts.</paragraph><paragraph>The oath will only be rescinded by another knight who will shoulder the burden of repentance and arrive at the mines and become a new guard by his own oath.</paragraph><paragraph>Such a knight will then, under the same conditions, be the new guard of hell, and the previous guardian will again see heaven and the love of God, and all his sins will be forgiven in the sight of the Lord.</paragraph>

<paragraph>尊敬的塔拉斯·穆拉勋爵以骑士的名义宣誓，他将守卫旧库特纳矿山的地狱之坑，在服役期间绝不离开矿井。</paragraph><paragraph>这份誓言只有当另一位骑士愿接过其忏悔的重担，在矿山立下新誓言时，方能解除。</paragraph><paragraph>那位骑士将在同等条件下成为地狱之坑新的守护者，而前一任守卫则终得再次面见天堂，迎接上帝之爱，他的所有罪过都将在主的面前得到宽恕。</paragraph>
The oath is sealed by the humble servant of God, Father Richard, and Knight Taras Mura, the first guardian of the pit of hell.
这份誓言由上帝的谦卑仆人理查德和骑士塔拉斯·穆拉，地狱之坑的第一守卫，共同见证。

I, Taras Mura, a servant of God, bound by covenant, guard the pit of hell in the mines of Old Kutna. In the endless darkness, let this record serve me as a proof of the days spent here in the service of God.
我，塔拉斯·穆拉，上帝之仆，为践行约定，守护旧库特纳矿山的地狱之坑。在无尽的黑暗中，谨以此记录作为我在此处服侍上帝之证明。

<paragraph>I'm cold. I had to dismantle some of the scaffolding to get firewood.</paragraph><paragraph>It's always cold in the mines, but there's a freezing draft coming from the shaft where I get my food now. Soon the first snow will come since I descended into the mines. My ministry shouldn't last much longer.</paragraph><paragraph>I have armed the passages of the pit with crosses and God is with me. The stench pouring from the pit leaves no doubt of the presence of hell.</paragraph><newpage><paragraph>I remain your humble servant, Lord, and beg for mercy for my sins.</paragraph><paragraph>I, Taras Mura, am the shield of God.</paragraph>

<paragraph>我很冷。我不得不拆下一些脚手架用来点火取暖。</paragraph><paragraph>矿井里总是很冷，但今天从我取食物的井口吹进来的寒风尤其刺骨。我很快就要迎来下井后的第一场雪，我的服役期应当也快要过去了。</paragraph><paragraph>我在坑道设置了十字架，上帝与我同在。地狱之坑中传来了地狱的恶臭，但我不会屈服。</paragraph><newpage><paragraph>主呀，我依然是您谦卑的仆人，请宽恕我的罪孽。</paragraph><paragraph>我，塔拉斯·穆拉，乃是上帝之盾。</paragraph>

I can't sleep. The inferno attacks whenever I close my eyes.A childbearing woman clothed in the sun, her fetus eaten by dragons. Fire and blood is in the walls. Voices all around. They reproach me with their death.I killed them all and then descended into darkness. The snow blows again in the shafts. I can't sleep. The devil is coming and behind him is Death.
我无法入睡。每当我闭上眼，炼狱的景象便侵袭我的精神。我看到阳光下有一位孕妇，胎儿被恶龙吞噬，我看到墙上尽是火与血，恶毒的话语环绕着我，责备我应为他们的死付出代价。我杀了他们，然后眼前只剩下黑暗。风雪飘进矿井，我无法入睡，恶魔向我走来，死亡紧随其后……

In the darkness I hear weeping and gnashing of teeth. I can't hold them in much longer. The voices of demons scratch at my soul like swords at my helmet.I can't take off my armour. I am never safe. Lord, protect me! They're everywhere. I can smell their burnt flesh again. I don't want to become one of them. The demons of hell are always calling my name. It sounds like the trumpet of the Last Judgment.
黑暗中，我听到了哀哭与切齿，我很快便将无法抑制它们了。恶魔的声音像剑刃一般刮擦我的头盔，直刺我的灵魂。我不敢脱下盔甲，我还处在危险之中。主啊，求您佑护！它们无处不在，我又闻到了它们烧焦的肉味，我不想成为它们的一员！地狱的恶魔总在呼唤我的名字，尖啸如末日审判的号角。

2) Keg and a half - Kolin
- the wagoner didn't have a covered wagon and it rained on it! (pay only Hälfte)

（2）一小桶半科林
车夫的车子没有顶篷，下雨淋湿了！（仅用Hälfte支付）
That Arschloch Whisker wants to carry the gunpowder to the camp himself! He wishes! Soon they'll be busy in Bohunowitz as in Kuttenberg…
Arschloch（混蛋）威斯克尔还想亲自把火药运到营地里！他想得美！博胡诺维茨也要像库滕堡一样乱起来了……
The greatest treasure are the friends we have made along the way.
最大的财富是我们一路上结交的朋友。
He who finds a friend finds a treasure. Usually in his pocket...
找到朋友的人就能找到宝藏。因为宝藏通常就在朋友们的兜里……
It leads a man to what he most desires. That is, if he most desires treasure…
它引导人们到达他们最渴望的地方，如果他们渴望的是宝藏的话......
Heplful to a person in material need. And in a time of supreme need, it can be used to wipe one's arse too.
对于想发大财的人可能有用，但紧急时候拿来擦屁股效果更佳。

A capite ad calcem – we celebrate Brada to the helm.
Gloria in excelsis deo – for we esteem him so.
Consumbstantialem Patri – He belongs with us, truly!
In nomine domini – our bailiff one and only.
Qui locutus est per Prophetas – he won't leave us to the brigands' grasp.
Kyrie Eleison – he can handle all on his own!
Et apostolicam Ecclesiam – he is always fair to us, this man.
Dominus Deus Sabaoth – he is full of wisdom and growth.
Benedicimus te – and how learned he can be!
Et vitam venturi saeculi – he ensures we live happily.

A capite ad calcem - 我们为布拉达高声欢呼，
>Gloria in excelsis deo - 我们在心底将他尊崇。
Consumbstantialem Patri - 他是我们之中的一员，
>In nomine domini - 又是我们之中的唯一。
Qui locutus est per Prophetas - 他不仅让我们战胜强敌，
Kyrie Eleison - 他还能解决所有问题！
Et apostolicam Ecclesiam - 他就是我们心中的正义。
Dominus Deus Sabaoth - 他有如此多的妙计，
Benedicimus te - 他的睿智无人能及！
Et vitam venturi saeculi - 他在这里，幸福就也在这里。

<heading>Zdena under the Root</heading><paragraph>The summer of the year thirteen hundred and twenty-seven was eventful. Quam gravis aestas erat - it seems impossible to write it all down here. Fear then sank its claws especially into old Zdena, who has a cottage near the forest. Per unam noctem in mense Iulio - listen to all that has happened. Zdena went into the woods, but in the darkness she went astray, fell down the hill and remained wedged in the roots of a tree. Half the village went to look for the poor woman, but the root prisoner herself could not answer their call to Zdena. Timor illam vocem subripuit - it was not until the morning that the woman was freed.</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>树根下的兹德娜</heading><paragraph>一三二七年的夏天发生了许多事情。Quam gravis aestas erat——几乎不可能在这里全部记录下来。老兹德娜居住在森林小屋里，恐惧深深地扎根在她的心中。Per unam noctem in mense Iulio——在那个夜里，兹德娜走进森林，在黑暗中迷了路。她跌下山坡，卡在一棵树的树根处。半个村子的人都上了山，寻找这位可怜的女人，但树根缠绕下的兹德娜无法回应他们的呼喊。Timor illam vocem subripuit——直到次日清晨，可怜的老妇人才被解救出来。</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>Guests of the lord of Trosky</heading><paragraph>The lord of Trosky often organizes great dances and invites important guests from all around. These events might not be of interest to our people if the Chamberlain of Trosecky did not take advantage of the situation. O tanta aviditas in corde suo - Conrad is the name of a bad servant. He often lures his master's guests out of the castle to show them the surroundings, and on that occasion he extorts small gifts from the noble lords. Among other places, he leads the lords to a strange alley to show them the bloody tree and the tree of the hanged man and to amuse them with bloody stories. Conradus non est nostrum - only our rowan tree does not show the guests.</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>特罗斯基领主的客人们</heading><paragraph>特罗斯基的领主经常举办盛大的舞会，邀请各地的贵客。这本来与我们毫不相干，但特罗斯基的管家却利用特罗斯科维茨的故事为他谋取私利。O tanta aviditas in corde suo——这个坏仆人名为康拉德，他经常把他主人的客人引出城堡，在周围参观，并借机向那些贵客索取小费。他带着贵族们走入阴暗的小巷，给他们讲述流血的树和上吊之人的血腥故事，以此来取悦他们。Conradus non est nostrum——而关于我们的好话，他半句也不会说。</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>A great recounting of the soil</heading><paragraph>The lord of the Troshechi gave orders to measure the soil in the spring, to increase the quantity of grain brought to him. Dominus noster justus est - he shall take six sacks of wheat. And after the fields had been measured, the young men were brought to the proper places where the manor's grain was, that they might receive a good cutting, and so remember their place until death. Verberas magnus erat - let us know these boys. Janek from the inn, Karel from the pigs, Ales from the carpenter's, Martin from Tachov, Simon from Hoňsobě, Petr the whistle, Matěj the curly-haired, and Olbram from Želejov, with whom, however, there is constant trouble, for he remembers his place badly even after repeated beatings!</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>土地大普查</heading><paragraph>特罗斯赫奇领主下令在春天测量土地，以期增加农民上缴的粮食数量。Dominus noster justus est——他今年将得到六袋小麦。田地测量完毕，年轻人们便被带到庄园的粮仓，接受适当的粮食分配，并终生铭记自己的职责。Verberas magnus erat——我们看看都有谁：客栈的雅内克，养猪场的卡雷尔，木匠阿莱斯，塔霍夫的马丁，霍尼索贝的西蒙，吹口哨的彼得，卷发的马捷伊，还有哲勒约夫的奥尔布拉姆，不过这家伙经常惹麻烦，就算挨上几顿鞭子，也还是记不住自己的位置！</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>The tree that bled</heading><paragraph>Troskovice witnessed terrible events when Brenek and Michal, two local shepherds, decided to cut down a tree in the meadow above Vidlak. Non fuit bona idea - half the village is angry with them now. The tree they chose to cut down is known for attracting lightning from far and wide to protect the good people, but it endangers the cattle in the pasture. Arbor inchoata cruentatur - Michael first struck the trunk with the axe. But no sooner had he raised the instrument to cut again, than red blood began to gush from the wound. The horrible phenomenon so frightened both men that they threw down their axes and fled home. The parish priest, who was summoned to the scene, did not declare the tree miraculous, but the locals know their own and believe that the tree will not allow evil things to happen to it or in its vicinity.</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>流血之树</heading><paragraph>特罗斯科维茨发生了一起可怕的怪事，两位牧羊人布雷内克和米哈尔决定砍伐维德拉克池塘旁的一棵树。Non fuit bona idea——半个村子的人都很不满，因为这棵树能吸走远近的闪电，保护好人免于雷击。但它吸来的闪电也确实威胁到了附近牧场的牲畜。Arbor inchoata cruentatur——米哈尔先用斧头砍伤了树干，但当他举起斧头，准备再次砍下时，红色的血液从树干上的伤口中喷涌而出。两位牧羊人被恐怖的景象吓坏了，扔下斧头，逃回了家。后来，一位教区牧师来此验证，但他并未宣布这棵树引发了奇迹。不过，当地人依然相信，这棵神树会阻止其周边的一切邪恶。</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>Margaret's Lovers</heading><paragraph>It is not for a decent man to judge another's love, but the circle of Margaret's lovers is already asking to be noticed. Illa femina multum viros amat - the brothers Martin and John had time to ask her. The woman, however, did not want to return the love of the brothers and chose another man for herself, thus causing immense grief to the brothers. Pax animae Johannis - John, in his distress, threw himself off the rock! The body of John, unrequited by love, lay under the rock between Troskovice and Tachov, and was buried outside the holy ground. Tristis erat frater eis - Martin then went to meet the world. The brother of the deceased left our country after a great mourning and is said to have become a member of a knightly order in foreign lands.</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>玛格丽特的情人们</heading><paragraph>作为一个正人君子，我本不该评判他人的爱情，但玛格丽特的交际圈广为人知。Illa femina multum viros amat——玛格丽特吸引了许多男人的爱慕，包括马丁和约翰两兄弟。但最后，对兄弟俩的爱慕，她并未给予任何回报，而是选择了另外一个男人，这给两兄弟带来了莫大的痛苦。Pax animae Johannis——爱而不得的约翰甚至从岩石上跳了下去！他的遗体就躺在特罗斯科维茨和塔霍夫之间的岩石下，被埋葬在未祝圣的土地上。Tristis erat frater eis——马丁则是在巨大的悲痛中离开了家乡，失去了兄弟的他沉浸在哀痛之中，不过据说他在多年之后走出了悲伤，加入了一个外国的骑士团。</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>Francek Bezočka</heading><paragraph>The young rooter, who settled in Apolena, had to come again among the honest people, because Francek, who was herding cattle on a farm, got into a cross with a bull. Taurus eum invasit - the bull can break his ouds. When the animal, enraged, rushed at the poor man, he wanted to hide in the crown of the miraculous tree, so that the tree, which does not allow evil, would protect him from the beast. But Francek, in his confusion, mistook the trees, and climbed up the oak instead of the miraculous tree. Magnum clamorem audivimus - then the real abomination happened! The bull knocked Francek down from the oak with one blow, his body was torn to pieces, and even his eye was gouged out with his horn. Although the oak is certainly not a miraculous tree, it brought Francek good luck, for he did not lose his life and returned to work after eight Sundays.</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>弗朗切克·贝佐卡</heading><paragraph>定居在阿波莱娜的年轻赶牛人弗朗切克不得不返回镇上，因为他在农场放牧时，惹火了一头公牛。Taurus eum invasit——公牛的力道足够打断他的肋骨。当这头愤怒的动物向可怜的弗朗切克发起冲锋，弗朗切克夺路而逃，试图躲进那神树的树冠中，他希望这棵断绝邪恶之树能保护他免受野兽的伤害。但弗朗切克慌不择路间，爬上的是另一棵橡树。Magnum clamorem audivimus——于是悲剧发生了！公牛一击就把弗朗切克从橡树上击落，撕裂了他的身体，甚至戳瞎了他的一只眼睛！不过，虽然他爬上的不是神树，这棵橡树也给他带来了好运，至少他没有丢掉性命。在八个星期的治疗和恢复后，弗朗切克重新回到了工作岗位上。</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>Spring in Troskovice</heading><paragraph>Like every spring, the most gracious and wise swift man, who is invited by Brada, inspected the fields and the living creatures and made this record. Sicut lex iubet villico - let us begin with the cattle for milk. There are fewer cows but more oxen in Troskovice this year. We have nice and big goats and plenty of sows too. Thanks to the cottagers Tomáš and Šimek, we have the two biggest bulls in the whole region. Nunc de terra fama - let's count the ground under our feet. The fields are still in the same management, even the land above the inn has not changed its lord, because the wedding of Anča and Vasek was ruined when the father of the bride, in his drunkenness, called Vasek a fool who had sex with sheep.</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>特罗斯科维茨之春</heading><paragraph>正如每个春天一样，那位最仁慈、最睿智、最敏捷的人应“红胡子”皇帝之邀，检查田地和牲畜，并做出了这份记录。Sicut lex iubet villico——让我们从牛开始吧，今年特罗斯科维茨的奶牛减少了，但公牛增多了。我们还有又壮又健康的山羊，还有很多母猪。感谢农夫托马斯和希梅克，让我们拥有了这片大地上最壮硕的两头公牛。Nunc de terra fama——让我们细数脚下的土地。田地的管理依然如旧，甚至旅馆的土地也没有更换主人，因为在安查和瓦赛克的婚礼上，新娘的父亲酒后失言，称呼瓦赛克为和羊交配的傻瓜，结果把整个婚礼毁掉了。</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>Vashek Hanged</heading><paragraph>Death has shrouded our land with a dark cloud, for Vashek, the shepherd, was found hanged. O mors est atrox et inutilis - all Troskovice mourned for him. Vashek, who had spent his life alone, and perhaps only loved Anca from the tavern, was buried outside the holy ground, for he had taken his own life. Today, the shepherds have returned to the fatal meadow, but the hanged man's tree continues to be circumvented. We can only give thanks to Vashek for not choosing the tree commemorating the famous battle for his heinous act, although he committed it in its vicinity. He could not have harmed the reputation and weight of the precious tree in any way.</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>瓦谢克之死</heading><paragraph>死亡笼罩了我们的土地，牧羊人瓦谢克吊死在了一棵树上。O mors est atrox et inutilis——整个特罗斯科维茨都为他哀悼。瓦谢克一生独居，或许只爱过酒馆的安卡。因为是自杀，所以他的尸体被安葬在未受祝圣的土地上。今天，牧羊人们返回了那片被死亡笼罩的草地，并绕过了瓦谢克上吊的那棵树。我们感谢瓦谢克没有选择在那棵纪念著名战役的树上实施他的罪行，尽管他是在附近自杀的，但这也避免了损害那棵树宝贵的声誉。</paragraph><newpage/>
<title>Troskovice Chronicle</title><subtitle>as laid down by Bailiff Brada</subtitle><newpage/>
<title>《特罗斯科维茨编年史》</title><subtitle>执行官布拉达著</subtitle><newpage/>
<poem><accent>And if people knew just one thing about him truly – Fecit ordinem in regione ope clavi ferrei</accent></poem>
<poem><accent>若你不知他是何人—— Fecit ordinem in regione ope clavi ferrei</accent></poem>

<heading>About the Avenue of the Strange</heading><paragraph>God has breathed many beautiful places into our region, to make it fit for human life. Deus dedit nobis terram perfectam - Of one place I will now tell you. On a hill near the pond of Vidlák, there is an avenue of strange trees, consisting of oaks, rowan trees and birches. Quercus, Sorbus, Betula - under one a battle was fought. Raubritter Albrecht and his band are said to have been defeated here a hundred years ago, and the tree adorns the site of his death. The other tree is of simpler origin and reminds us of the border between the lands of Tachov and Želejov. Optima ad finem - let us also speak of another tree. The third of the trees provides protection from the storm, for it attracts lightning from all around. There are hundreds of similar places in this region, but next time we will tell about them, so as not to shame other countries.</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>关于“奇树大道”</heading><paragraph>神赐予我们众多美丽的土地，让人类得以在上面居住。Deus dedit nobis terram perfectam ——接下来我要讲述的，就是其中一个地方。在维德拉克池塘附近的小山上，有一条“奇树大道”，周围生长着橡树、槐树和桦树。Quercus, Sorbus, Betula ——其中一棵树见证了一场血战，据说一百年前，强盗骑士阿尔布雷希特和他的爪牙正是在此地被击败，而这棵树也是他戎马一生的终点。另一棵树的起源则较为简单，它提醒人们此地乃塔霍夫和哲勒约夫的边界。Optima ad finem ——第三棵树则大不相同，它为人们提供了避雷的加护，因为它能吸引周围的闪电。这片大地上还有数以百计的神奇去处，但我们留到下次再讲，以免其他国家自惭形秽。</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>The Brothers of the Commonwealth</heading><paragraph>Aleš and Míka, sons of the carpenter Marek, who had fallen down in age last winter, certainly did not take after their father. Ever since their uncle Josef came from Mladějov to take over their upbringing, both of them began to shun people, and various rumours began to circulate among the good people of Troskovice about how the brothers were always gloomy and did not like to stay alone with their uncle. Res etiam graviores malae factae sunt - then the brothers left their native land. But uncle Joseph forbade the brothers to look for them, and began to tell various stories about their idleness. Ambo fratres magna peccata habebant - they were said to have wanted to have devilish intercourse with their uncle. Joseph took the cottage as his own, but he still cannot manage the land formerly belonging to his brothers. For it was the younger Ales who had their borders in mind, for he had once been cut on them. This story should therefore be a warning to future generations that a new way of marking boundaries must be created.</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>公国的兄弟</heading><paragraph>木匠马雷克有两个儿子，阿莱斯和米卡。自马雷克于冬季去世，两兄弟的叔叔约瑟夫从姆拉杰约夫过来抚养他们，他们俩就像变了个人一样，开始避开人群。特罗斯科维茨的人们也觉得他们过分阴郁，似乎不喜欢和他们的叔叔待在一起。随着时间的推移，各种各样的谣言愈发恶劣，最终两兄弟也因此离开了故乡。但约瑟夫叔叔不允许任何人去寻找他们，还散播出种种他们十分懒惰的故事，最后甚至流传成了他们打算与叔叔乱伦。后来，约瑟夫把他们的房子据为己有，但他却无法管理他们以前的土地，因为只有在土地边界受过伤的阿莱斯才知道这些边界具体的位置。这个故事警示着后世，或许人们需要一种更明确的新方法来标记边界，防止混乱场面的出现。</paragraph><newpage/>
The history of Troskowitz, written down by the famous Bailiff Brada.
由著名执行官布拉达写下的特罗斯科维茨历史。
After an unlucky throw, you can throw again. Can be used three times per game.
如果出目不满意，你可以重骰。每局游戏可使用3次。
After an unlucky throw, use this badge to throw again. Can be used once per game.
如果出目不满意，你可以使用该徽章进行重骰。每局游戏可使用1次。
When a throw doesn't go your way, use this badge to throw again. Can be used twice per game.
若某次掷骰的结果未能如愿，使用此徽章可进行重新掷骰，每局游戏可使用两次。
The badge of the rightful king of the birds will allow you to roll an additional die. Can be used twice per game.
正统鸟王的徽章。使用后，可在指定掷骰时额外增加一枚骰子，每局游戏可使用两次。
Aranka gave me this die to make it easier for me to play against her husband.
阿兰卡给了我这颗骰子，可以用来对付她的丈夫。
The third and last in the line of demonic dice.
恶魔般的骰子的第三个，也是最后一个。
A more reliable die than a normal one, but it cannot be relied on for everything.
比普通骰子更可靠，但不能太过依赖它。
One could say it will get you out of the frying pan into the fire. And sometimes it will let you stew in your own juice.
刚出龙潭，又入虎穴，有时候还会让你被咬上几口。
A blue die mirroring the sadness of its original owner.
这颗蓝色的骰子映照出其主人内心的悲伤。
For some reason, this die usually rolls a three. Why?
不知为何经常掷出3的骰子，所以究竟为什么？
It is actually not all that lucky, but don't tell anyone!
其实没那么幸运，不过不要告诉别人！
Using this badge will double the point value of your last throw. Can be use three times per game.
使用此徽章可让你上一次掷骰的分数翻倍，每局游戏可使用三次。
You double the score of your last throw. Can be used twice per game
你可以将上一次掷骰的出目翻倍。每局游戏可使用2次。
Using it will allow you to roll one extra die. Can be used twice per game
使用后，可在指定掷骰时额外增加一枚骰子，每局游戏可使用两次。
Using it will allow you to roll one extra die. Can be used three times per game
使用后，可在指定掷骰时额外增加一枚骰子。每局游戏可使用三次。
Use it to add one extra die to your throw. Can be used once per game.
使用后，可在指定掷骰时额外增加一枚骰子。每局游戏可使用一次。
Using this badge, you will gain triple points for every 1+1+1 dice combination. Emperor's don't lose.
这枚徽章可让你每1+1+1的骰子组合获得三倍分数。君主永不败。
You gain a new dice formation called The Eye, consisting of the values1, 3 and 5.
你骰出了点数1、3、5。这个组合名为“全视之眼”
You gain a new dice formation called the Cut, consisting of 3+5.
你骰出了点数3、5。这个组合名为“切割”
You gain a new dice combination called The Gallows, which consists of 4, 5 and 6.
你骰出了点数4、5、6。这个组合名为“绞刑台”。
A common ladies leather shoes with a round toe, also known as crocs. They are worn by women and girls from the whole society.
常见的圆头女士皮鞋，也称为“crocs”，各个阶层的女士和女孩都会穿戴。
Women's embellished leather shoes with a sharp toe. They are worn mainly by bourgeois and noblewomen.
有装饰的女士皮鞋，鞋头尖，主要由中产阶层和贵族女性穿着。
Using this badge will give you a large point lead at the start of the game.
使用此徽章可让你在游戏开始时获得大量的分数领先。
You gain a small point lead at the start of the game.
你在游戏开始时将获得少量分数领先。
Use it to get a moderate point lead at the start of the game.
使用后可在游戏开始时获得一定程度的分数领先。
Letter from a secret admirer to Knight Florian.
一位秘密崇拜者写给弗洛里安骑士的信。
Black rooster feathers. They seem more fallen than plucked out.
黑色的公鸡羽毛。看起来像是自然脱落，而不是被拔掉的。
A tasty freshwater fish, ideal for frying, baking, or adding to a soup. How come this one doesn't have a single bone?
一种美味的淡水鱼，是油炸、烧烤或煲汤的理想食材。这块鱼肉里怎么会一根鱼刺都没有？
It is said Katherine will fall head over heels in love with whoever drinks the potion.
据说，凯瑟琳会爱上喝下这份药剂的人。
At first glance, an ordinary dagger that seems to beg for another soul hidden in the heart.
乍一看是一把普通的匕首，刀刃正渴求鲜血的滋味。
Are these actually demon droppings or just ordinary charcoal?
这些东西是真的恶魔粪，还是只是普通的木炭？
This delicacy has great sentimental value.
这种美味承载着深厚的情感价值。
I expect the people who work at Bach have no choice but to keep this with them at all times.
我觉得在巴赫工作的人都不得不随时带着这东西。
It is palatable to the simple peasants, the poor and the cattle. The nobility often turn up their noses at it, but Lady Jitka seems to be an exception.
它对于农民、穷人和牲畜来说十分美味，贵族则通常对其嗤之以鼻。吉特卡小姐是个例外。
Ordinary spectacles of a certain Kapihorian scholar E. Leminger.
一位卡皮霍里亚学者，E·莱明格的普通眼镜。
A golden chalice gifted to the vineyard by one Pippo Spano of Ozora.
奥佐拉的皮波·斯帕诺赠予葡萄园的金杯
A strange concoction smelling of oil and hemlock. If it's supposed to kill weeds, it'll surely work on humans too.
奇怪的混合物，散发着油和毒芹的气味。要是它能杀死杂草，那它对人也会有效果。
A dagger that can rid the world of superfluous entities and retain only the most essential - God.
这把匕首可以抹去世上一切多余的实体，只保留最纯粹的本质——上帝本身。
A potion found in the cradle in von Bergow's chamber. What will his sons grow up to be when he pours them this?
在冯·波尔高房间的挂架上发现的药剂。要是他给他的孩子喝下这个会怎么样？
Water from the Bach stream that's been distilled and purified several times. It might even be drinkable now.
从巴赫河里打上来的河水，已经过多次过滤与净化。现在或许甚至能直接饮用了。
A chalice from some sort of bandit expedition. It seems to have a sentimental value for Zizka.
一次剿匪行动时获得的金杯，对杰式卡来说似乎有特殊意义。
An odd device full of cogs, dials and other mechanisms I know nothing about. I hear it's called an astrolabe, but that doesn't tell me much about what it's used for.
一个奇怪的装置，里面全是齿轮、刻度盘，还有其它我叫不上名字的组件。听说它叫“星盘”，但从名字上看不出有什么用。

Or, The Book about the Heavens and the Earth is an important work by the French philosopher and astronomer Nicole Oresme. In the book he speculates, among other things, that the visible movement of the heavenly bodies from the earth may be only apparent and its real cause is the movement of the earth through the cosmos.
或者，按照法国哲学家和天文学家尼古拉·奥雷姆在他的著作《天地论》中推测的那样，地球上看到的天体在运动只是表象，实际上这是因为地球本身在宇宙中运动而产生的现象。
A strange verse, probably referring to a certain place in Kuttenberg.
一首奇怪的诗，可能暗指库滕堡的某个地方。
A map of the Kuttenberg underground, which has been used for not entirely honourable purposes.
库滕堡地下区域的地图，曾被用来做过坏事。
An unsightly mixture of meat and lead. Inedible.
肉和铅的混合物。不堪入目，也入不了口。
A valuable trophy that will bring glory to any hunter and a noose to any poacher who acquires it.
宝贵的战利品，会给猎人们带来荣耀，也会把偷猎者带上绞架。
Freshly extracted sheep guts. Carrying something like that around is a bit... disgusting.
刚取出的羊内脏。随身携带这种东西有点……恶心。
The least dangerous part of the wolf and the easiest to carry.
狼身上最不危险也最容易携带的部分。
An apple a day keeps the apothecary away. It's not terribly nutritious, but stays fresh a long time.
每天一苹果，医生远离我。虽然不是特别有营养，但能保鲜很久。
They say an apple a day keeps the sawbones away. When you boil them it makes for a tasty treat.
有人说，每天一苹果，医生远离我。此外，煮熟的苹果非常好吃。
Nothing special, but at least it will not spoil.
没什么特别之处，但至少不会变质。
A red apple, like it was just picked. It sparkles beautifully.
一颗红苹果，就像刚刚摘下来一样闪闪发光。
Simple elbow pads with round rondels. Unless one can afford better armour, every protection counts.
配有圆形护板的简易肘部护具。除非能负担起更好的护甲，此类护具亦然重要。
Better hand protection is a must in combat because as they say: hands go first in any fight.
加强手部保护是战斗中的必行之事，毕竟人们常说：任何战斗中，冲在最前面的就是你的手。
Simple elbow pads. You can suffer all sorts of injuries in combat, so it's best to protect yourself however you can.
简易肘部护具。人们可能会在战斗中受到各种伤害，因此尽可能地保护自身就尤为重要。

Full arm and forearm protection made of precision-forged and perfectly aligned metal plates. The armour is decorated with brass lining on the edges. It is named after the famous armour workshops in Nuremberg, Germany, where it may have originated, but is now commonly made in other cities.
由精良打造并完美对齐的金属板制成的全臂和前臂护甲。护甲的边缘饰有黄铜镶边，它以德国纽伦堡著名的盔甲工坊命名，这一护甲可能起源于此地，但现在在其他城市中也常有锻造。
Protection of the whole arm and forearm by precisely fitted metal plates. The armour is decorated with brass and artistic ornaments.
由精确契合的金属板构成的护甲，可保护整个后壁和前臂，护甲上饰有黄铜和具艺术风格的饰品。
Placeholder weapons. If you see this in game, report it!
占位符武器。如果你在游戏中看到这个，请向我们汇报！
As long as it served, it had purpose.
A cheap, homemade arrow. I've seen better.
廉价的自制箭矢，我见过比这更好的。
An arrow with serrated arrowhead to increase damage and bleeding.
箭头呈锯齿状的箭矢，可提升伤害、加剧流血效果。
A well-balanced arrow with a serrated arrowhead to increase damage and bleeding.
平衡良好的箭矢，箭头呈锯齿状，可提升伤害、加剧流血效果。
An arrow designed for hunting game. It is extra accurate, and causes more damage.
一支专用于狩猎的箭矢，精确度和伤害均更高。
A well-balanced arrow designed for hunting game, it is slightly more accurate and causes more bleeding.
一支平衡性良好、专用于狩猎的箭矢，精确度和伤害略微提高。
A common arrow used to fire from a bow.
An arrow with a heavy arrowhead designed to pierce armour.
配载重型箭头的箭矢，用于击穿护甲。
A well-balanced arrow with a heavy arrowhead designed to pierce armour.
平衡性良好的箭矢，配载重型箭头，用于击穿护甲。
An arrow with modified fletching designed for better accuracy at long range.
箭羽经过改良的箭矢，专用于长距离精准射击。
A well-balanced arrow with modified fletching designed for better accuracy at long range.
平衡性良好的箭矢，且箭羽经过改良，专用于长距离精准射击。
An arrow designed for tournament shooting, not suitable for combat.
专门用于射箭竞技的箭矢，不适用于战斗。
The bearded axe is a battle axe which is a simple tool in its origin, but it can chop down shields as well as trees.
由简单工具演化而来的一种战斧，既能劈开盾牌，也能砍倒树木。
The battle axe, called a broadaxe, is related to the ordinary carpenter's axe, but is much lighter and forged specifically for combat. It's a good weapon against shields and chain mail.
宽刃斧是一种战斧，与普通木匠斧相似，但要轻得多，专门为战斗而锻造。能轻松劈开盾牌和锁甲。
The horseman's pick is a light riding axe with a spike. Used correctly, it's a good friend in a pinch. Its sharp point can cut through armour, its blade through any shield.
骑兵镐是一种带有尖刺的轻型骑兵斧。使用得当的话，在紧要关头能发挥很大用处。它锋利的斧尖可以轻易击穿盔甲，而斧刃则可以劈开任何盾牌。
A knight's battle axe. A dexterous weapon that can pierce good armour or crush the bones underneath with its spike. It also has a pointed tip to finish off tougher opponents.
骑士战斧是一种灵活的武器，其刃既可以击穿坚固的盔甲，也可以敲碎盔甲之下的骨头。它还有一个尖头，可以用来对付更难缠的对手。
Cuman long-handled fokos. A fast and agile weapon of the Hungarian raiders. It can pierce light armour or the skull of a good Christian.
库曼长柄战斧。匈牙利人常用的一种敏捷的武器。它可以轻易穿透轻甲，或击碎一个基督徒的头骨。
A lightweight, well-forged war axe. The blade forged into the point replaces the spike, which can be used to cut through the ring armour and the belly underneath.
轻便，锻造精良的战斧。斧刃被锻造成尖头形状，代替了传统的尖刺，可以用来切穿锁子甲，开肠破肚。
Lightweight axe designed for work in the woods or on the farm. An invaluable tool for all woodcutters, but also for angry people who don't have a better weapon at hand.
轻便的工作斧，专为森林或农场的工作而设计。对伐木工来说是必备的工具，而对愤怒的人而言，在手头没有其他东西的时候也能做一件趁手兵器。
Heavy work axe used by carpenters for working beams. If there's no better weapon at hand, it can become a tool of revenge.
木匠用来加工横梁的重型工作斧。但如果手头没有别的武器，它自然也可以用来反击。
This axe is done choping. First Kunesh, then Jezhek. The chain of unfortunate fate is broken with you.
这把斧头已无法再挥砍。先是库尼什，后到杰泽克，悲惨命途的锁链到了你这里就已中断。
An axe made by the skilful hands of a blacksmith in Skalitz, it always seems to find its way to the one who drinks the most.
斯卡利茨的一位技艺高超的铁匠锻造而出的斧头，它似乎总是能找到那个喝得最多的人。
A talisman made from the boiled finger bone of a dead unbaptized child protects against unwanted conception. -5 erection bonus.
未受洗的死婴指骨烹煮后制成的护身符，可以防止意外怀孕。-5勃起加成。
A talisman made from the teeth of an unfortunate dead child will protect a thief from capture. +3 luck bonus and -3 enemy speed.
一种用早夭孩童的牙齿制成的护身符，可以庇护小偷，让他们不被抓住。+3运气加值，-3敌人速度。
A talisman made from the thumb of a dead dwarf is said to help a woman conceive a son. +2 erection bonus.
据说，死去矮人的拇指制成的护身符可以帮助女性怀上儿子。+2勃起加成。
Dead miner's left boot. Boots for the grave are just for show, they don't actually use them for walking. Hopefully.
一位已故矿工的左靴，这种陪葬的靴子只是摆设，实际上穿不了。希望如此吧。
The right boot of a dead miner. Boots for burial are just for show, not for walking. One hopes.
一位已故矿工的右靴，这种陪葬的靴子只是摆设，实际上穿不了。希望如此吧。
A talisman made from the head of a dead man, buried under a full moon. It's said to protect a thief from dogs. +2 to howling at the moon.
用死人头骨制成的护身符，埋于满月之夜的土中。据说可以保护小偷免受狗的伤害。+2对着月亮嚎叫。
A talisman made from the hair of a dead virgin. It's said to protect its wearer against venereal diseases. +8 gonorrhea resistance.
用已逝处女的头发做成的护身符，据说可以保护佩戴者免受性病侵害。+8淋病抗性
This talisman from the body of a hanged man is said to bring good luck to thieves.
据说，这个从被绞死者身上取下的护身符能为盗贼带来好运。
A nail from the coffin of a revenant is said to protect its wearer from those who've returned from the dead. +3 damage to undead.
据说从死而复生之人的棺材中取下的钉子，能保护佩戴者免受回魂者的伤害。对亡灵+3伤害。
Bronze seal of a rich mining magnate and shaft owner.
A silver-plated button from a dead miner's clothing.
一个死去矿工衣服上的镀银纽扣。
The small brass cross is a symbol of Christian modesty, because no one takes any wealth with them to the next world.
这个小黄铜十字架是基督教教义里谦逊的象征，因为没有人能将财富带到来世。
Fine smoked bacon, filling and pleasing.
一块不错的熏猪肉，令人满足，令人愉悦。
Jewish pastry with a beautifully soft crumb and a crispy crust.
一种外酥里嫩，无比美味的犹太糕点。
A lead ball. It rattles a little in the barrel, but at least it's easy to load. Even the best plate armour can't stop it up close!
铅制弹丸。它会在枪管中发出咔哒声响，但要想装填此弹药并不困难。即便是最坚硬的板甲也无法在近距离抗住它的攻击！
A longer strip of clean cloth that can safely stop bleeding.
干净的长布条，可以安全地止血。
Makes running impossible and reduces Health by 110 in 60 seconds. More suitable for poisoning cooking pots than applying to weapons.
致人丧失奔跑能力，且在1分钟内减少110点生命值。相比于涂抹在武器上，把它洒进别人的餐食里才是明智之选。
Makes running impossible and reduces Health by 110 in 45 seconds. More suitable for poisoning cooking pots than applying to weapons.
致人丧失奔跑能力，且在45秒内减少110点生命值。相比于涂抹在武器上，把它洒进别人的餐食里才是明智之选。
Makes running impossible and reduces Health by 110 in 30 seconds. More suitable for poisoning cooking pots than applying to weapons.
致人丧失奔跑能力，且在30秒内减少110点生命值。相比于涂抹在武器上，把它洒进别人的餐食里才是明智之选。
Makes running impossible and reduces Health by 110 in 15 seconds. More suitable for poisoning cooking pots than applying to weapons.
致人丧失奔跑能力，且在15秒内减少110点生命值。相比于涂抹在武器上，把它洒进别人的餐食里才是明智之选。
A helmet called a bascinet with a wide chainmail aventail that protects the neck and shoulders of the warrior.
名为“bascinet”的头盔，配有宽阔的链甲颈甲，可保护战士的脖颈和肩膀。
A helmet called a bascinet forged from a single piece of sheet metal. In this basic form, it has no bretache or klappvisor and therefore does not protect the warrior's face.
名为“bascinet”的头盔，有单片金属片锻造而成。这种基础款式的头盔并未配备保护片或翻盖面甲，因此无法保护战士的脸部。

A helmet called a bascinet protecting the whole head except the face, so it looks a bit like a bell. Very often used by marksmen because the face is not covered by any visor and it is easy to see the target.
名为“bascinet”的头盔，为除脸颊外的整个头部提供保护，因此形状与钟相似。这种头盔常由弓箭手穿戴，因为脸部未设面甲，便于佩戴者清晰地观察目标。
An older form of the bascinet with a removable wide bretache, complete with a chainmail aventail protecting the warrior's neck and shoulders.
旧式钢盔，配有可拆卸的宽型保护片，还附带可保护战士脖颈和肩膀的链甲颈甲。

A helmet of a peculiar pointed shape, not used in our lands for a long time, favoured by nomads on the eastern steppes. The Cumans are fond of adorning it with horsehair, and some evil tongues claim that also with the hair of good christian virgins.
形状特异的尖顶头盔，在我们国家已很久未被使用，主要受东部草原的游牧民族青睐。库曼人喜欢用马鬃装饰这种头盔，有些恶意言论称，头盔上还装饰着基督教处女的头发。
A foreign helmet of a peculiar shape originating from the eastern steppes, worn by the Cuman horsemen. It is feared because it is associated with raiders who have burned many villages.
源自东部草原、形状奇特的外来头盔，由库曼骑兵佩戴。此种头盔令人畏惧，因为它与焚毁许多村庄的劫掠者有所关联。
A large bascinet decorated with a gilded lion statuette, excellent for jousting tournaments. According to legend, it belonged to the Bohemian prince Brunswick.
大型钢盔，饰有镀金狮子雕像，适用于马术对决。据说此头盔曾属于波希米亚王子布伦瑞克。
A helmet called a bascinet with a fitted klappvisor of an older drop-shaped pattern. The helmet is fitted with a wide chainmail aventail, so it protects the whole head and shoulders of the warrior.
名为“bascinet”的头盔，配有旧式水滴形状的翻盖面甲。这种头盔还配有宽阔的链甲颈甲，所以可为战士的整个头部和肩膀提供防护。

A helmet called a bascinet with a fitted klappvisor. It has been pejoratively nicknamed the dog's snout because of its strange shape, but it is easier to breathe in it and is more durable than its older models.
名为“bascinet”的头盔，配有翻盖面甲。因其形状奇特，人们戏谑地称其为“狗鼻盔”，但它比旧式头盔更便于呼吸，也更加耐用。
