An unfinished list of food and drink needed for the wedding feast.
婚宴所需食物和饮料的清单，物品尚未列完。

<paragraph>The bride, Agnes, shall bring to the marriage as her dowry two long brocades, six embroidered robes, three good winter coats and two lined summer robes. Three Bardejov hats and two men's fine rabbit hats. Also linen for three beds and pillows and quilts of good goose down. Utensils of copper and pewter sufficient for two full tables and a very fine mirror in a frame of bone. Of jewels, two necklaces of river pearls, two brooches of silver and one inlaid with almandine, called the Marian brooch.</paragraph>
<paragraph>新娘阿格尼丝将以下物品作为其嫁妆：两条长丝绸，两件刺绣长袍，三件上好冬衣和两件衬里的夏袍，三顶巴尔德约夫帽子和两顶男士兔毛帽，三张床的床单和优质鹅绒的枕头和被子，足够摆满两张桌子的铜和锡器皿，以及一个镶有骨架的精美镜子。珠宝包括两条河珍珠项链，两枚银胸针和一枚镶有石榴石的、称做“玛丽安胸针”的胸针。</paragraph>
Another excerpt from the draft of the wedding contract between Lord Semine and Bailiff Thrush.
关于塞米领主和瑟鲁什执行官之间婚约草案的另一段摘录。

<paragraph>On the part of the free magistrate <accent>Drozda</accent>, the marriage of his daughter is to be secured by the yearly proceeds of ten corners of corn or half of that given on anything else, and half a penny from the possession of the hereditary fast. And all this is to pass outright to the children who come of the union.</paragraph> <paragraph>On the part of Mr. <accent>of Semin</accent>, the covenant is supported by the whole of the property which shall pass to his son Oldrich, except such property as shall be acquired afterwards, or shall fall to the gift for the salvation of the soul of Mr. John of Semin.</paragraph>

<paragraph><accent>德罗兹达</accent>一方为确保其女儿的婚姻，将每年提供十角谷物作为保障，其中一半可以由其它任何形式的财产代替。此外，还将让渡一部分遗产的继承权。这些资产最终将直接归属于双方在婚姻中生下的子嗣。</paragraph> <paragraph><accent>塞米</accent>一方承诺，将他目前的全部财产转让给儿子奥尔德里希，今后获得的财产，以及塞米的约翰死后，为安抚其灵魂而捐赠的财产不算在内。</paragraph>
Part of the draft of the marriage contract between the lord of Semine and bailiff Thrush, a free farmer from Troskowitz.
塞米领主与特罗斯科维茨的自由农夫、执行官瑟鲁什的婚约草案的一部分。

<subtitle>On the Wisdom of the Elders</subtitle> <paragraph>A father says to his son on his wedding day, 'Remember, son, that a newlywed woman loves well and cooks badly. But wait a few years and it will be just the opposite.'</paragraph>
<subtitle>过来人的智慧</subtitle> <paragraph>父亲在儿子的婚礼日对他说：“记住，儿子，新婚的女人爱意深沉，厨艺却很糟，几年之后，就会完全反过来了。”</paragraph>

<subtitle>Wedding toast</subtitle> <paragraph>Unfortunately, I don't know the bride, so I can't congratulate her groom. And knowing the groom too well, neither can I congratulate the bride.</paragraph>
<subtitle>婚礼祝词</subtitle> <paragraph>遗憾的是，我不认识新娘，所以没法祝贺新郎。我对新郎了解甚多，所以也没法祝贺新娘。</paragraph>

<newpage/><subtitle>Thinking is Not Knowing</subtitle> <paragraph>A certain Kuttenberg gentleman once visited an old charlatan and wanted to know his fate. The charlatan examined his palm carefully and said to him, 'I see you are the father of two children...' 'You're mistaken,' he shook his head. 'I am the father of three children!' 'It is you who are mistaken!' smiled the charlatan. </paragraph>
<newpage/><subtitle>想象非真知</subtitle> <paragraph>从前，库滕堡有一位男子拜访了一位年长的占卜师，希望了解自身的命运。占卜师认真地观察了他的手掌后说道：“我看到你有两个孩子……”“那只是你的想象罢了，”男子摇了摇头说，“我有三个孩子！”“但那也只是你的想象……”占卜师微笑着回答。</paragraph>

<newpage/><heading>Repent, Adam's Gender</heading> <subtitle>A. von Wallenstein and Raimund R. Hardt on men and women</subtitle> <paragraph>As many, and men in particular, will gladly testify, of the two genders, it is the female that is imperfect, prone to all manner of sins and faults. It is an old known truth that the testimony of many is a credible testimony, the truth of which cannot be doubted. But who hath appointed the woman her lot? God? Or man? Who has decreed that woman is incapable of thinking, acting and deciding without the guidance of man?</paragraph> <paragraph>By whom was it determined that women were too foolish and vice-ridden to participate in matters wholly male - politics, science, or the liberal arts? Is such a resolution supported by experience or evidence? After all, no one has ever given a woman the opportunity to demonstrate the necessary judgement and wit. We have only conveniently condemned it as inadequate and have made this judgement an established truth which no one dares to question. </paragraph> <paragraph>We have witnessed many injuries to the daughters of Eve, and therefore may, or rather must, testify that the world is unjustly ordered in this respect. Men are fond of exalting themselves above women and attributing all sorts of wrongs to them, but only to cover their own faults!</paragraph> <paragraph>A man who accuses a woman of vice has squandered his own youth in licentiousness. In old age, these men recall with regret the sins of their past life without ever repenting of them. It is out of this bitterness that they denounce women, in order to humiliate and vilify them in the minds of all who are willing to listen to them. These corrupt old men are like incurable leprosy.</paragraph> <paragraph>But even more than women, men prefer to elevate themselves above other men. For example, they claim that husbands who listen to their wives' advice are fools and deserve ridicule. But we say that a man who has a wife who is sensible and wise, and refuses to listen to her, is twice as foolish!</paragraph>

<newpage/><heading>悔改吧，亚当之子</heading> <subtitle>瓦伦施泰因和雷蒙德关于男女的论述</subtitle> <paragraph>在讨论男性与女性的议题上，许多人，特别是男性，常常声称女性是不完美的，容易犯各种罪过和错误。一条古老且公认的真理是：多数人的证词就是可信的证词，其真实性不容置疑。但是谁为女性定下这样的命运？是上帝还是男性？又有谁规定女性不能在没有男性指导的情况下思考、行动和决策？</paragraph> <paragraph>又是谁将女性定义为愚昧和陋习缠身，认为她们无法参与所谓“纯粹男性的领域”——政治、科学或自由艺术？这样的决议是否有经验或证据作为支撑？说到底，从未有人给予女性机会来展示她们所需的判断力和智慧，人们只是自顾自地认定她们能力不足，并将这一判断奉为既定事实，无人敢于质疑。</paragraph> <paragraph>我们见证过太多对夏娃之女的诽谤与中伤，因此我们可以，或者说必须站出来，证明这个世界在性别平等方面的不公。男性常常将自己凌驾于女性之上，并将种种罪责归咎于她们，但这一切只是为了掩盖他们自己的缺点！</paragraph> <paragraph>那些指责女性有恶习的男性，往往在年轻时也沉溺于放纵的生活。这些男性到了晚年，虽然对自身过去的罪行感到后悔，却从未真心悔改。正是出于这种心态，他们谴责女性，以便在所有与他们一派的人心中羞辱和诋毁她们。而他们的这些言论，就如同麻风病般在社会上蔓延。</paragraph> <paragraph>但与对女性的贬低相比，男人欺压其他男人的行为更胜一筹。比如，他们会嘲笑那些听从妻子建议的丈夫，认为这是愚蠢的行为。但如果一个男人有通情达理且聪慧的妻子，却不愿听从她建议，那才是真正的愚蠢！</paragraph>
<subtitle>The Gravedigger's Jest</subtitle> <paragraph>What do you call a woman who knows exactly where her husband is every night? A widow.</paragraph>
<subtitle>掘墓人笑话</subtitle> <paragraph>什么样的女人能知道丈夫每晚都在哪？答案是寡妇！</paragraph>

<subtitle>On Innocence</subtitle> <paragraph>A young man tenderly embraces his beloved and asks, 'Am I your first lover by any chance?' 'Could be,' she replies. 'I thought I'd seen you somewhere before.'</paragraph>
<subtitle>纯真</subtitle> <paragraph>一位年轻男子温柔地拥抱他的爱人，问道：“我是否是你的初恋？”女子回答说：“也许吧，我觉得我在哪里见过你。”</paragraph>

<heading>Lullaby</heading><paragraph>This poison will not bring quick death, but its effects may be even more terrible. It soothes a man in a reasonable quantity, and gives him rest, that his body may be speedily healed, but if it be given by a person of dishonest intentions, his victim falls into a sound sleep, in which he does not feels his body, and may be treated so unkindly and cruelly. If drank oftenly, the healthy spirit then leaves the body.</paragraph><paragraph>A man intoxicated with the Lullaby concoction feels faint, his tongue is confused, his head is heavy, and he soon falls asleep. When more than in moderation, however, a man drinks suddenly, he vomits it up, and it loses all its effect.</paragraph><paragraph>If you want to relieve people around you with Lullaby, prepare for yourself oil, thistle, herb paris and especially a handful of poppies, which give the decoction a vibrant odour and a sparkling color, and can overcome the disgust of herb paris.</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>“摇篮曲”</heading><paragraph>此毒药并不会令人当场暴毙，但其影响或许更加不容小觑。适当剂量可使人安定，促人休息，饮用者的身体或将迅速痊愈。但倘若此药剂落入不法分子之手，可让受害者失去知觉，彻底陷入沉睡，期间或将自身难保。长期饮用此药剂，人们健康的精神状态就会彻底崩坏。</paragraph><paragraph>遭“摇篮曲”麻醉之人将感受到扑面袭来的眩晕，他舌头发麻，头重脚轻，很快便会酣然入睡。而突然的过量饮用则会让饮用者将其呕出，使药效彻底消散。</paragraph><paragraph>若你想使用催眠药抚慰身边之人，需准备好油、蓟草以及四叶重楼，尤其要准备一把罂粟，它不仅能为药剂添上扑鼻芳香和粼粼色泽，还能掩盖四叶重楼的恶心感。</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>Pitohui Bird Poison</heading><paragraph>This is one of the rarest, for it is obtained only from the feathers and skin of the Pitohui. This creature, of a black and yellow colour, has its origin far beyond the land of the Indians, and the touch of it causes considerable trouble to man. The killers, therefore, have no need to prepare any decoctions, but only to make headdresses and necklaces of the feathers for their victims.</paragraph><paragraph>Those who come into contact with the feathers of the Pitohui often feel a tingling and tension in their muscles. This condition can persist for days, giving the murderer the time he needs to escape. In such cases, it is enough to burn the feathers and the poisoning will pass. If, however, the unfortunate ingests the essence of the feathers prepared by a long boil, expect more serious consequences. The victim first stiffens and soon dies, unless a drink of sea-water and crushed stone from the mountains of Monti Pallidi, which thou shalt find in the Italian land, be prepared in time.</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>“小毒雨燕毒素”</heading><paragraph>在最罕见的毒药之中，此毒药正占得一席之位，因为它只能通过小毒雨燕的羽毛和皮肤制作而成。小毒雨燕周身黄黑相间，其起源地远在印度的土地之外，触碰它的人会感受到相当程度的痛苦。因此，如欲借此杀人，不必熬制任何毒性药剂，仅需使用小毒雨燕的羽毛为谋杀目标制作头饰或项链即可。</paragraph><paragraph>触碰小毒雨燕羽毛的人时常会感到肌肉刺痛与紧张，这一状况会持续好几天，因此给了凶手足够的逃跑时间。这种情况下，烧掉羽毛，中毒症状就会过去。但是，倘若受害者不慎摄入了经过长时间熬煮的羽毛精华，后果将更为严重。起初，受害者会像一块木板，全身僵直，除非能及时准备好海水与在意大利苍白山脉弄来的碎石，否则无需多久便会死去。</paragraph><newpage/>
<title>The Book of Poison</title><subtitle>about abominable poisons and their remedies</subtitle><newpage/>
<title>毒药注解</title><subtitle>解析万人唾弃之毒药及解毒艺法</subtitle><newpage/>

<heading>Kiss of Death</heading><paragraph> Although difficult to prepare, this potion is often used because its pleasant aroma can be confused with ordinary cooking. It is also said among the poor that this mixture can be used to turn metals into gold.</paragraph><paragraph>The Kiss of Death will first cause a stomachache. It makes the skin red and blistered, the bowels painfully empty at both ends, the udders stiffen in spasm, and the nails break. And then thou shalt know that death is certain, but before that thou mayest relieve the poor man with a bezoar put under the tongue. In quick reaction, a mixture of hot milk, vinegar, and garlic can also be used to cause the poison to be thrown up.</paragraph><paragraph>If you want to make this poison, take a new clay pot, put a handful of red copper, half a bottle of strong water, arsenic, oak bark, and rose water inside. Boil it all, and test it with an iron nail. When the muddy mixture has completely coated the iron, you will know that you have cooked enough.</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>“死神之吻”</heading><paragraph>尽管制作起来并不简单，但此毒药那惹人喜爱的芳香能与日常菜肴混在一起，因此广为人用。而且据说，穷人们都认为此药剂具有点铁成金的效用。</paragraph><paragraph>“死神之吻”首先会导致腹痛，随后致使皮肤泛红起水泡，使人上吐下泻，喉咙痉挛，指甲断裂。随后，死亡很快便接踵而至，但在这之前，你可将牛黄放至患者舌头之下以减轻痛苦。若反应及时，可让患者饮用热奶、酸醋与大蒜的混合物，便可促使毒素倾吐而出。</paragraph><paragraph>制作此毒药需准备好一口新的陶罐，往其中加入一把紫铜、半瓶蒸馏酒、砒霜、橡树皮以及玫瑰水。煮沸后将铁钉放置其中，若罐中浑浊物完全附着于铁钉之上，即表明制药已成。</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>Dollmaker Potion</heading><paragraph>This potion is especially useful because it soothes and relieves pain. It is therefore a favourite among the physicians. If you rub even a few drops on the skin of a wounded man, you can cut him without causing him suffering. Men who are hasty in their love rub their manhood with this potion too, so that it may become numb and they may manage to please their wives.</paragraph><paragraph>A fool who tastes even a sip of the potion will experience total numbness, his intestines will become clogged, and he may lose his sight for a while. Fortunately, the stomach will eject this disgusting potion before it has time to have its pernicious effect, unless the body has already been weakened.</paragraph><paragraph>If you need to replenish your supply of this decoction, prepare yourself a strong liquor, a handful of valerian and twice as much herb paris. Remember, however, not to boil the valerian in the liquor, but only to put the crushed valerian into the cold decoction!</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>“玩偶药剂”</heading><paragraph>此药剂能够缓解疼痛，颇有药用价值，也因此深受医生喜爱。假如在一位伤者皮肤上擦上几滴，你就能对他进行无痛手术。那些欲火焚身的男人同样也会擦拭这种药剂，好让相关部位变得迟钝，进而取悦他们的爱妻。</paragraph><paragraph>要是哪个傻瓜喝了这种药剂，哪怕只是抿上一口，他的身体将会完全麻木，肠道堵塞的同时还会短暂失明。好在幸运的是，除非你身体虚弱，否则健康的肠胃能够在如此恼人药剂发挥作用前就进行修复。</paragraph><paragraph>制作此药剂需准备烈酒、一把缬草和两把四叶重楼。但是记住，千万别将缬草放入烈酒中熬煮，而是将碾碎的缬草撒入熬制完成并充分冷却的药剂中。</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>Bane</heading><paragraph>A particularly evil potion, which causes certain death even in small quantities. It is widespread especially in Bohemia and Austria, because the plants necessary for its preparation are everywhere plentiful. Do not expect much benefit from the knowledge of this poison, for it can be used for nothing but killing.</paragraph><paragraph>When an unfortunate man who has swallowed this poison comes to you for advice, give glory to God, for it is a miracle that he is still alive. For a little while thou mayest observe in him the blackness of the eyes, the dryness of the body, or the looseness of the muscles, but then send for the priest at once. Even a few drops will cause certain death, and there is no guaranteed antidote in the whole wide world.</paragraph><paragraph>If you have to cook this abomination, prepare yourself some wine, a handful of wormwood and twice as much belladonna. Then you shall finish the evil work with Fly agaric. Boil the mixture until you have a clear liquid, almost imperceptible in taste and smell.</paragraph><newpage/>

<heading>“祸根”</heading><paragraph>毒性极恶，微小剂量便能致人死地。制作该毒药所需的药材广泛生长于波希米亚及奥地利地区，因此此毒药在以上两处区域尤为常见。别指望熟知这种毒药就能够从中获益，因为它除了用来杀人外并无其他用途。</paragraph><paragraph>要是有个饮下了这种毒药的可怜人来向你求助，最好先感谢上帝的护佑，因为他此刻还能活着便是奇迹。片刻后，你或许就能注意到，他瞳孔发黑、身体干涩，或是肌肉松弛，然后你就得立刻去找牧师来为他超度。如此毒药，哪怕是几滴就足以让人魂飞魄散，即便在这广阔的大千世界，也根本找不到任何解药。</paragraph><paragraph>制作此毒药需准备一些葡萄酒、一把艾草及两把颠茄，在后续的流程中还需使用毒蝇伞。将混合溶液煮沸，直至液体变得清澈透明，味道和气味几乎无法被察觉。</paragraph><newpage/>

<paragraph>The most honourable man and commander of the military camp by Kuttenberg, the noble lord Grozav of Borumlaca, hereby confirms by this letter that he has received the sum of six threescores from the cuman Chertan, and is therefore obliged to pay his debt duly.</paragraph><paragraph>The noble lord of Borumlaca further promises that he will not use any goods or cattle to repay his debt, in return for which the cuman Chertan has promised not to sell the note and not to mention its existence.</paragraph>
<paragraph>库滕堡军营最尊贵的指挥官，博鲁姆拉卡的高贵领主格罗扎夫，特此以此信件确认，已从库曼人赫尔坦处收到了六个三十格罗申的款项，并将适时偿还债务。</paragraph><paragraph>博鲁姆拉卡的高贵领主进一步承诺，他将使用现金，而非使用任何货物或牲畜来偿还债务，而库曼人赫尔坦应承诺不出售这份借据，也不提及其存在。</paragraph>

Brave Sir Markvart of Úlice, Commander of the Prague militia and dear friend.

I have received news of your injury and the progress of the siege of Suchdol fortress, therefore I address you with this letter not as your sovereign, but as a friend.Once your health permits travel, leave the Praguers to handle that cursed fortress as best they can and join me in Hungary. I need you by my side as an advisor and on the Hungarian field as a commander.

I pray for your recovery and our early reunion.

英勇的乌利采的马科瓦尔爵士，布拉格民兵指挥官，亲爱的朋友：

我已收到您受伤的消息以及苏赫多尔堡垒围攻的进展。因此，我以朋友而非君主的身份向您致信。一旦您的健康允许，请尽快离开布拉格，来匈牙利与我会合。那座受诅咒的堡垒就交给布拉格人处理，我需要您在我身边，作为我的顾问和匈牙利战场的指挥官。

我祈祷您的康复，期待我们早日团聚。
A short personal letter from Sigismund.
西格斯蒙德简短的个人信件
A short brief letter from Lord Sokol of Lamberg bearing a coat of arms with a goat head.
一封简短的信件，来自兰贝格的索科尔领主，信封上有一个山羊头纹章。
A short letter from an unknown Moravian nobleman.
来自不知名的摩拉维亚贵族的简短来信。

<paragraph>My dear friend, unfortunately we will not meet as planned because the recent events in the Kingdom of Hungary have forced me to stay in Moravia. Of course, I cannot entrust more details to letters, but I am sure you will understand what I mean when I say the hunters are already gathering and the fox hunt will soon begin.</paragraph><paragraph>Along with the letter, I send you my shield, as there is no need to hide anymore, but rather to openly show what side are we on. May my coat of arms with a goat head bring you good luck and protect you in your righteous fight. God bless you!</paragraph><paragraph>Jan Sokol of Lamberg bearing a coat of arms with a goat head</paragraph>

<paragraph>亲爱的朋友，很不幸，由于匈牙利王国最近的事态，我不得不留在摩拉维亚，我们原定的会面计划无法进行。在信中我不能透露更多细节，我只能说，猎人们已经聚集，猎狐计划即将开始。我相信你明白我的意思。</paragraph><paragraph>随信一同的还有我的盾牌，这象征着我们已经无需隐匿，可以公开我们的立场。愿我刻有山羊头的盾牌能给你带来好运，在正义的战斗中保护你。愿上帝保佑你！</paragraph><paragraph>兰贝格的杨·索科尔与山羊头盾牌</paragraph>

<paragraph>Dear friend, the time has come to finally push the League of Lords against the wall. Their arrogance is outrageous! I managed to persuade Margrave Jobst to join our side. He himself had to admit that, whoever his royal cousin Wenceslas might be, a country without a king benefits only leeches like von Bergow or von Rosenberg.</paragraph><paragraph>Therefore I urge you to go to Trosky, recruit more men for our cause there, and, above all, force Otto von Bergow to withdraw from Prague. I know you will not let me down. I know that when you start something, you finish it. I hope to see you soon. God bless you!</paragraph>

<paragraph>亲爱的朋友，我们终于把那些傲慢的贵族逼入绝境了！我说服了约布斯特侯爵加入我们的阵营。他也明白，不管瓦茨拉夫国王有多昏庸，一个没有国王的国家只会让冯·波尔高或冯·罗森堡这样的寄生虫得利。</paragraph><paragraph>因此，我敦促你去特罗斯基，为我们的事业招募更多人，以及，最重要的是，让奥托·冯·波尔高离开布拉格。我知道，你肯定能办成的，希望不久之后能听到你的喜讯。愿上帝保佑你！</paragraph>
